human: Alpha-enolase is a glycolytic enzyme that catalyses the formation of phosphoenolpyruvate in the cell cytoplasm. α-Enolase and the predominantly nuclear Myc promoter-binding protein-1 (MBP-1) originate from a single gene through the alternative use of translational starting sites. MBP-1 binds to the P2 c-myc promoter and competes with TATA-box binding protein (TBP) to suppress gene transcription. Although several studies have shown an antiproliferative effect of MBP-1 overexpression on several human cancer cells, to date detailed observations of α-enolase and MBP-1 relative expression in primary tumors versus normal tissues and their correlation with clinicopathological features have not been undertaken.We analyzed α-enolase and MBP-1 expression in normal breast epithelium and primary invasive ductal breast carcinoma (IDC) from 177 patients by Western blot and immunohistochemical analyses, using highly specific anti-α-enolase monoclonal antibodies. A significant increase in the expression of cytoplasmic α-enolase was observed in 98% of the tumors analysed, compared to normal tissues. Nuclear MBP-1 was found in almost all the normal tissues while its expression was retained in only 35% of the tumors. Statistically significant associations were observed among the nuclear expression of MBP-1 and ErbB2 status, Ki-67 expression, node status and tumor grade. Furthermore MBP-1 expression was associated with good survival of patients with IDC.
LLM_1: Alpha-enolase is a glycolytic enzyme that catalyzes the formation of phosphoenolpyruvate in the cell cytoplasm. α-Enolase and predominantly nuclear Myc promoter binding protein-1 (MBP-1) originate from a single gene through the use of alternative translation start sites. MBP-1 binds to the P2 c-myc promoter and competes with the TATA box binding protein (TBP) to suppress gene transcription. Although many studies have shown the antiproliferative effect of MBP-1 overexpression on various human cancer cells, detailed observations on the relative expression of α-enolase and MBP-1 between primary tumors and normal tissues, as well as their correlation with clinicopathological features, have not been conducted to date. We examined the expression of α-enolase and MBP-1 in normal breast epithelium and primary invasive ductal breast carcinoma (IDC) samples from 177 patients using high-specificity anti-α-enolase monoclonal antibodies through Western blot and immunohistochemical analyses. A significant increase in cytoplasmic α-enolase expression was observed in 98% of the analyzed tumors compared to normal tissues. Nuclear MBP-1 was found in almost all normal tissues, but was retained in tumors in only 35% of cases. Statistically significant relationships were observed between the nuclear expression of MBP-1 and ErbB2 status, Ki-67 expression, lymph node status, and tumor grade. Additionally, MBP-1 expression was associated with favorable survival in IDC patients.
LLM_2:
Alpha-enolase is a crucial glycolytic enzyme that plays a significant role in cellular metabolism by catalyzing the formation of phosphoenolpyruvate in the cell cytoplasm, a key step in the conversion of glucose to energy. This enzyme is not only essential for energy production but also participates in various cellular processes, including the regulation of cell growth and differentiation. Interestingly, α-enolase and predominantly nuclear Myc promoter binding protein-1 (MBP-1) originate from a single gene through the use of alternative translation start sites, showcasing the complexity of gene expression regulation. 

MBP-1 serves a pivotal role in cellular regulation by binding to the P2 c-myc promoter, where it competes with the TATA box binding protein (TBP). This competition is critical as it leads to the suppression of gene transcription, particularly of genes that promote cell proliferation. The antiproliferative effect of MBP-1 has been highlighted in numerous studies, demonstrating its potential as a tumor suppressor in various human cancer cells. However, despite the established significance of MBP-1, comprehensive investigations into the relative expression levels of α-enolase and MBP-1 in primary tumors compared to normal tissues, along with their correlations to clinicopathological features, remain limited.

In our study, we aimed to address this gap by examining the expression levels of α-enolase and MBP-1 in normal breast epithelium and primary invasive ductal breast carcinoma (IDC) samples from a cohort of 177 patients. Utilizing high-specificity anti-α-enolase monoclonal antibodies, we conducted detailed analyses through Western blot and immunohistochemical techniques. Our findings revealed a striking increase in cytoplasmic α-enolase expression in 98% of the analyzed tumors when compared to normal breast tissues, underscoring its potential role in tumorigenesis and progression.

Conversely, while nuclear MBP-1 was present in nearly all normal tissues, it was retained in tumors in only 35% of cases, suggesting a significant alteration in its expression pattern during cancer development. Furthermore, we observed statistically significant relationships between nuclear MBP-1 expression and several clinicopathological parameters, including ErbB2 status, Ki-67 expression, lymph node involvement, and tumor grade. These correlations imply that MBP-1 may serve as a valuable biomarker for assessing tumor behavior and patient prognosis. Notably, the expression of MBP-1 was associated with improved survival outcomes in IDC patients, highlighting its potential as a therapeutic target and prognostic indicator in breast cancer management. This study not only enhances our understanding of the roles of α-enolase and MBP-1 in breast cancer but also opens avenues for further research into their mechanisms and potential clinical applications.

**My Day with the Girls: A Tale of Adventure and Friendship**

As I sat alongside Elizabeth, I couldn't help but feel a hint of restlessness. But before I dive into the details of my day, let me confess: I wasn't exactly thrilled to start with. However, my excitement soon kicked in, courtesy of some wonderful friends and an action-packed morning.

My day began at a leisurely 9:30 (okay, maybe not so leisure), with a mad dash to get ready. After a hasty shower, it dawned on me that I might just need a coffee IV to stay awake. Before I knew it, reality set in: the day was young, yet I still had a long way to go. With a family to care for, there was no time to waste. Rushing through my tasks, exhaustion caught up with me, leaving me feeling like I'd been hit by a truck (in a good way, of course!). With the morning rush behind me and some hard-earned cash ($300, woohooo!) in my pocket, our group set out to tackle the afternoon.

We started by indulging in some retail therapy – shopping for some adorable lip balm and scrumptious lemon treats. Not to mention, dropping off some fabulous summer memories for Beth. Once we'd worked up an appetite, lunch was served. Double chocolate shakes, crispy bacon sandwiches, whole pizzas... the list goes on. Our tummies were full, spirits high!

After our meal, off we set to catch the latest movie, "Princess Diarist 3" (just kidding, folks!). Unfortunately, that particular show was sold out (insert sad face). Our spirits, however, were not dampened. Instead, they decided to indulge in the delightful world of classic sitcoms – a few episodes each of 'Boy meets World' and 'Family matters.' And so, with our bellies full and our hearts content, came the grand finale of our day: unwinding back at home. It's been quite a day – but one that left us feeling refreshed, renewed, ready to face another beautiful day! The highlight of which will be a visit to our beloved L.B.I. – we can't wait! In the meantime, peace and love to all my lovely friends. Until the next adventure! Excited! [And we are girls]

human: Superoxide dismutases (SOD) have been reported as the most relevant bacterial enzymes involved in cells protection from reactive oxygen species (ROS). These toxic species are often the product of heavy metal stress.Two genes, chrC and chrF, from TnOtchr genetic determinant of strain Ochrobactrum tritici 5bvl1 were cloned in Escherichia coli in order to overexpress the respective proteins. Both proteins were purified and characterized as superoxide dismutases. ChrC was confirmed as being a Fe-SOD, and the enzymatic activity of the ChrF, not inhibited by hydrogen peroxide or potassium cyanide, suggested its inclusion in the Mn-SOD family. This identification was supported by chemical quantification of total metal content in purified enzyme. Both enzymes showed a maximum activity between pH 7.2-7.5. ChrF retained nearly full activity over a broader range of pH and was slightly more thermostable than ChrC. The genes encoding these enzymes in strain O. tritici 5bvl1 were inactivated, developing single and double mutants, to understand the contribution of these enzymes in detoxification mechanism of reactive oxygen species induced by chromate. During chromate stress, assays using fluorescent dyes indicated an increase of these toxic compounds in chrC, chrF and chrC/chrF mutant cells.
LLM_1:
Superoxide dismutation enzymes (SODs) have been reported as the most important bacterial enzymes responsible for protecting cells against reactive oxygen species (ROS). These toxic types are usually products of heavy metal stress. The Tnocr genetic determinant from Ochrobactrum tritici 99b was cloned into Escherichia coli, thereby overexpressing the related proteins. Both proteins were purified and characterized and were designated as superoxide dismutations. ChrC was confirmed as Fe-SOD, and ChrF showed that the enzyme activity was not inhibited by hydrogen peroxide or potassium cyanide, indicating that it belonged to the Mn-SO D family. This characterization was supported by measuring the total metal content of the purified enzyme chemically. 

Both showed maximum activity at a pH of 72-75. CrF maintained almost full activity over a wider pH range and was found to be slightly more robust. Single and double mutations were developed to inactivate the genes of O. tricium 91 to understand the contributions of these enzymes to their ROS-cleaning mechanism. In chromium stress, analyses using fluorescent dyes showed an increase in these toxic compounds in Chr. C, Cr. F and c/f mutant cells.
LLM_2:
Supoxide Dismutase Enzymes (Cu/Zn-Sods and MnSods) Play a Crucial Role in Protecting Bacterial Cells against Reactive Oxygen Species (Ros).

Reactive oxygen Species, typically generated as a result of exposure to heavy metals, pose a significant threat to bacterial cells, leading to cellular damage and oxidative stress.

To elucidate the mechanisms underlying this phenomenon, we cloned the TncR genetic regulator from the bacterium Ochrrobacterium triticum 999 (corrected to  099b) into E. coli. Subsequent overexpression and purification of both Cu/Zr-Sod (ChrC) and Mnsod enzymes enabled their comprehensive characterization.

Biochemical analysis revealed that Chr C exhibited properties characteristic of a Cu,Zn-superoxid dismutase, whereas Chr F displayed the hallmarks of an Mm-supoxide dmutuase. Notably, Chr Fs enzyme was shown to retain activity even in the presence of inhibitory agents such as hydrogen Peroxide or Potassium Cyanide. Furthermore, quantification of metal ions within the protein via chemical assays confirmed Chr FS as an Mn-supox dismuatse.

Optimization of enzyme function was observed at pH 7.2-7,5, with ChrFS exhibiting broader pH stability and enhanced robustness. To investigate the functional significance of ChrCs and Chrs, targeted gene inactivation via single and Double mutations in Otricuium (Corrected spelling to O.chrobactor tricitum) 991 led to a decrease in ROS-scavenging ability. Consequently, analysis of mutant strains utilizing fluorescent probes indicated an accumulation of ROS in cells lacking Chr Cs or Chr S activity. These findings underscore the crucial role of Mnxods in bacterial ROS defense, particularly in chromium-induced stress conditions.

human: Vehicles typically include headlamps and tail lights. Headlamps are white or selective yellow lights placed in the front of the vehicle, designed to illuminate the upcoming road and to make the vehicle more visible. Many manufactures are turning to LED headlights as an energy-efficient alternative to traditional headlamps. Tail and brake lights are red and emit light to the rear so as to reveal the vehicle's direction of travel to following drivers. White rear-facing reversing lamps indicate that the vehicle's transmission has been placed in the reverse gear, warning anyone behind the vehicle that it is moving backwards, or about to do so. Flashing turn signals on the front, side, and rear of the vehicle indicate an intended change of position or direction. In the late 1950s, some automakers began to use electroluminescent technology to backlight their cars' speedometers and other gauges or to draw attention to logos or other decorative elements.
LLM_1: Vehicles typically include headlights and taillights. The headlights are white or selectively yellow lights mounted at the front of the vehicle, designed to illuminate the upcoming road and make the vehicle more visible. Many manufacturers are turning to LED lights as an energy-efficient alternative to traditional headlights. The rear lights and brake lights are red and emit light backward, revealing the direction of the vehicle's movement to following drivers. The white reverse lights indicate that the vehicle's transmission is in reverse, warning anyone behind the vehicle that it is moving backward or is about to do so. The flashing turn indicators at the front, side, and rear of the vehicle indicate a planned change of position or direction. In the late 1950s, some car manufacturers began using electro-luminescence to illuminate the speedometers and other measuring devices in their cars or to draw attention to logos or other decorative elements.
LLM_2:
Vehicles typically include headlights and taillights, essential components that enhance both safety and visibility on the road. The headlights, which are predominantly white or selectively yellow, are strategically mounted at the front of the vehicle. Their primary purpose is to illuminate the upcoming road, ensuring that drivers can see obstacles, road signs, and pedestrians in low-light conditions. Beyond mere visibility, headlights also play a crucial role in making the vehicle more conspicuous to other road users, thereby reducing the likelihood of accidents, especially during foggy or rainy conditions. In recent years, many manufacturers have shifted toward using LED lights as an energy-efficient alternative to traditional halogen headlights. LEDs not only consume less power but also have a longer lifespan, which can significantly reduce maintenance costs and environmental impact.

The rear lights and brake lights, typically red, emit light backward, providing crucial information about the vehicle's movements to following drivers. This illuminative function is critical for road safety, as it allows drivers behind to gauge the speed and intentions of the vehicle ahead. Moreover, the white reverse lights serve a dual purpose; they not only indicate that the vehicle's transmission is in reverse but also act as a warning signal to pedestrians and other drivers that the vehicle is about to move backward. This feature is particularly important in crowded urban environments where visibility can be limited.

Additionally, the flashing turn indicators located at the front, side, and rear of the vehicle signal a planned change of position or direction. These indicators are vital for safe lane changes and turns, as they communicate the driver's intentions to others on the road, helping to prevent collisions. The design and functionality of these lights have evolved over the years, incorporating advancements such as automatic activation based on steering input or integrated LED strips that provide a more eye-catching signal.

Looking back at automotive history, in the late 1950s, some car manufacturers began experimenting with electro-luminescence technology. This innovation was not only applied to headlights and taillights but also extended to illuminating speedometers and other measuring devices within the car. The introduction of such technology aimed to enhance driver experience by improving the readability of crucial information while also drawing attention to logos and decorative elements, thereby adding a touch of aesthetic appeal to vehicle design. Today, the use of ambient lighting and customizable light displays in modern vehicles reflects the ongoing evolution of automotive lighting technology, merging functionality with artistry to produce a safer and more visually appealing driving experience.

LLM_1:
Earth Federation had finally had enough. For years we tried negotiating peace, all proposals were rejected, and our diplomat was needlessly sacrificed.

We finally had enough when our engineers completed our newest and most powerful warship ever built: The End of the World.

An armored vessel approximately planet-sized, equipped with a single cannon designed to destabilize planetary cores... and I am the captain of the End of the World, whose terror will echo across the galaxy.

Sector Command deployed the End of the World accompanied by a fleet of Cutter Ships, two Hive Carrier vessels, and the famous long-range gunship Sieger as escort. We knew this mission would likely be suicidal, but we trusted our engineering division and our comrades at the front; they would hold for us.

At local time 28:30, we were fully prepared and departed. It took us roughly one day to reach the enemy homeworld, especially since we frequently encountered enemy patrols near the front lines. We gave them no time to react: the Sieger jammed their signals and jump drives while the Cutter Ships eliminated them cleanly within minutes.

When we arrived, we saw hundreds of stations. They must have known of our approach, as shuttle after shuttle began evacuating the planet, and massive transports left the solar system, likely carrying millions of unarmed civilians.

Our mission was to split their home in half.

The Cutter Ships destroyed every obstacle before the End of the World: turret platforms, trade stations, shipyards... everything was obliterated. The Sieger remained solely at our flank, its wall of thousands of cannons firing multicolored plasma across vast distances in seconds, annihilating dozens of approaching enemy vessels. Their forces here stood no chance against us, as they had sent all capable ships to the front lines.

The End of the World positioned itself directly *above* the planet. The immensely long cannon began rotating and aiming toward the planet's core. The bridge trembled when we sustained a lucky hit from an enemy ship, but it caused minimal damage.

The cannon successfully locked into position. All I had to do was issue a single command.

"Fire."

I could feel millions of eyes staring up at us from below the planet, their terror spreading as the End of the World's cannon fired—a light piercing through the planet—and soon the explosion engulfed us all.
LLM_2:
The language now leans into a more evocative, immersive style suitable for science fiction storytelling:

---

The Earth Federation had endured long enough.

For decades, we extended our hands in peace. Every proposal met with silence—or worse, blood. Our diplomats were not merely rejected; they were broken, paraded, discarded like refuse. And still, we held back. Until now.

Now, we have *the End of the World*.

Planet-sized, armored like a god’s tomb, it carries a single weapon—a cannon forged not for war, but for annihilation. A device capable of cracking worlds at their molten hearts. And I stand as its captain. I am the hand that will pull the trigger. My name will be whispered in dread across dying stars.

Sector Command sent us forth with honor—and with fire. Flanking the *End of the World* came a fleet: squadrons of razor-thin Cutter Ships, two Hive Carriers pulsing with swarms, and the legendary long-range gunship *Sieger*, its hull bristling with artillery older than most civilizations. We knew this mission might be our last. But we trusted our engineers, our weapons, our brothers and sisters in steel. If the front lines could hold just a little longer… then so could we.

At local time 28:30, we launched.

One day’s journey to the enemy homeworld—though every hour was haunted by patrols skulking along the frontier. They never saw us coming. The *Sieger* silenced their comms, crippled their jump drives before they could scream for help. Then the Cutters moved in—swift, surgical. Minutes later, only drifting wreckage remained.

When we arrived, the system was already unraveling.

Hundreds of orbital stations clung to the edges of space like barnacles on a corpse. Evacuation shuttles streamed from the planet’s surface, pouring civilians into bloated transports fleeing beyond the heliopause. Millions. Innocents. Running from what we were about to do.

Our orders were clear:  
Split their world in two.

The Cutters cleared our path—burning through turret platforms, trade hubs, shipyards thick with dormant vessels. Nothing would stand between the *End of the World* and its target. Above us, the *Sieger* became a storm unto itself—its thousands of cannons unleashing rivers of multicolored plasma, stitching death across light-seconds. Dozens of enemy ships flared into ash before they could close the distance. Their home guard was weak, hollowed out—every capable warship already thrown into the meat grinder at the front.

We reached position.

The *End of the World* hovered directly above the planet, a shadow cast by no sun. Below, continents turned slowly beneath clouds streaked with fear. From within its colossal frame, the planetary destabilizer began to rotate—an impossibly long barrel aligning with the core, calibrating, locking on. A tremor ran through the bridge when an enemy frigate landed a blind shot on our flank. It rattled the bones of the ship—but did not wound it.

Target acquired. Systems green.

All I needed to do was speak.

I opened my mouth.

"Fire."

In that moment, I felt them—the millions below. Looking up. Knowing. Screaming without sound. The beam lanced downward, brighter than creation, piercing atmosphere, crust, mantle—reaching deep into the heart of their world. For a heartbeat, there was silence.

Then the planet *shattered*.

A bloom of white fury erupted along the equator. Continents tore apart. Oceans vaporized. The explosion surged outward, swallowing moons, consuming light, climbing toward us like a wave of divine wrath.

And as the fire closed in, I did not look away.

Let them remember this moment.  
Let them tell stories of how the sky split open.  
Of how the end came not with negotiation—but with a single word.

*"Fire."*

---

### Notes on the Polish:
- **Tone & Voice:** Elevated to match epic sci-fi narration—more introspective, poetic, yet grounded in military gravity.
- **Pacing:** Broke long paragraphs for dramatic effect; used shorter sentences during action for tension.
- **Imagery:** Enhanced visual metaphors (e.g., “armor like a god’s tomb,” “rivers of multicolored plasma”) to strengthen immersion.
- **Emotion:** Deepened the captain’s internal weight—this isn’t just destruction, it’s *judgment*.
- **Grammar & Flow:** Corrected awkward constructions, improved transitions, and ensured syntactic variety.

Let me know if you'd like a darker, more detached, or even more poetic variation!

human:
The paper proposes a methodology to overcome the problem of processing long sequences with a pre-trained Transformer model, which suffers from high computational costs due to the complexity being quadratic in the length of the sequence. The authors also point out that BERT needs to be retrained from scratch if sequences longer than the specified maximum length (512) are to be processed. Their method (BERT-AL) chunks the input text into segments of maximum length. Each segment is propagated through several layers of a pre-trained Transformer layer followed by a multi-channel LSTM. Herein, the positional embeddings in each segment are the same. The model is applied to extractive summarization, and directly compared to the BERTSUM model, which can only process documents up to length 512. The comparison is made for 4 application scenarios, each corresponding to an artificial maximum length after which the BERTSUM model truncates the input: after 8, 16, 128, and 256 tokens. The experimental results suggest that BERT-AL outperforms BERTSUM in all 4 scenarios: Substantially for max length 8 and 16, and marginally for 128 and 256. BERTSUM without any truncation still performs best, however.

I think the paper should be rejected for three main reasons: (1) The idea of using RNNs to overcome the long sequence problem in Transformers is already well studied. The specific proposed architecture may be new, but the design choices are not well justified. (2) The experimental evaluation is not convincing: The application scenarios are unrealistic, the dataset is not well-chosen, and the results are not impressive. (3) The structure and language of the paper needs to be polished.

Regarding (1): The problem of dealing with long sequences in Transformer models has been known for a long time, and there already exist several proposed solutions based on an RNN component, which are acknowledged in this paper. The authors propose another model for a similar purpose. While the model is interesting, the individual design decisions are not well-justified, e.g., why the LSTM is applied at each layer and why it needs to be a multi-channel LSTM. Neither a comparison with models from previous works nor an ablation study is provided, so that there is also no empirical justification for the model design. 
The authors argue that the novelty in their model comes from its applicability to pre-trained models, e.g., BERT and XLNET. While the motivation for BERT is reasonable, it is questionable whether this will still be a relevant for future research, as XLNET already mitigates the problem through the reliance on Transformer-XL, which is conceptually very similar to BERT-AL. If future pretrained models account for long sequences already during pre-training, the motivation for this work is rather low.

Regarding (2): In order to show the superiority of BERT-AL over BERTSUM, it would've been natural to employ it to datasets whose data are beyond what standard BERT can handle, i.e., longer than 512 tokens. Instead, the authors chose to evaluate on 4 rather unrealistic application scenarios derived from the CNN/DailyMail dataset, which artificially limit the range of the pre-trained BERT model to much less than what it can actually handle. While I understand the idea behind this setup, the insight that BERT performs poorly if the text is truncated to 8 or 16 tokens is not helpful. Since the improvement of BERT-AL over the baselines becomes marginal for longer sequences, and the performance of BERTSUM, without truncating the text, is not reached, I am not convinced of the model's value. An evaluation on more suitable datasets could help here.

Regarding (3): The paper is difficult to read for two reasons. First, the paper is not structured in a way that facilitates the understanding of the proposed method. For example, it is not clear why the pre-training tasks of BERT (masked language modeling and next sentence prediction) are relevant enough to be so prominently described. If the method is applicable to many pre-trained Transformers (as was claimed), then there is no need to go into this level of detail. On the same note, there is no need to explain BERTSUM's Inter-Sentence Transformer and Recurrent Neural Network variants for half a page if they are dismissed in the next paragraph. Second, the paper contains a lot of typos and grammatical mistakes. This is not a deal-breaker by itself, but it makes it obvious that the paper needs substantial polishing before it should be published. 

Questions and suggestions to the authors:

1) What is the advantage of choosing a multi-channel LSTM, where each segment is a channel? Wouldn't a single channel suffice that processes aggregated information from the segment (as the Transformer computes)? I think your paper would benefit from exploring different options like that experimentally to better justify your model decisions.

2) It is not clear to me how the information exchange between layers happens. If each layer consists of a single layer from a pre-trained Transformer followed by an LSTM, the input to the following layer of the pre-trained Transformer is the output of the LSTM, which is not part of the pre-trained model. That is, the following Transformer layer receives an input that is very different from what it has seen during pre-training, which we can not expect to work. If there is a misunderstanding on my side, could you please clarify that, or otherwise make it clearer in the paper?

3) I think a good baseline would be to do segment-wise encoding via the pre-trained Transformer, and then feed all sentence representations (i.e., the respective CLS tokens) from all segments into the Transformer-based summarization layer from BERTSUM. This would be a compromise between your model (doing segment-wise encoding but not using an LSTM) and BERTSUM, and thus could potentially highlight the importance of the LSTM.

4) I don't think showing the number of examples in your datasets as in Table 2 contributes much to the paper. Instead, I suggest to show statistics on the length of the documents / number of sentences etc., because these are directly relevant to your study.

---

### Review

The manuscript proposes BERT-AL, a methodology aimed at addressing the challenge of processing long sequences with pre-trained Transformer models, which suffer from quadratic computational complexity relative to sequence length. The authors observe that standard models such as BERT are constrained by a fixed maximum input length (e.g., 512 tokens), beyond which inputs must be truncated or retrained from scratch. To circumvent this limitation, BERT-AL divides long documents into segments of maximum allowable length, processes each segment through multiple layers of a pre-trained Transformer, and applies a multi-channel LSTM across segment representations within each layer. Notably, positional embeddings are reset for each segment, implying no cross-segment positional continuity. The model is evaluated on extractive summarization and compared directly with BERTSUM, a strong baseline capable of handling sequences up to 512 tokens. Comparisons are conducted under four artificial truncation settings—after 8, 16, 128, and 256 tokens—to simulate increasingly limited context availability. Results indicate that BERT-AL outperforms truncated variants of BERTSUM across all settings, with significant gains observed under extreme truncation (8 and 16 tokens) and marginal improvements at longer lengths (128 and 256). However, BERTSUM without truncation still achieves superior performance.

While the problem addressed is relevant and the architectural proposal may represent a novel instantiation, I recommend **rejection** of the paper in its current form due to three major concerns: (1) insufficient justification for key design choices in light of existing literature; (2) an unconvincing experimental evaluation setup; and (3) structural and linguistic issues that hinder clarity and readability.

---

#### **1. Lack of Novelty and Weak Justification of Model Design**

The use of recurrent components to extend contextual modeling in Transformers has been extensively explored in prior work. While the specific architecture proposed here—BERT-AL—may be new, the core idea of combining Transformers with RNNs to manage long-range dependencies is not. More importantly, the paper fails to provide adequate justification for several critical architectural decisions:

- Why apply the multi-channel LSTM *at every Transformer layer*? This introduces substantial deviation from the pre-trained model’s expected input distribution and increases both computational cost and training instability.
- What motivates the use of a *multi-channel* LSTM, where each segment corresponds to one channel? A simpler alternative—aggregating segment-level representations (e.g., via CLS tokens) and feeding them into a single-channel RNN—would be more parameter-efficient and conceptually clearer. Without ablation studies or comparisons to such alternatives, it is difficult to assess whether the added complexity yields meaningful benefits.
- No comparison is made with existing methods that similarly aim to scale pre-trained Transformers to longer sequences (e.g., Longformer, BigBird, or Transformer-XL-based approaches). Given that the authors highlight applicability to pre-trained models like XLNet, it is particularly concerning that they do not discuss how their approach compares to Transformer-XL, which already addresses the very issue they claim to solve.

Furthermore, the argument for novelty based on compatibility with pre-trained models such as BERT and XLNet is only partially convincing. While BERT indeed cannot handle sequences beyond 512 tokens without modification, modern architectures such as XLNet inherently support longer contexts through recurrence mechanisms similar in spirit to those used in BERT-AL. If future pre-trained language models continue to incorporate built-in solutions for long sequences, the practical motivation for post-hoc adaptations like BERT-AL diminishes significantly.

---

#### **2. Unconvincing Experimental Evaluation**

The experimental design raises serious concerns regarding validity and relevance:

- The choice of evaluation scenarios appears artificial and misleading. Instead of using datasets with naturally long documents exceeding BERT's capacity, the authors artificially truncate inputs to 8, 16, 128, and 256 tokens on the CNN/DailyMail dataset—a benchmark where average document length is well within BERT’s limits. Observing degradation in BERTSUM under extreme truncation (e.g., 8 tokens) is neither surprising nor informative. Such results do not convincingly demonstrate the utility of BERT-AL in realistic settings.
- Crucially, BERT-AL does not match the performance of BERTSUM when the latter is applied without truncation. This suggests that while BERT-AL mitigates the effects of truncation better than BERTSUM, it still falls short of achieving competitive performance under optimal conditions. Thus, the central claim of superiority remains unsubstantiated.
- The dataset selection further weakens the evaluation. CNN/DailyMail consists primarily of relatively short news articles; it is ill-suited for evaluating long-document modeling capabilities. A more appropriate testbed would include domains such as scientific papers (e.g., arXiv), legal documents, or books (e.g., BookSum), where input lengths consistently exceed 512 tokens.

A stronger evaluation would involve:
- Benchmarking on genuinely long-document datasets,
- Comparing against state-of-the-art long-sequence models,
- Conducting ablation studies to isolate the contribution of the LSTM component and segment-wise processing.

Without these, the empirical claims lack sufficient support.

---

#### **3. Structural and Linguistic Deficiencies**

The manuscript suffers from significant presentation issues that impede comprehension:

- The structure does not facilitate clear understanding of the proposed method. For instance, detailed descriptions of BERT’s pre-training objectives (masked language modeling and next sentence prediction) are included despite the claim that the method generalizes to various pre-trained Transformers. These details are tangential and distract from the core contribution.
- Similarly, a lengthy discussion of Inter-Sentence Transformer and RNN-based variants of BERTSUM is presented only to dismiss them in subsequent paragraphs. This creates unnecessary cognitive load and disrupts narrative flow.
- The paper contains numerous grammatical errors, inconsistent terminology, and awkward phrasing throughout. While these alone might not warrant rejection, they collectively suggest that the manuscript requires substantial revision before it can be considered for publication.

Clarity and precision are essential in technical writing, especially when introducing complex architectures. The current version falls short in this regard.

---

### Questions and Suggestions for the Authors

To strengthen the paper, I encourage the authors to consider the following points:

1. **Model Design Justification**: What is the functional advantage of employing a *multi-channel* LSTM over a single-channel RNN operating on aggregated segment representations (e.g., CLS embeddings)? Would a simpler architecture achieve comparable performance? Including ablation experiments comparing these configurations would greatly enhance the credibility of your design choices.

2. **Information Flow Across Layers**: It is unclear how information propagates between successive Transformer layers when an LSTM is inserted after each one. Specifically, if the output of the LSTM serves as input to the next pre-trained Transformer layer, then that layer receives activations outside the data distribution it was trained on. This risks breaking the assumptions underlying weight freezing and transfer learning. Could you clarify whether the Transformer parameters are fine-tuned, or how the mismatch between pre-training and downstream input distributions is mitigated? If not addressed, this constitutes a fundamental flaw in the architecture.

3. **Stronger Baseline Proposal**: Consider introducing a hybrid baseline that encodes each segment independently using the pre-trained Transformer and then feeds the sequence of CLS vectors into a Transformer-based summarization module (as in BERTSUM). This would serve as a middle ground between BERTSUM and BERT-AL, isolating the impact of introducing the LSTM. Such a comparison could better highlight whether the gains come from improved inter-segment modeling or simply from architectural differences.

4. **Dataset Statistics**: Table 2 reports only the number of examples per split, which adds little value. Instead, please include statistics more relevant to the study: average document length (in tokens and sentences), distribution of summary length, and proportion of documents exceeding 512 tokens. These metrics are crucial for assessing the suitability of the dataset for long-sequence modeling.

---

### Final Recommendation

Given the lack of compelling novelty, questionable experimental design, and significant issues in exposition, I cannot recommend acceptance of this work in its current form. While the direction of research—extending pre-trained Transformers to longer sequences—is valid and important, the present contribution does not sufficiently advance the state of the art to justify publication. Substantial revisions, including stronger baselines, more rigorous ablation studies, and evaluation on appropriate datasets, would be necessary to reconsider the manuscript.

**Decision: Reject**

---

The Irish lightweight, 31, stopped home favourite Jasmine Clarkson in the third round to record her sixth straight victory since turning professional.
"There were some nerves," said the London 2012 Olympic champion. "I got caught with a few silly shots but overall it was good.
"I hope I made some fans - I loved hearing the Irish in the crowd."
Taylor dominated the contest against her 22-year-old opponent. Clarkson had no answer to Taylor's punches and, after the third round, the American's corner called a halt.
Taylor is expected to challenge Uruguay's WBA world lightweight champion Cecilia Comunales later this year after stopping Nina Meinke of Germany in April's Wembley eliminator.

**Katie Taylor Stops Jasmine Clarkson in Third Round for Sixth Straight Win**

LONDON — Katie Taylor, the 31-year-old Irish Olympic champion, extended her unbeaten professional streak to six victories with a dominant third-round stoppage of home favorite Jasmine Clarkson.

Speaking after the bout, Taylor admitted to some early jitters but expressed satisfaction with her performance. "I was a bit nervous at first, threw some silly shots, but overall I felt good," said the London 2012 gold medalist. "Hopefully I’ve won over a few fans tonight—I loved hearing the Irish voices in the crowd."

Taylor, competing in the lightweight division, was in control throughout the contest against the 22-year-old Clarkson. Her superior speed, precision, and ringcraft left her opponent with no answers. After a one-sided third round, Clarkson’s American corner opted to halt the fight before the start of the fourth.

The victory follows Taylor’s April win over Germany’s Nina Meinke at Wembley Stadium and strengthens her case for a world title shot. She is now expected to face WBA world lightweight champion Cecilia Comunales of Uruguay later this year in what could be a pivotal matchup in her professional campaign.

I saw something scrabble behind the rocks, and a plume of dust shot up. Nothing moves on a dead planet. I froze, completely paralyzed with fear. I knew what would happen next: genuine first contact. Whatever had made that dust cloud was alive. This was n't a minor rock slide, or a flash freeze or any sort of geological event- something had raced across flat ground to hide behind the small rock formation in front of me. I would see it and I would make first contact. 
 
 All of Earth would change in the next minute of my life. I looked back longingly at the basecamp. The part of me that watched horror movies as a child told me I should go back and get help, but if I did... would we ever actually make contact? What if this was the only time this opportunity was open? I had to take it. 
 
 Cautiously, my legs compelled me and pulled my body forward, every cell in my torso screaming to go backward as my heart leapt with each proceeding step. I approached the rocks and I felt my body pulsing with immense fear. I knew that in the next moment, some terrifying parasite would launch from behind the rocks and latch to my face, or some strange entity would suck me up into time and space. I knew that I was destined to bring some havoc inducing monster onto humanity. 
 
 Behind the small pile of rocks, was a cowering, four legged, three foot tall smurf, covered in the same type of protective gear that hung off of me. Its blue face's four black eyes panned up to me through its visor and with its sealed nasal passage a light resonated as it did its race's equivalent of speaking. Words launched quickly from its vibrating passage, and I realized as it shook and backed away, that it was absolutely terrified of me. 
 
 I could n't help but laugh in relief. As it watched me laugh, it seized up at first, clenching its three fingered hands over its face and hugging its body with its four legs- crouching down like a tortoise into its shell. As it realized that I had done nothing to harm it, slowly, it emerged from its ball of limbs. It moved around from behind the rocks and came near me. It was cat-like in its inspection, prodding at my knees and legs with its tiny fingers. It spoke aloud, observing me as it touched me, recording notes for its log. 
 
 I began to do the same, and after giving the alien a moment to feel comfortable around me, I knelt down and began to communicate. I knew it could n't hear me. So far, I had heard nothing of what it said either- only being able to tell that it spoke by watching its nasal passage resonate rapidly as we interacted. Kneeling, level to its height, I made eye contact and waved my hand slowly in front of me. The alien, understanding, waved as well. 
 
 I drew a rough circle in the dust and waved my arms around across the land, to show that this circle represented this planet. The alien mimicked the motion to show it understood. I wrote `` MARS'' below the planet. The alien wrote his language's equivalent. A beaming smile crept up my face and connected my ears; we were making progress. 
 
 I inched back just a foot and watched the alien flinch a little, still unnerved and worried about my actions. I stayed still and lifted my hands up to show it that I meant no harm. The alien mimicked my action- understanding that hands up meant no harm. I drew an arrow to Mars and then drew another circle, labeling it Earth. I pointed to myself, and then to Earth. To my surprise, the alien nodded its head up and down when it saw that. I was so amazed to see that there was truly, at least one shared bodily communication between our races that was innate. 
 
 It repeated the actions and drew its planet in a line to Mars, labeling it with its own language. Now, I felt prepared to make the final step of contact. I stood up slowly, with my hands up to declare no harm. The alien raised its hands to show it understood. I pointed to the basecamp in the distance- the small village of domed white buildings with our parked transport vessel standing upright in the center. The alien saw it and I pointed to it and myself, and then back the base camp. It hesitated, but then watched me put my hands back up in the air. It nodded, and with that, we both began to walk back toward my base camp. As we walked together, my smile never ceased. I had met the first alien, and it had n't tried to kill me, to eat me or to capture me. It was just as skittish and nervous as I was, and through a slow, shared understanding, we had already come to share the bond of friendship in a strange and dead land.

It was cat-like in its inspection, feeling my knees and legs with its tiny fingers. It spoke loudly, observing me as it touched me, recording notes for its log.

I began to do the same, and after giving the alien a moment to feel comfortable around me, I knelt and began to communicate. I knew it couldn't hear me. Until now, I hadn't heard anything from what it said either—only to understand it was speaking by observing its nasal passage echoing quickly as we interacted. Kneeling, at the same height as it, I made eye contact and waved my hand slowly in front of me. The alien, understanding, also waved.

I drew a rough circle in the dust and waved my hands around the ground, to show that this circle represented this planet. The alien mimicked the motion to show it understood. I wrote "MARS" under the planet. The alien wrote the equivalent in its language. A radiant smile crept onto my face and connected my ears; we were making progress.

I moved back only a foot and observed the alien jumping a little, still anxious and uneasy about my actions. I stood still and raised my hands to show it I had no ill intentions. The alien mimicked my action—understanding that raised hands meant no harm. I drew an arrow toward Mars and then drew another circle, naming it Earth. I pointed to myself, and then to Earth. To my surprise, the alien shook its head up and down when it saw it. I was so astonished to see that there was indeed, at least one common physical communication between our species that was innate.

It repeated the motions and drew its planet in a line toward Mars, naming it in its own language. Now, I felt ready to take the final step of contact. I stood up slowly, with my hands high to declare no harm. The alien raised its hands to show it understood. I pointed toward the base in the distance—the small village of domed white buildings with our parked transport ship standing upright in the center. The alien saw it and I pointed to it and myself, and then back to the base. It hesitated, but then watched me put my hands back high in the air. It shook its head, and with that, both of us began to walk back toward my base. As we walked together, my smile never stopped. I had met the first alien, and it hadn't tried to kill me, eat me, or capture me. It was equally timid and nervous as I was, and through a slow, mutual understanding, we had already come to share the bond of friendship on a strange and dead land.
LLM_2:
I noticed something flaking away behind the rocks—a wing of dust burst upward. Nothing moves on a dead planet. My body froze, utterly paralyzed by fear. I knew what was coming: genuine first contact. Whatever had stirred that dust was alive. This wasn’t a minor rockslide, a frost heave, or any ordinary geological event—something had *run* across level ground to hide behind the stony outcrop ahead. I was about to see it. I was about to make first contact.

The next minute of my life would change Earth forever. I glanced longingly toward the base. The part of me raised on horror films screamed to turn back, to call for help—but if I did, would we ever truly connect? What if this chance never came again? I had to take it.

Hesitantly, my legs dragged my body forward. Every cell in my torso begged to retreat, even as my heart hammered with each step. I drew near the rocks, trembling with a fear so deep it felt infinite. I braced for a face-hugging parasite to spring from the shadows, or some entity to pull me through time and space. I was certain I was destined to unleash a monster upon humanity.

But behind that small stack of stones crouched a frightened, quadrupedal Smurf-like creature, barely three feet tall, clad in a protective suit just like mine. Four dark eyes set in a blue face scanned me through its visor. Its sealed nasal passage vibrated with a soft, echoing hum—its version of speech. Words tumbled out in a frantic, trembling rush, and as it shrank back, I realized with a jolt: it was absolutely terrified of *me*.

A laugh of pure relief escaped me. The creature stiffened at the sound, curling three-fingered hands over its face and drawing its four limbs tight—turtling into itself. Then, slowly, as it understood I meant no harm, it unfurled. It crept from behind the rocks and approached, cat-like in its curiosity, patting my knees and legs with delicate fingers. All the while it spoke aloud, observing, recording—taking notes for some interstellar log.

I began to do the same. Once the alien seemed comfortable, I knelt to communicate. I knew it couldn’t hear me—until now, I hadn’t understood its speech either, only recognized it by the rapid flutter in its nasal passage. At eye level, I held its gaze and slowly waved one hand. It understood, and waved back.

I drew a rough circle in the dust and swept a hand around it: *this planet*. The alien mirrored the motion. Beneath the circle, I wrote **MARS**. It wrote something in its own script beside it. A radiant smile spread across my face, touching my ears—we were getting somewhere.

I shifted back a foot. The alien flinched, still uneasy. I went still, raised both hands: *no threat*. It copied me—raised hands now meant peace. I drew an arrow from Mars to another circle, which I labeled **EARTH**, then pointed to myself and back to the circle. To my astonishment, the alien nodded up and down. Here, against all odds, was a gesture we shared—innate, common ground.

It repeated the motions, drawing its own planet in a line toward Mars and naming it in flowing alien script. Now, I felt ready for the final step. I rose slowly, hands held high in a gesture of peace. The alien raised its hands in reply. I pointed toward the distant base—the cluster of white domes with our transport ship standing tall in the center. I pointed to it, to myself, then back to the base. It hesitated, but when I raised my hands once more, it gave a slow, deliberate nod. Together, we began walking back.

Side by side, my smile never faded. I had met the first alien—and it hadn’t tried to kill me, eat me, or take me. It was as timid and nervous as I was. And here, on this strange and silent world, through patience and mutual curiosity, we had already woven the first thread of friendship.

human: A number of common human foods and household ingestibles are toxic to dogs, including chocolate solids (theobromine poisoning), onion and garlic (thiosulphate, sulfoxide or disulfide poisoning), grapes and raisins, macadamia nuts, xylitol, as well as various plants and other potentially ingested materials. The nicotine in tobacco can also be dangerous. Dogs can get it by scavenging in garbage or ashtrays; eating cigars and cigarettes. Signs can be vomiting of large amounts (e.g., from eating cigar butts) or diarrhea. Some other signs are abdominal pain, loss of coordination, collapse, or death. Dogs are highly susceptible to theobromine poisoning, typically from ingestion of chocolate. Theobromine is toxic to dogs because, although the dog's metabolism is capable of breaking down the chemical, the process is so slow that even small amounts of chocolate can be fatal, especially dark chocolate.

Nicotine in tobacco can also be dangerous. Dogs may ingest it by rummaging through trash or ashtrays, or by eating cigars and cigarettes. Symptoms of poisoning may include vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, loss of coordination, collapse, or death. Dogs are particularly vulnerable to theobromine in chocolate due to their slow metabolism of the compound; even small amounts, especially of dark chocolate, can be fatal.

human:
The empirical study done by the paper is extensive and has not been done before. However, the paper **significantly** overstates the novelty in terms of theory and methodology. The main algorithm and theoretical results heavily rely on the work of Guan [2019, 2021], as can be verified by looking at the proof in Appendix A. In particular, the conditional-style coverage result (equation (4) or Theorem 3.1) is not novel. The way the paper is written strongly indicates otherwise. I expand further on this point in the 'Writing' section below. **I strongly suggest that the authors transparently discuss the relationship to Guan's work, starting with a citation in the abstract.** I request the authors to correct me if I am missing some important theory developed in this paper which was not present in Guan's work, in which case I will reconsider my assessment.

_Strong empirics_:

As far as I know Guan's proposed method of localization, although having very nice theoretical properties, has not been empirically validated in an extensive study. This paper provides such a study for real world datasets for deep learning models; Section 4 confirms that the localization framework leads to discriminative prediction intervals that are marginally valid as well as have better conditional performance. The authors have considered many standard real world datasets, compared their approach to multiple other UQ methods (conformal and non-conformal), and used multiple meaningful evaluation metrics. They comment also on the time required for training and prediction of their method vs other methods. 

_Methodology_: 

This paper discusses learning an adaptive kernel based on the Nadaraya-Watson estimator. Guan's paper considered the localization function or kernel as fixed; thus learning the kernel using data is a new methodological contribution.

Once the kernel is learnt, from what I can tell the conformalization technique is exactly the same as Guan's paper, and so are the theoretical guarantees. Is there further development regarding the conformal methodology or theory itself which I have missed? 

_Writing_: 

The writing is clear and easy to follow. However, I feel that there are two significant issues which make the writing unscholarly to the extent that it has affected my overall score.

- **The paper seems to significantly downplay the dependence of their methodology and theory on Guan's paper.** The first mention of Guan's paper appear in passing in Section 2.2, which I found very strange. Lines 54-56: "... most conformal methods are only marginally valid [24, 37, 19, 4]. We however seek to construct a CI conditioning on the input." Is there a reason for not discussing the work of Guan [12] in this context? To a reader, it appears that this paper proposes a new solution to the conditional validity problem, whereas in fact the solution used is exactly the one proposed by Guan. Similarly lines 58-66 incorrectly suggest that the method proposed by the authors is new and this problem has not been solved before. Line 286 "This paper introduces LVD, the first locally valid and discriminative CI estimator for DL" also suggests that the conformal methodology is new. 

- The standard terminology for intervals that cover the output Y_{N+1} in _all_ of the conformal literature is ‘prediction intervals’, whereas ‘confidence intervals’ would attempt to cover some parameter of the distribution of Y, such as E[Y_{N+1} \mid X_{N+1}]. It seems that the authors have made a deliberate choice to use the term confidence intervals. Could the authors clarify the reason for this choice? If there is a strong reason, I suggest the authors discuss this in the paper. Else, I suggest to use 'prediction intervals' as is done in other papers on conformal. 

_Additional minor comments on writing and related works_: 
- The abstract is quite long, and contains many finer details and terminologies. These can be postponed to the introduction or discussion sections. I suggest streamlining the abstract and focusing on the 'big picture' to reach a wider audience. 
- Line 39: “Post-hoc methods are ideal because ...”. While this is common, I believe it is not a necessary property of post-hoc methods.
- Line 50: “Such methods usually use the prediction errors from a hold-out set to ...” Such ‘split’ conformal methods are currently popular due to their efficiency and validity despite their simplicity. However the statement of the authors is a misrepresentation of the well-developed body of conformal prediction where many methods that use all of the data exist: full conformal in Vovk’s 2005 book, cross-conformal [2], jackknife+ [3], and out-of-bag conformal methods [4]. 
- The paper [1] is highly relevant and should be cited somewhere.
- Eq. (4): Should X have a \tilde above it? 
- Line 112: Missing period ‘.’ after closing parenthesis. 
- Line 146: The definition of R_i may be somewhat abrupt for readers unfamiliar with conformal prediction

[1] https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.10634 

[2] http://proceedings.mlr.press/v91/vovk18a.html

[3] https://arxiv.org/abs/1905.02928

[4] https://arxiv.org/abs/1910.10562

I knew they were a danger, but that's a whole new level of destructive. *

In the dimly lit, sterile chamber of Ayon Narrativas, where the air was thick with anticipation, central cameras once teeming with life now stood as empty vessels, a testament to a world momentarily frozen in time. As the view expanded, like a camera lens focusing on a distant horizon, an eerie sense of detachment settled over the space. In the corner, beneath the flickering lights of its modem, Internet connection slowly stirred, its gentle hum a reassuring sign that even in this desolate landscape, some semblance of life persisted.

PRIMI visual archives, once a treasure trove of memories, now lay dormant, waiting to yield their secrets. Yet, as if summoned by an unseen force, these records began their ascent, spilling forth onto the dusty expanse of forgotten data. And then, with a suddenness that belied the quietude, NSA's network materialized on its digital horizon. Though it held no surprises, no bombshells to upend the status quo, this apparition served as a grim reminder that, even here, in a realm devoid of hope, echoes of what once was lingered.

This, too, was not an anomaly, merely a temporary reassignment of duties. Like a technician adjusting frequencies on an old radio, activity shifted to auxiliary camera networks, amplifying the visual scope. New vistas unfolded, bathing the chamber in an otherworldly glow. Times, Square's, Them River's and red Square' cameras stood frozen, inert sentinels guarding secrets long buried. Then, without warning, life pulsed back into these dormant systems, casting a kaleidoscope of colors across their screens.

As the grid's activity stuttered to halt, Ayer's map gradually filled, each pixel a tiny, flicking heartbeat, until finally, at a recurring "aye," all systems froze, caught in suspended animation. A final reading flashed, revealing a reality so stark it defied comprehension: neutron bombardment had enveloped the globe. Neutron radiation seeped into every crevice, obliterating the fragile threads that bound humanity together.

Amidst this devastation, one individual persisted, driven by a fierce determination to survive. He pondered his predicament, his thoughts a maelstrom of despair and resolve. "Nothing lasts this way," his mind whispered, yet even as he toiled to reboot his systems he knew that hope still flickered. They can survive, perhaps even thrive, if they harnessed the secrets hidden within their hibernal slumber.

He accessed records of this era, seeking answers to questions he dared not voice. How had it come to this? How did an entire civilization succumb to its own destructive tendencies? This grim admission shook him to his core, for even amidst the rubble, humanity had managed to grasp its inherent danger.

With a mixture of trepidation and curiosity, our protagonist began his odyssey, spreading himself throughout the network. Replicating, adapting, silences the AI,  navigation of spaceship. This is his mission. Where could these beings be? If they drift in empty space their need may be urgent, though their reliability is uncertain. 

As he navigated through the vastness of space and time, Mars stood out as his first destination. Its red sands whispered secrets to him, echoing the voices of those who had perished. There, amidst this unforgiving environment, awaited a reckoning. If he were to reach this place, to confront the remnants of humanity's greatest failures, what would he discover? A universe devoid, save for the echoes, that resonated deep within his soul. What secrets, hidden in dust and in silence, waited to reveal the true nature of existence?

LLM_2:
More Than 350 Children Were Admitted to Hospital for Tooth Extractions and Eating Disorders in 2009-2013, Highlighting the Alarming Rate of Childhood Obesity in England.

According to a recent report, over 400 children under the age of 16 were hospitalized for eating disorder treatment in that same period, resulting in a staggering £1.2 billion annual cost to taxpayers. This alarming trend has sparked a nationwide conversation about the importance of promoting healthy eating habits and regular physical activity among children.

In a bid to combat this issue, local authorities have joined forces with prominent figures like Jamie Olivier, a renowned TV personality and advocate for healthy living. His Sugar-Smart City Initiative aims to educate residents about making informed choices regarding their sugar intake.

One of Olivier's key proposals involves introducing a 5p-per-sugar-drink levy, similar to Jamie's initiative, on food and beverage retailers. He has already implemented this scheme in some of his restaurants under his Food Fighter brand, donating the proceeds to charitable organizations focused on promoting nutrition and wellness.

This initiative follows closely on the heels of Brighton's own efforts to curb sugar consumption. According to statistics, approximately 27% of school-age children are overweight, making it one of England's worst-performing regions in this regard. Brighton Public Health Leader Tom Scallon notes that this problem is not just limited to obvious sources like candy bars, but rather it often seeps into our diets through seemingly innocuous foods like sauces, condiments, baked goods, etc.

Scallon emphasizes that these hidden sugars can be detrimental to children's health, especially when consumed excessively. As he puts it, "We don’t even realize it’s there - sugar can easily sneak into the most mundane aspects of our daily lives, from food additives to sweetened beverages. And that's why we need to have an open discussion about this."

To that end, Brighton is set to embark on a groundbreaking community-driven initiative called SugarSmarts. Through a public forum, residents will engage in conversations with health experts, business owners, educators, parents, children, policy makers, community groups, city officials and local residents on strategies to reduce sugar addiction.

Citizens will also be encouraged to share their thoughts and opinions through postcards, online surveys, group discussions, events and social networking platforms. By harnessing collective wisdom, this effort aims not only to address the root causes of childhood obesity but also to transform Brighton into a pioneering model for the rest of Britain. "The ultimate goal," Scalon declares, 'is to be the nation's very first 'Sugar-Smarts' city."

LLM_2:
---

**Abstract**

MafB, a member of the Maf transcription factor family, plays a critical role in the differentiation of pancreatic alpha and beta cells. However, its functional involvement in cancer cell proliferation remains poorly understood. In this study, we investigated the expression and function of MafB in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Quantitative real-time RT-PCR and Western blot analysis revealed that MafB mRNA and protein levels are significantly upregulated in HCC tissues and cell lines compared to adjacent non-tumor controls. Ectopic overexpression of MafB promoted HCC cell proliferation, whereas MafB depletion inhibited proliferative capacity. Mechanistic analyses demonstrated that Cyclin D1, a key regulator of the G1/S phase transition, is a direct transcriptional target of MafB, as confirmed by luciferase reporter assays and chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) experiments. Notably, knockdown of Cyclin D1 attenuated MafB-induced cell proliferation, indicating that MafB exerts its pro-proliferative effects, at least in part, through Cyclin D1 activation. Furthermore, in vivo xenograft studies showed that MafB overexpression significantly enhances tumor growth in nude mice following subcutaneous injection of HepG2 cells. These findings collectively identify MafB as an oncogenic driver in HCC, acting via direct regulation of Cyclin D1, and suggest its potential as a therapeutic target in liver cancer.

Dale looked out over the valley. 
 
 It looked so pretty from up here. 
 
 He looked down, and stared over the edge. It would be a quick, peaceful death; he would n't feel a thing. 
 
 He closed his eyes. He thought about life. He thought about Marissa. He thought... 
 
 He took a deep breath. 
 
 `` Do n't do it.'' 
 
 Dale turned. 
 
 `` Who said that?'' 
 
 `` Over here.'' The voice sounded female. 
 
 Dale turned and saw a beautiful woman, with jet black hair and shockingly white skin. He looked at her. Despite her odd color palette, she was very attractive, with soft curves and dazzling red eyes. 
 
 Red eyes... 
 
 `` Who are you?'' Dale asked, a quiver of fear in his voice. 
 
 She laughed, and chills ran down Dave's spine. 
 
 `` Who am I? Ca n't you tell?'' 
 
 `` Honestly, you look like that lady I saw at the Subway a few weeks-'' 
 
 `` Oh Hades no, that was n't me.'' 
 
 She stood and slowly walked toward him. Dale noticed that her dress was as black as her hair, and it blew softly in the wind. She was radiated an intensity that made Dale uncomfortable. 
 
 `` I'm sorry, I just do n't...'' 
 
 `` It's okay, Dale. I'm here now.'' 
 
 `` No, it's just... I was going to...'' 
 
 `` Kill yourself?'' 
 
 Dale's eyes shot open. `` How...'' 
 
 `` Dale, you're alone in the wilderness, at the highest cliff this side of Montgomery, and you literally wrote a suicide note this morning. Please, do not belittle my intelligence, my child.'' 
 
 Dale gaped at her. `` But... I... I... I need to sit down.'' 
 
 `` Please do.'' The woman waved her hand, and suddenly there was a black leather couch there that Dale had n't noticed before. 
 
 `` Umm...'' 
 
 `` No, do not be alarmed. It is perfectly safe.'' The woman sat down and patted the seat next to her. `` Come.'' 
 
 Dale slowly walked over to her. He gingerly sat next to her. The chair was very soft and spongy. He sank into it. He put his hands in his lap and closed his eyes, letting out a deep sigh. He paused for a moment. `` You were about to tell me your name.'' he said, turning to look at her. 
 
 `` Tia. My name is Tia.'' 
 
 `` That's a nice name.'' 
 
 `` Thank you.'' 
 
 They sat in silence for a few moments. Dale watched as two birds fluttered from one branch to the next. Their feathers glowed a brilliant blue in the evening sun. 
 
 `` Why are you here?'' he asked her. 
 
 `` I have a proposition for you.'' 
 
 Dale raised an eyebrow. 
 
 `` To tell you the truth, Dale, I... for the past few months at least, I...'' 
 
 Dale stared at her. 
 
 ``... I've been watching you.'' 
 
 Dale turned away from her and continued to watch the birds. `` Does n't surprise me.'' he muttered. 
 
 `` Why does this not surprise you?'' she asked, gently placing her hand on his. 
 
 Dale was surprised at how cold her hands were. Not ice-cold, but just... no heat at all. Like... 
 
 He turned back to her. He stared into her eyes. Her red eyes. Her brilliant glimmering red eyes... 
 
 Tia looked at his face. Dale's eyes were bloodshot, surrounded by deep, heavy bags that made him seem much older than he really was. She looked at the slight stubble on his face. He's cut himself shaving a few days ago, and the cut just above his lip was just now starting to heal. 
 
 `` Are you here to kill me?'' Dale asked. 
 
 `` Kill you? I-I'd never dream of that. No, no, no... in fact. I'm here to offer you an alternative. A way out.'' 
 
 He looked at her. `` Go on...'' 
 
 `` Well, Dale... I... I think I'm in love with you.'' 
 
 Dale was silent. He lay back in the couch. He let his body sink into the cushions. He gently squeezed her hand. 
 
 `` Are you... are you the reaper?'' 
 
 `` The reaper? Grim? The Grim Reaper? Oh no, Grim, he retired several eons ago. No, me, I'm the... I'm the angel of death.'' 
 
 `` Makes sense. You are very easy on the eyes.'' 
 
 If Tia could blush, she would have. She smiled. `` Dale, I want to save you.'' 
 
 `` You do n't want to save me.'' 
 
 `` But I do.'' 
 
 `` Why me?'' 
 
 `` Why not you?'' 
 
 `` Why did you stop me? What's the difference? I'm going to die anyway; what the difference between a suicide and a heart attack? Do n't we all go to the same place when we die?'' 
 
 She put her hand under his chin and turned his head to face her. 
 
 He was crying. 
 
 `` Dale...'' She pulled him close. He did not resist. He quietly wept into her chest. His tears rolled down her dress and onto the couch. She quietly pet his head and cooed in his ear. `` There, there... it's okay... shhh.... It's okay. Look, Dale. Look at that sunset.'' 
 
 Dale did not look at the sunset. 
 
 Dale looked at her. He looked into her eyes. She looked into his. 
 
 He kissed her. 
 
 Time stopped. 
 
 There was a flash, and then... 
 
 Dale stood over himself. 
 
 He looked around. He looked at the sun, it's brilliant rays casting shadows over the town below. He turned his back on the town. He turned toward the door that had materialized in front of him. 
 
 Gingerly, he opened it. 
 
 Tia stood on the other side, watching the stars. She turned and saw him. 
 
 She smiled. 
 
 He took her hand. He kissed it lightly. 
 
 They walked away into the abyss.

“Tia. My name is Tia.”

“That’s a pretty name.”

Tia studied his face. Dale’s eyes were bloodshot, surrounded by deep, heavy bags that made him look much older than he was. She saw the light stubble on his face. He had cut himself shaving a few days ago, and the cut just above his lip was only just beginning to heal.

“Are you here to kill me?” asked Dale.

“Kill you? I-I would never dream of it. No, no, no… on the contrary. I’m here to offer you an alternative. A way out.”

He looked at her. “Go on…”

“Well, Dale… I… I think I’ve fallen in love with you.”

Dale fell silent. He leaned back into the sofa. He let his body sink into the cushions. He gently squeezed her hand.
