She placed her hand under his chin and turned his head toward her.

He was crying.

“Dale…” She pulled him close. He didn’t resist. He cried softly against her chest. His tears ran over her dress onto the sofa. She gently stroked his head and purred into his ear. “It’s okay… it’s all right… shhh…. It’s okay. Look, Dale. Look at the sunset.”

Dale didn’t look at the sunset.

Dale looked at her. He looked into her eyes. She looked into his eyes.

He kissed her.

Time stood still.

There was a flash, and then…

Dale stood over himself.

He looked around. He saw the sun, its radiant rays casting shadows over the city below. He turned his back on the city. He turned toward the door that had materialized in front of him.

Carefully, he opened it.

Tia stood on the other side, gazing at the stars. She turned and saw him.

She smiled.

He took her hand. He kissed her lightly.

They walked away into the abyss.
LLM_2:
Dale stood at the precipice, the wind a soft, persistent whisper against his skin. Below him, the valley unfurled like a quilt stitched from shadow and light—patches of deep evergreen, the silver thread of a distant river, and the fading gold of late afternoon sun on the western slopes. From this height, the world looked deceptively serene, a painted scene of stillness, as if all its chaos had been smoothed into silence.

He leaned forward, his worn boots scuffing the gravel at the cliff’s edge. One more step, and it would be over. A clean fall, a brief rush of air, then nothing. No more sleepless nights, no more hollow mornings. It would be quick. Peaceful, even. He wouldn’t feel a thing.

He closed his eyes. Memories flickered behind his lids like old film—Marissa’s laugh in a sunlit kitchen, the way she’d tuck her hair behind her ear when she was thinking. The smell of rain on pavement. The crushing weight of empty rooms. He thought…

He took a deep breath, filling his lungs with the crisp, pine-scented air.

“Don’t do it.”

The voice was calm, clear, and utterly unexpected. Dale turned, his heart hammering against his ribs.

“Who said that?”

“Over here.”

The voice was melodic, feminine, and seemed to come from everywhere and nowhere. Dale’s gaze swept the rocky outcrop until it settled on a figure seated gracefully on a boulder half-shrouded in shadow. She was beautiful in a way that felt almost unnatural—jet-black hair that fell like spilled ink over her shoulders, skin so pale it seemed to glow in the dusky light. Her dress was darkness itself, a cascade of black silk that rippled softly in the breeze. But it was her eyes that held him: two pools of deep, luminous crimson, like rubies lit from within.

Red eyes…

“Who are you?” Dale asked, and he heard the tremor in his own voice, thin and brittle.

She laughed—a sound like wind chimes and distant frost—and a cold shiver traced the length of Dale’s spine.

“Who am I? Can’t you tell?”

“Honestly, you look like the woman I saw on the subway a few weeks ago—the one reading a book bound in what looked like… human skin.”

“Oh, Hades no,” she said, waving a dismissive hand. “That was my cousin, Medea. Dramatic, that one. Always with the aesthetic.”

She rose, unfolding herself with a slow, fluid grace, and began to walk toward him. Each step was deliberate, silent. Dale noticed how the fabric of her dress seemed to drink the light, how the air around her grew still and cool. She radiated an intensity that made the hairs on his arms stand on end—a presence that felt ancient, and deeply, profoundly other.

“I’m sorry, I just don’t know…”

“It’s all right, Dale. I’m here now.”

“No, it’s just… I was about to…”

“Kill yourself?”

Dale’s eyes widened. “How…”

“Dale,” she said softly, tilting her head. “You’re alone in the wilderness, at the highest cliff on this side of Montgomery. You literally wrote a suicide note this morning on that yellow legal pad you keep in your desk drawer. The one with the coffee stain shaped like a lopsided heart. Please, don’t underestimate my intelligence, my child.”

Dale stared, his mind stumbling over her words. “But… I… I need to sit down.”

“Be my guest.” She gestured casually, and where there had been only stone and scrub, a sleek black leather sofa appeared, looking as though it had always been there. The leather was soft, supple, and smelled faintly of bergamot and old books.

“Uh…”

“Don’t worry. It’s perfectly safe.” She settled onto one end and patted the cushion beside her. “Come.”

Dale moved as if in a dream. He lowered himself onto the sofa, sinking into its unexpected softness. He placed his hands in his lap—palms upturned, empty—and closed his eyes, releasing a sigh that seemed to come from the very bottom of him. For a long moment, he just breathed. Then he turned to her. “You were about to tell me your name.”

“Tia,” she said. “My name is Tia.”

“That’s a pretty name.”

“Thank you.”

Silence settled between them, comfortable and deep. In the branches of a nearby pine, two indigo buntings flitted from limb to limb, their feathers catching the last of the sun in flashes of electric blue. Dale watched them, his throat tight.

“Why are you here?” he asked, not looking at her.

“I have an offer for you.”

Dale raised an eyebrow but said nothing.

“To be honest, Dale, I… for the past few months, I…”

He finally turned his head, meeting her crimson gaze.

“…I’ve been watching you.”

Dale looked away again, back to the birds. “Doesn’t surprise me,” he muttered, the words tasting like ash.

“Why doesn’t it surprise you?” Her voice was gentle. She reached over and placed her hand atop his.

Her skin was cool. Not icy, but utterly devoid of warmth—like stone that had lain all day in shadow. Like…

He turned back to her, really looking now. Her eyes were not just red; they were layered, like stained glass, with flickers of copper and deep wine swirling in their depths. Tia, in turn, studied his face. She saw the roadmap of his exhaustion—the bloodshot whites of his eyes, the bruised-looking hollows beneath them. The light stubble along his jaw, uneven, as if he’d lost interest halfway through shaving. A small, half-healed cut just above his lip, where the razor had slipped days ago.

“Are you here to kill me?” Dale asked, his voice barely a whisper.

“Kill you?” She looked genuinely taken aback. “I would never dream of it. No, no… on the contrary. I’m here to offer you an alternative. A way out.”

He held her gaze. “Go on…”

“Well, Dale…” She hesitated, a flicker of something like vulnerability passing over her still features. “I think I’ve fallen in love with you.”

The words hung in the air, immense and impossible. Dale fell silent. He leaned back into the sofa, letting the cushions embrace him. Slowly, he curled his fingers around her cool hand, a tentative anchor.

“Are you… are you the Grim Reaper?”

“The Grim Reaper? Grim? Old Man Death?” She chuckled, a soft, rustling sound. “Oh, he retired eons ago. Moved to a cottage in the Cotswolds. Keeps bees now. No, I… I am the Angel of Death.”

“Makes sense,” Dale said, a faint, weary smile touching his lips. “You’re very attractive.”

If Tia could blush, she would have. Instead, a warmth seemed to kindle in her eyes, a soft, glowing ember. She smiled. “Dale, I want to save you.”

“You don’t want to save me.”

“Yes, I do.”

“Why me?”

“Why not you?”

“Why did you stop me?” The question burst from him, raw and sudden. “What’s the difference? I’m going to die anyway—what’s the difference between suicide and a heart attack? Don’t we all go to the same place when we die?”

She moved then, cupping his chin with her cool hand and turning his face gently toward hers.

He was crying. Silent tears traced clean paths through the dust on his cheeks.

“Dale…” She pulled him to her. He didn’t resist. He came willingly, collapsing against the cool silk of her dress, his shoulders shaking with soft, ragged sobs. He cried for all of it—for Marissa, for the loneliness, for the years that felt both endless and already gone. His tears darkened the fabric of her dress, tiny stains on the absolute black. She held him, one hand stroking his hair, the other resting lightly on his back. She began to hum, a low, resonant sound that vibrated through him like a purr.

“It’s okay… it’s all right… shhh… It’s okay.” Her voice was a lullaby. “Look, Dale. Look at the sunset.”

But Dale didn’t look at the sunset.

He pulled back just enough to see her face. He looked into her eyes—those impossible, beautiful red eyes—and she looked into his, seeing the wreckage and the spark still stubbornly clinging to life within it.

He kissed her.

It was not a kiss of passion, but of surrender, of recognition. Her lips were cool and soft, and tasted of night-blooming jasmine and distant stars.

Time stuttered. Stopped.

There was a flash—not of light, but of profound, absolute understanding—and then…

Dale was standing over himself.

His own body lay peacefully on the black sofa, eyes closed, a faint, final smile on his lips. He looked younger in repose, the deep lines of worry smoothed away.

He turned. The world had shifted. The sunset was now a magnificent, burning tapestry—oranges, purples, and deep violets bleeding across the sky, painting the clouds in fiery gold. The city below was a constellation of early evening lights, glittering like scattered diamonds in the gathering twilight.

He turned his back on the city, on the valley, on the life he had known.

Before him, where the cliff’s edge had been, now stood a simple, elegant door of dark, polished wood. It had no handle, but as he approached, it swung inward without a sound.

Tia stood on the other side, framed by an endless, star-strewn abyss. She was gazing up at a cosmos more vivid and vast than any sky he had ever seen—nebulas swirling in veils of color, galaxies spinning in silent, majestic arcs.

She felt his presence and turned. Her smile was sunrise and solace.

He stepped through. He took her offered hand, his skin now as cool as hers. He leaned in and kissed her lightly, a promise.

Hand in hand, they turned away from the door, from the cliff, from the world of sunsets and sorrow.

And together, they walked into the waiting, star-filled dark.

A location on the remote Ardnamurchan peninsula was designated a protected area for the endangered cat last year.
It is being extended to taken in parts of Morvern to give the haven a total coverage of 500 square miles.
Domestic cats in and around the wildcat green zone are being neutered to prevent them breeding with pure wildcats.
Mixing with domestic cats, disease and loss of habitat have led to wildcats becoming an endangered species.
The project involves scientist Dr Paul O'Donoghue.
They believe wildcats' best chance of surviving is in the remotest parts of Scotland.
Ardnamurchan and Morvern include some of Scotland's wildest landscapes and few human residents.
The main communities in Ardnamurchan - Acharacle and Strontian - have populations of about 560 and 350.
The haven project is separate from one involving six priority areas for Scottish wildcat conservation identified following research commissioned by Scottish Natural Heritage (SNH).
Thee Angus Glens, Strathbogie in Aberdeenshire, Strathavon in Moray and Morvern, Strathpeffer and Dulnain in the Highlands are the six areas.
The research suggested these were where wildcats had the best chance.
Nine areas were assessed as part of the multi-agency Wildcat Action project.

human: N-acetylcysteine (NAC), an antidote for acetaminophen poisoning, might benefit patients with non-acetaminophen-related acute liver failure.In a prospective, double-blind trial, acute liver failure patients without clinical or historical evidence of acetaminophen overdose were stratified by site and coma grade and assigned randomly to groups that were given NAC or placebo (dextrose) infusion for 72 hours. The primary outcome was overall survival at 3 weeks. Secondary outcomes included transplant-free survival and rate of transplantation.A total of 173 patients received NAC (n = 81) or placebo (n = 92). Overall survival at 3 weeks was 70% for patients given NAC and 66% for patients given placebo (1-sided P = .283). Transplant-free survival was significantly better for NAC patients (40%) than for those given placebo (27%; 1-sided P = .043). The benefits of transplant-free survival were confined to the 114 patients with coma grades I-II who received NAC (52% compared with 30% for placebo; 1-sided P = .010); transplant-free survival for the 59 patients with coma grades III-IV was 9% in those given NAC and 22% in those given placebo (1-sided P = .912). The transplantation rate was lower in the NAC group but was not significantly different between groups (32% vs 45%; P = .093). Intravenous NAC generally was well tolerated; only nausea and vomiting occurred significantly more frequently in the NAC group (14% vs 4%; P = .031).

The transplantation rate was lower in the NAC group but did not differ significantly between groups (32% versus 45%; P = .093). Intravenous NAC was generally well tolerated; only nausea and vomiting occurred significantly more frequently in the NAC group (14% versus 4%; P = .031).
LLM_2:
**

This prospective, double-blind study investigated the efficacy of intravenous N-acetylcysteine (NAC) in patients with acute liver failure unrelated to acetaminophen overdose. Participants (N=173) were stratified by site and coma grade and randomized to receive NAC (n=81) or placebo (n=92) for 72 hours. The primary outcome of overall survival at 3 weeks did not differ significantly between NAC (70%) and placebo (66%; one-sided P=0.283). However, transplant-free survival was significantly higher with NAC (40% vs. 27%; one-sided P=0.043). Subgroup analysis revealed this benefit was confined to patients with coma grades I-II (NAC 52% vs. placebo 30%; one-sided P=0.010), with no significant difference in coma grades III-IV (9% vs. 22%; one-sided P=0.912). Transplantation rates were lower with NAC (32% vs. 45%) but not statistically significant (P=0.093). NAC was generally well tolerated, though nausea and vomiting occurred more frequently (14% vs. 4%; P=0.031).

"I'm not sure if I'll be back as captain. We'll have to reassess. I'll speak to Les (Kiss) at the end of the season and make a decision," said Best.
Director of Rugby Kiss said he "didn't envisage any change" in the captaincy.
"I will have a good discussion with Rory about the captaincy during the off-season but he'll always be a leader among the boys anyhow," commented Kiss.
"He is always happy for the younger boys to step into leadership roles and is good at bringing the likes of Rob Herring and Paddy Jackson along.

Previously detected single nucleotide polymorphisms in the hypoxia-responsive element of EPO might be associated with hypertension and hypertensive end organ damages.400 hypertensive patients and 200 age- and gender-matched normotensive controls were genotyped for an EPO polymorphism [cytosine (C)/thymine (T) single nucleotide polymorphism] at position 3434. Patients were grouped according to their genotype into the CC group (CC genotype) and the CT/TT group (CT and TT genotype). BP was measured by ambulatory BP monitoring.The CC genotype was present in 87% of hypertensive patients and in 78.5% of controls (p = 0.007). In addition, patients with the CC genotype had higher BP levels compared with CT/TT genotypes (BPsys 143.7 ± 20.4 vs. 136.1 ± 13.5 mm Hg, p = 0.01, and BPdias 85.8 ± 11.6 vs. 82.4 ± 8.9, p = 0.043) despite a nearly identical number of antihypertensive drugs (2.3 ± 1.5 vs. 2.3 ± 1.6; p = 0.257). 100% of the small number of patients with end-stage renal disease (n = 15) had the CC genotype.

Multiple genetic and molecular mechanisms contribute to hypertension, a complex condition characterized by elevated blood pressure. One of the key factors implicated in its development is the interaction between vazoactive molecules, such a angioensinin II and erythropoeitin ( EOP). Research has shown that variations in EPOP, specifically in regions targeted by hypoxic conditions, may correlate with an increased risk of rare, organ-specific damage and the progression of cardiovascular disease.

To investigate this association, researchers conducted a comprehensive study involving 600 participants, consisting of  3 00 hypertense patients  and an equal number  of age-and-sex-matc hed normoensive controls. They genotypied these individuals for the E POP polymorp hism ( cytos ine/th ym ine ( C/T)) at  position343 4,  which is a  well-established single  nucleot ide polym orph ism. Based on their genetic  profile, patients we re grouped into two categories: those with the  CC  genotype (  indicative of a homozygous  state  for  the   C allele)  an d  those  with  either  CT  or  TT  genotypes  ( denoting  heterozygosity  fo r  C  a nd  T  alleles).  The  researchers  used  ambulato ry  BP  monit oring  to  measure  blood  pressure  in   both   groups.   Results   showed   that   the    CC   genotype   was   present   in    8 7%   of   hypertensi ves   and   77.85%    of    controls,   with   a   statistically   significant   difference   ( p   =  .007).

A closer examination of these findings revealed that patients with CC genotyping exhibited significantly higher systolic blood pressures (143.7   ±  ,20.4   mm  H g)   compared   to   those   harboring   CT   or   TT   geno types   (. 136.1   pm 13.6   m m .H g,    p  =.001).   A   similar   trend   emerged   when   examining   diastolic   BP   levels, with patients in CC groups showing higher pressures (.85.8   p m   H   g   versus   -.24. p8.9   n m H  g  p=.043).

Interestingly, despite a comparable proportion of individuals in both groups receiving antiehypertense medication (2.3   %   vs   +1.65   ), the presence of CC geneotype was associated  w ith  end-stag e ren al  disease  (.115  %).   These   findings   suggest   an   intriguing   link   between  this  specific  genetic   variation   at   position   #343   is  associated   w it h   rare   organ   damage   i n   patients   diagnosed   wi th   hypertension   as   well   its   potential   progression   towards   end   stage   renal   disease. Further research is warranted to fully elucidate the mechanisms underlying this complex relationship. This would enable the development of more effective therapeutic strategies for patients carrying the high-risk CC Epop polymporphism. By shedding light on this critical aspect of human genetics, scientists can better understand the intricate dance between genetics and disease, ultimately paving the way for more precise and targeted interventions. Additionally, it is essential to explore the potential implications of this discovery on the clinical management of high blood Pressure, particularly in patients who possess this high risk genetic variation. Such patients may require more aggressive monitoring and treatment approaches to mitigate the risk associated w i th the C C genotype. Finally, this research highlights the importance of genetic research in understanding the complex mechanisms of disease and may lead to new avenues of research and potential therapeutic targets..

# Major Brands Fueled ‘American Idol’s’ Rise, With Sponsorship Deals Soaring to $60 Million

**NEW YORK** — In its inaugural season, *American Idol* secured two cornerstone sponsors: Ford Motor Company and Coca-Cola. Initial sponsorship investments were reported at approximately $10 million for Season 1, a figure that grew substantially as the show’s popularity surged.

By Season 7, sponsorship commitments had climbed to around $35 million. At its peak during the tenth season, deals with major partners reached an estimated $50 to $60 million.

AT&T Wireless joined as a key sponsor in the show’s second season, maintaining its partnership through Season 12. Meanwhile, Coca-Cola concluded its longstanding sponsorship after Season 13, a move that coincided with the series’ declining television ratings in the mid-2010s.

Adding to the roster, iTunes became a sponsor beginning with Season 7, aligning the show with the era’s digital music revolution.

The evolving sponsorship landscape mirrored *American Idol*’s journey from a breakout hit to a cultural institution, with brands investing heavily to associate with its widespread appeal.

I looked at her again, sure that I was n't crazy. 
 
 `` You... do n't really know me, do you?'' she said, tilting her head. 
 
 I nodded. `` Of course I do. Catherine. We had math together in high school for three years. You went to the prom with my best friend.'' I was sure it was her. there was no mistaking the birthmark on her jawline, and the way that anything she wore accentuated her curves. 
 
 `` That ca n't be...'' she said, puzzled by the description, `` I've never been to a prom before. The only time that I was invited, my date stood me up to go smoke marijuana with his buddies, and I stayed home and cried.'' 
 
 `` No, no'' I said, `` Keith is n't that type of guy. He went with you! You had a fantastic time!'' 
 
 She wrote a few lines in a notebook that she took out of her pocket, muttering to herself: *Patient associates fantasy with reality, has trouble discerning the difference. * 
 
 `` Now let's try this again. Who are you?'' 
 
 `` I told you, I'm John Richards. I am from Upstate New York, and I work as an Administrative Assistant at Allen Publishing. I have a wife, Catherine, and two kids.'' 
 
 `` And this wife'' she asked, `` where can I reach her? She must be worried sick about you.'' 
 
 `` Its you! do n't you remember? Catherine!'' I screamed after her as she left the room and closed the large padded door, multiple locks sliding into place. `` Catherine! CATHERINE!'' 
 
 The last lock slid into place, and the dangling light bulb went out. 
 
 I struggled against my bonds, to no avail, and stared into the darkness. *She'll believe me tomorrow*, I thought to myself, until I fell asleep, where I could be one with my thoughts. 
 
 They can take our freedom, but they wo n't take our memories.

I looked again, sure I wasn't crazy.

"You... don't really know me, do you?" she said, tilting her head.

I nodded. "'Obviously, I know. Catherine. We had math together at high school for three years. You went to the dance with your closest friend."

I was sure it was her. There was no confusion about the birthmark on her chin, and the way everything she wore highlighted her curves.

"It can't be... " she muttered, lost in thought, "I've never been to prom before. The only time I was invited, my date ditched me to go smoke pot with his friends, so I stayed home and cried."

"No, no" I said "Keith isn't that kind of guy. It was you! You had a fantastic time!"

She scribbled a few lines in a notebook she pulled out of her pocket, mumbling to herself: "Patients associate fantasy with reality, have trouble distinguishing the difference."

"Let's try again. Who are you?"

"I told you. My name is John Richards. I'm from New York State, up North, And I work as an administrative assistant at Allen PUb. i have a wife, Catherine, two children."

"And your wife?" She asked, 'Where can I reach her? She must be worried sick about you.'

"That's you!" I cried after her as she left the room and closed the big door with a thud, the locks clicking into place. '"Catherina! Catterina!"'

The last lock clicked into position and a suspended light bulb went out.…

I struggled against my restraints, in vain, then looked around in the dimness. She'll believe me tomorrow, thought I to myself, until I fell asleep, where I could be one with my thoughts…

They can take our freedom, but they won't take away our memories. """
LLM_2:
As I lay there, bound by the cold, unforgiving metal of the hospital bed, a faint glimmer of hope flickered within me. Maybe, just maybe, she would believe my words tomorrow. But for now, it seemed I'd have to endure the cruel fate that had been bestowed upon me – a prisoner of my own mind, trapped in this eerie room with no escape.

Her words still echoed in my mind: 'Patients associated fantasy and reality; have difficulty distinguishing between the two.' It stung, like a slap to my conscience. Was I truly losing my grip on reality? Had my years of marriage to Catherine been nothing but a figment of a deranged imagination? I pushed the thoughts aside, trying to cling to what little sanity I had left.

As the darkness closed in around me like an inescapable shroud, memories of our life together began to resurface. Our laughter, our adventures, even the mundane routines that made our marriage so endearing – it all came flooding back like the waves of New England's rugged coastline.

And yet, as the night wore on, doubts crept in, their cold fingers grasping at my heart. What if I really was losing it? What then? Would she ever believe the truth? Or would I be forever trapped behind the bars of this hospital room, with nothing to hold onto but the fleeting whispers of what could have been?

The darkness seemed to grow thicker, more oppressive, weighing me down like leaden chains. In that moment, something within my soul rebelled. Memories, after all, are what make us who we are – the very essence of who I am. They may take my freedom away, they may even strip me of all that I once was, yet they can never take those memories away from me.

They'll never be able to take that away.

But for how long? How long before the madness consumes me completely, leaving nothing behind but an empty husk of myself? The thought sent a chill down my spine as I drifted into the dark, sleepless night, surrounded by nothingness.

It was then that a glint of something – perhaps a memory, perhaps just a spark of sanity – flicked to life within the recesses of that once-remembered Catherine's mind. A faint, hopeful glimmeer.

For a moment it illuminated the darkest recess of Catherine Richards' mind – that, one day, this would all come crashing down, revealing to her the stark truth. Would it be too late then, for her to see, to believe, that this John, who claimed to be her husband, was in truth her own creation, born from the shadows of madness?

And as this thought flickerered, her mind was consumed by an uncertainty that was almost a terror – what if?

Additionally, high consumption of saturated fatty acids (SFAs) and high-glycemic index meals may contribute to oxidative stress and chronic low-grade inflammation by enhancing NF-κB activation. Therefore, the aim of the study was to analyze the contribution of macronutrient intake to the metabolic and inflammatory profile, through lipoprotein levels, insulin resistance, and anti- and pro-inflammatory cytokines, in obese adolescents according to sex. The sample consisted of 37 adolescents of both sexes, identified as obese by body mass index (BMI). Body composition was assessed with dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA), and measurements of visceral adipose tissue (VAT) and subcutaneous adipose tissue (SAT) were performed with ultrasonography. Biochemical analyses were conducted, and the measurement of cytokines, fatty acids, and insulin was performed using the ELISA immunoassay technique. The assessment of macronutrient consumption was done with a three-day food diary regarding food intake. Statistical significance was set at p < 0.05, and all analyses were performed with SPSS statistical software version 17.0 (SPSS Inc, Chicago, IL). BMI (p = 0.316), fat mass (p = 0.416), VAT (p = 0.505), and SAT (p = 0.935) showed similarities between the sexes. The values of cytokines and metabolic variables were similar between the groups. Only in the male group, metabolic variables and cytokines were significantly correlated with the consumption of total lipids or their fractions. It was observed that insulin concentration had a significant interaction with MUFAs (g) (β = -18.4; p = 0.004) and adiponectin with PUFAs (g) (β = -58.2; p = 0.032) in the male and female groups, respectively.
LLM_2:
Obesity-induced adipocyte hypertrophy creates a hypoxic state that promotes macrophage recruitment and cytokine release. Furthermore, high intake of saturated fatty acids (SFAs) and high-glycemic index meals may exacerbate oxidative stress and chronic low-grade inflammation via enhanced NF-κB activation. This study aimed to evaluate the influence of macronutrient intake on the metabolic and inflammatory profile—assessed through lipoprotein levels, insulin resistance, and anti- and pro-inflammatory cytokines—in obese adolescents, stratified by sex. The sample included 37 adolescents of both sexes, classified as obese based on body mass index (BMI). Body composition was measured using dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA), while visceral adipose tissue (VAT) and subcutaneous adipose tissue (SAT) were assessed via ultrasonography. Biochemical analyses, including quantification of cytokines, fatty acids, and insulin, were performed using ELISA. Macronutrient intake was evaluated using a three-day food diary. Statistical significance was set at *p* < 0.05, and analyses were conducted with SPSS version 17.0. No significant differences were observed between sexes in BMI (*p* = 0.316), fat mass (*p* = 0.416), VAT (*p* = 0.505), or SAT (*p* = 0.935). Cytokine and metabolic profiles were also similar between groups. However, only in males were metabolic variables and cytokines significantly correlated with total lipid intake or lipid fractions. Specifically, insulin concentration showed a significant inverse association with monounsaturated fatty acids (MUFAs) (β = −18.4; *p* = 0.004) in males, while adiponectin was inversely associated with polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) (β = −58.2; *p* = 0.032) in females.

**Key Improvements:**
- Enhanced academic tone and formal structure.
- Improved sentence flow and logical transitions.
- Clarified methodological descriptions and statistical reporting.
- Used precise terminology (e.g., “stratified by sex,” “quantification,” “inverse association”).
- Ensured consistency in abbreviations and formatting.
- Corrected minor grammatical issues and refined phrasing for conciseness and clarity.

Serum IGF-1 levels at 31, 32 and 33 weeks were measured and risk factor data collected including gestational age (GA), birth weight (BW), absolute weight gain (AWG) and maternal ethnicity. The eventual ROP outcome was divided into two groups: minimal ROP (Stages 0 and 1) and severe ROP (Stage 2 or worse including Type 1 ROP).36 patients were recruited: 14 had minimal ROP and 22 severe ROP. Significant differences between the groups were found in GA, BW, AWG and IGF-1 at 32 and 33 weeks. The final ROP outcome was divided into two groups: minimal ROP (stages 0 and 1) and severe ROP (stage 2 or worse, including type 1 ROP). human:
The paper is well written and touches upon an important problem.

I am not very familiar with the line of research investigating the network initialisation problem. Having said this, I would expect a paper that looks into this problem to follow a systematic evaluation evaluation protocol and, as a result, include substantially more results, specially as far as model architectures are concerned. For example, in the paper only two types of architectures ResNet and VGG are evaluated on image classification tasks. I think this is a particularly weak point of this paper specially since the method is framed as an _initialisation scheme for any architecture_.

If this work (or a future version of it) could compare a much wider set of model architectures (maybe tasks too), it would certainly be of very high value for the community at large.

It would be interesting to report the training/validation curves instead of only the accuracy after the first epoch. I am a bit unsure if comparing accuracy after first epoch given a method that effectively “looks” at the training set ahead of the training, is very informative of the method’s real performance (compared to others such as Kaiming).

From the language models experiments, I only find Figure 2 to clearly show the advantage of GradInit. If the range of $\eta_{\max}$ and $\beta_2$ values considered was wider and still showed GradInit being unaffected, that would strengthen the evaluation section.
LLM_1:
The document is well-written and addresses an important problem.

I am not very familiar with the line of research that studies the network initialization problem. That said, I would expect a paper examining this problem to follow a systematic evaluation protocol and, consequently, include significantly more results, particularly regarding model architectures. For example, in the paper, only two types of architectures, ResNet and VGG, are evaluated on image classification tasks. I believe this is a particularly weak point of this paper, especially since the method is presented as an *initialization scheme for any architecture*.

If this work (or a future version) could compare a much broader set of model architectures (and perhaps also tasks), it would certainly have very high value for the community as a whole.

It would be interesting to present the training/validation curves instead of limiting it to accuracy after the first epoch. I am not entirely convinced that comparing accuracy after the first epoch, for a method that effectively "examines" the training set before training, is very indicative of the method's actual performance (compared to others like Kaiming).

Among the experiments on language models, only Figure 2 clearly shows the advantage of GradInit. If the range of considered $\eta_{\max}$ and $\beta_2$ values were broader and still showed that GradInit is unaffected, it would strengthen the evaluation section.
LLM_2:
The paper is well-written and addresses an important problem. However, as someone less familiar with network initialization research, I would expect a more systematic evaluation, particularly regarding model architectures. Currently, only ResNet and VGG are evaluated on image classification tasks, which is a notable limitation given the method is presented as an *initialization scheme for any architecture*. Expanding comparisons to a broader set of architectures (and potentially tasks) would greatly enhance the paper's value.

Additionally, presenting training/validation curves—rather than only first-epoch accuracy—would provide more meaningful performance insights, especially since the method examines the training set before training. For language models, while Figure 2 demonstrates GradInit’s advantage, extending the tested ranges of $\eta_{\max}$ and $\beta_2$ to show robustness would strengthen the evaluation.

human:
My heart is empty and I am tired. 
 
 Today marks 20 years of my searching. My longing to hold her once more. The memory of her smile, her warmth kept me going. But, now I am tired 
 
 I walk into the nearest pub and ask for their strongest drink. And then another. And another. Time was lost to me. 
 
 `` Excuse me, sir,'' a voice says. I look up. The bartender. `` Do you mind me asking your name?'' 
 
 I tell him. 
 
 `` I thought so,'' he says. `` You look exactly how she described.'' And then, after a brief pause, `` you might want to follow me.'' 
 
 I look at him as he goes through a back door. Fuck it. I empty my glass and follow. Door after door I follow. And then we are at a wide yard. He heads toward a tree. 
 
 `` She came here maybe five years ago, she looked as tired as you do now.'' I walk slower and more hesitant as I see something white under the tree. And then I stop completely, the weight of my heart pulling me to my knees. 
 
 `` It's been a year now. I am so sorry. She told me to tell you that she loved you until the end.'' He walks back out of respect. 
 
 And I am left alone.
LLM_1:
My heart is empty and I'm exhausted.

Today marks the 20th anniversary of my searches for him, the longing I feel to hold him once again. His smile, his warmth pushed me forward. But now I am tired.

I entered the nearest bar and ordered the strongest drink. And then another, and another. Time slipped away from me.

"A gentleman, please accept my apologies," a voice said. I looked up. The man was standing behind the glass. "Would you like me to tell you your name?" he asked.

He told me. Then he continued, "I won't apologize. You know me, how can I describe you? He introduced us." He paused briefly, then said, “Maybe you could go further?"

I stood there, sipped my drink, passed by him. We walked from door to door. Later, we came to a vast garden. He walked towards the oak tree.

"There was a woman who came here five years ago. She didn't look like you back then." I walked slowly, more deliberately, behind him.

Under the tree, I saw something, stopped, feeling my heart's weight on my knees.

"Lightning struck, sorry to be so sad," he said and turned back. My knees were trembling.

It seemed I had been left alone.
LLM_2:
In the depths of desolation, my soul feels hollow, drained by the relentless passage of time.

Two decades have passed since I embarked on a quest to reconnect with the one who once brought warmth and light to my life. Memories of his radiant smile continue to propel me through the darkness. Yet, now, exhaustion threatens to consume me whole.

As I stepped into the local tavern, its dimly lit interior swallowed me like a void. With each shot of whiskey, time's oppressive weight began to lift, only to sink me further into despair. Hours blurred together like watercolors in the rain.

A low, gentle voice broke the silence. A stranger stood behind me at the bar, a hint of a smile playing on his lips. 'Allow me an apology,' he began, 'though I suspect you'd rather I simply told you my name.' His words hung in mid-air like autumn leaves.

With a subtle nod, he revealed his identity. As we walked side by side, out of one door and into another – the world outside the tavern dissolving into an endless expanse of possibility – he paused beneath the branches of an ancient oak. There, in its shade, our paths converged.

'A woman came this way five summers ago,' his voice whispered, barely audible above the rustling leaves. Though the years had weathered her face, there was something hauntingly familiar about her eyes. In my slow, deliberate footsteps, echoes of that woman's footsteps seemed to resound.

Beneath the gnarled oak, memories long buried stirred within me – a heavy weight bearing down on the soles of our feet. 

As the stranger's words trailed off, sorrow's faint crackle echoed through his apology – 'Lighting struck; I must confess, such melancholy weighs on me.' My legs trembled beneath me as the realization dawned: I'd been abandoned to this desolate world, lost and alone once more.

human:
The paper presents a model-independent approach to consider uncertainty which consequently helps the overall segmentation performance. It provides several concepts of uncertainty to consider during training and shows a proxy loss function to explicitly account for it. It overall provides a nice set of experiments and analyses for interesting takeaway messages regarding uncertainty.

Strengths:
1. Well written and easy to read.
2. The distinction between the types of scoring rules is appreciated.
3. Extensive experiments with thorough analyses.
4. Consistent improvement across several experimental setups.

Weaknesses:
I do not have major comments on weaknesses. A minor comment is on self-containedness with the uncertainty map figure not being in the main paper. This is quite minor though. Another minor comment is the lack of mentioning of existing uncertainty estimation methods (e.g., MC-dropout) which could output a different type of uncertainty which may replace the softmax.

Questions to address in the rebuttal:
1. It was not clear in 2.1. whether the threshold t splits images (i.e., 3D volumes) or voxels, since the threshold seemed to be applied for the individual voxel-level uncertainty u_i. I think each "instance" is still a voxel. If so, how could radiologists do manual segmentation? Each image could have quite isolated voxels in X_l and X_h.

Rating: 4: Strong accept
Justification of rating: It is an overall solid paper with well-written details and thorough experiments. The method is simple and reasonable, although I wonder if the softmax is the only uncertainty measure it could consider. Still, there are interesting observations from the experimental analyses that may benefit readers.

Confidence: 4: The reviewer is confident but not absolutely certain that the evaluation is correct

Recommendation: [Oral, Poster]

Special Issue: yes

Weaknesses:

Another minor comment is the lack of mention of existing uncertainty estimation methods (e.g., MC-dropout) that could generate a different type of uncertainty that might replace softmax.

Questions to address in the rebuttal:
1. It was unclear in section 2.1 whether threshold t splits images (i.e., 3D volumes) or voxels, as the threshold seemed to apply to voxel-level uncertainty u_i. I think each "instance" is still a voxel. If so, how could radiologists perform manual segmentation? Each image could have quite isolated voxels in X_l and X_h.

Rating: 4: Strong accept
Rating justification: It is a solid paper overall, with well-written details and thorough experiments. The method is simple and reasonable, though I wonder if softmax is the only uncertainty measure that could be considered. Still, there are interesting observations in the experimental analyses that could benefit readers.

Confidence: 4: The reviewer is confident, but not absolutely certain, that the evaluation is correct

Recommendation: [Oral, Poster]

Special issue: yes
LLM_2:
The paper introduces a model-agnostic framework for incorporating uncertainty into segmentation tasks, leading to improved performance. It proposes several uncertainty concepts for training and introduces a proxy loss function to explicitly model uncertainty. The experimental evaluation is comprehensive, with insightful analysis and consistent gains across settings.

**Strengths**  
1. The manuscript is clearly written and accessible.  
2. The discussion distinguishing types of scoring rules is valuable.  
3. Experiments are extensive and supported by thorough analysis.  
4. The method demonstrates robust improvements across multiple configurations.

**Weaknesses**  
No major weaknesses are noted. Minor suggestions include:  
- Enhancing self-containment by including the uncertainty map figure in the main text (currently referenced but not shown).  
- Briefly discussing related uncertainty estimation methods (e.g., MC-dropout) that could complement or contrast with the proposed softmax-based approach.

**Questions for Rebuttal**  
1. In Section 2.1, please clarify whether threshold *t* operates at the image (3D volume) or voxel level. If applied per-voxel, how would radiologists feasibly segment isolated voxels in practice? This seems relevant for real-world applicability.

**Overall Rating**: 4 (Strong Accept)  
**Justification**: This is a solid contribution with clear writing, rigorous experiments, and a sensible methodology. While the reliance on softmax for uncertainty could be discussed in broader context, the experimental insights are noteworthy and likely to benefit the community.

**Confidence**: 4 (Confident but not absolutely certain)  
**Recommendation**: Poster  
**Special Issue**: Yes

God stood atop a massive cloud, overlooking the Earth. The time had finally come for revelations, and man would need to pay for his sin. His white robes, brighter that the brightest light, flapped in the wind, his massive beard stretching down to his waist. A halo sat atop his head, a golden ring of perfection. `` It is time, Lucifer.'' God said to the man standing next to him. The devil looked back at God, smiling. He did n't look how most imagined him. He was an older looking man, thin but fit. He wore a deep blue suit, and a pair of round-framed glasses. 
 
 `` This is what we have been waiting for, Clarence.'' The Devil said. `` I told you never to call me by my name!'' God shouted `` It's God, Lucifer, man you're an ass.'' The Devil smiled, looking back down on the world. `` I finally get the earth, and you get the the true believers.'' The Devil said with a smile. `` My time has finally come.'' 
 
 Macho Man sat atop his throne, leg casually thrown over the side of the arm rest. He wore a yellow and pink skin tight suit with yellow tassels hanging from the arms. His cowboy hat rested atop his head, alternating colors to match. A massive Heavy Weight Champion belt around his waist. `` It's time, ooooh yeeeah.'' he whispered. 
 
 He was surrounded by the best. Hulk Hogan, Andre the Giant, The Honky Tonk Man, Big Boss Man. They had all decided that Macho was the best chance earth had. The WWF was a secret organization going back thousands of years, finding the greatest fighters to fend off the end of time. Macho Man descended the steps, stepping into an ornate ring. The other wrestlers climbed the ropes, standing at the top looking down at him, a look of respect in each mans eye. `` It's time,'' Macho man said. `` the match the whole world, Jupiter, Saturn, Venus... Or anywhere else is waiting for.'' With that, the other wrestlers sent him to Heaven above, each man doing Macho Man's signature elbow drop; his body exploded from the impact. 
 
 God raised his hand, ready to signal to begin. The Angels of war stood ready, the Four Horseman trotting impatiently. The sky flashed above God. He looked up, startled. The WWF had sent their champion. Macho Man Randy Savage exploded out of a burst of light, elbow dropping the Horseman of death in two as he landed. `` We're in space and space is the place!!'' He shouted as death exploded under his elbow. 
 
 `` Who are you?'' God shouted in anger, and perhaps, just perhaps, a hint of fear. 
 `` Best there is... past, present and future! Ohhhhh yeahhhh!'' Macho Man shouted, suplexing one of Gods angels. This force was greater than god had ever seen. Macho man leg dropped Pestilence, his head exploding under Macho Man's boot. Famine turned to run, but was hit with short-arm clothesline, ripping his body in two. `` What right do you have to bring violence into the Kingdom of God!'' God shouted at Macho Man. 
 
 Macho Man smiled, covered in the blood of gods soldiers. `` Expect the unexpected in the kingdom of madness!'' He shouted it return, flipping Famine upside-down, crushing his head in a vicious pile driver. `` Oooooooh Yeeeeeah!'' Macho Man bellowed his battle cry. War raised his sword to strike, but was knocked from his horse from a powerful double slap. War maintained his footing, but was dispatched by a Spinning headlock elbow drop. God and the Devil found themselves alone suddenly. `` Do something, Clarence!'' The Devil shouted in fear. 
 `` My heavenly powers have no effect on him!'' God replied, obviously scared. 
 
 Macho Man lifted the devil above his head. `` The madness is runnin' wild!'' He screamed, shattering the devil with a wicked back-breaker, tossing his body off the cloud to the world below. `` YOU CAN NOT DO THIS!'' God screamed, pointing at Macho Man. Mach Man smiled, shouting `` The tower of power, too sweet to be sour, ohhhh yeahh!'' A massive corner of a wrestling ring began to rise below him, raising him into the sky. `` OOOOOOOOOH YEEEEEEEAH'' He shouted, elbow dropping God off of the cloud, falling to earth faster than anything had before. Flames engulfed God as he screamed, the power of Macho Man being too mighty, even for the creator of Heaven and Earth. Theystruck the ground, a massive shock wave destroying everything within 1000 miles. Macho Man stood, placing Gods halo on his head, the only piece of God that survived the attack. `` What can I say about that move? Nothing so I wo n't.'' he said, ascending to heaven. 
 
 The angels did n't know what to do. God was gone, who would lead them? Who would answer prayers of the people? Who would watch over the world? The Pearly Gates flew open from a powerful kick. Macho Man Randy Savage, God's halo on his head, ascended to the golden throne. He sat, throwing his leg over the edge of the chair. Slim Jims began to rain from the sky. The angels were in awe, since God never let them eat meat. The angels waited for him to speak. 
 
 `` Too hot to handle, too cold to hold! Ten thousand years as Intercontinental Champion, Oooooh yeeeah!'' He said. The angels bowed, and man would live to see another day, under the watchful eye of the Almighty, our Savior, Macho Man Randy Savage.

He looked up, startled as the WWF’s champion descended. Macho Man Randy Savage burst forth from a blinding flash, crashing down upon the rider of Death with a thunderous elbow drop. “We are in space, and space is the place!!” he bellowed as the figure of Death shattered beneath his might.

“Who are you?” God screamed, anger and perhaps a hint of fear lacing His voice. “The best there is… past, present, and future! Ohhhhh yeahhhh!” Macho Man replied with a fierce suplex, sending one of God’s angels sprawling. This power was unlike anything God had ever witnessed. He dispatched Pestilence with a devastating leg drop, the angel’s head exploding under the force of Macho Man’s boot. Hunger attempted to flee but was met with a short-arm clothesline that tore his body in two. “What right do you have to bring violence into the kingdom of God?” God shouted at Macho Man.

Macho Man, drenched in the blood of God’s soldiers, shot back with a grin, “Expect the unexpected in the kingdom of madness!” He turned Hunger upside down, crushing his head with a brutal piledriver. “Oooooooh Yeeeeeah!” Macho Man roared, his battle cry echoing through the heavens. War raised his sword to strike but was knocked off his horse by a powerful double clap. Though he held his ground, he succumbed to a spinning headlock elbow drop.

Suddenly, God and the Devil found themselves isolated. “Do something, Clarence!” the Devil cried, panic creeping into his voice.  
“My heavenly powers are powerless against him!” God confessed, fear evident in His tone.

With a surge of adrenaline, Macho Man hoisted the Devil above his head. “Madness runs wild!” he shouted, executing a vicious backbreaker before hurling the Devil from the cloud to the world below. “YOU CAN’T DO THAT!” God screamed, pointing accusingly at Macho Man. 

Macho Man, unfazed, shouted, “The tower of power, too sweet to be sour, ohhhh yeahh!” As a massive corner of a wrestling ring began to rise beneath him, it propelled him further into the sky. “OOOOOOOOOH YEEEEEEEAH!” he shouted, launching God off the cloud, sending Him plummeting to Earth faster than anything before. Flames engulfed God as He screamed; the power of Macho Man proved too formidable, even for the Creator of heaven and earth. They crashed to the ground, a cataclysmic shockwave obliterating everything within a thousand-mile radius. Rising from the chaos, Macho Man placed God’s halo atop his head—the sole remnant of the Almighty. “What can I say about this move? Nothing, so I won’t,” he declared, ascending into heaven.

The angels stood in bewilderment. With God gone, who would lead them? Who would answer the prayers of humanity? The pearly gates burst open with a resounding kick. Macho Man Randy Savage, halo aglow, ascended to the golden throne. He settled into the seat, casually throwing his leg over the edge. Slim Jims began to rain down from heaven, much to the astonishment of the angels, who had never been allowed to taste meat. They waited in anticipation for him to speak.

“Too hot to handle, too cold to hold! Ten thousand years as intercontinental champion, Oooooh yeeeah!” he proclaimed. The angels bowed, and mankind would live another day under the watchful eye of the Almighty, our savior—Macho Man Randy Savage.

**Double Fatality Investigated by Essex Police Following Gas Leak Call-Out in Leigh-on-Sea**

LEIGH-ON-SEA — The bodies of a man and a woman were discovered Tuesday evening at a residential property on Eastwood Road North, prompting a joint emergency response and an ongoing investigation by Essex Police.

At approximately 6:25 p.m., officers were dispatched to the bungalow following welfare concerns for the two individuals. Emergency services arrived swiftly, but both victims were pronounced dead at the scene. The identities of the deceased have not yet been released, pending formal identification and notification of next of kin.

The incident unfolded after Essex Fire Service received an emergency call reporting a suspected gas leak at the address. Fire crews arrived equipped with specialist detection gear and conducted safety assessments to rule out immediate hazards. While officials confirmed the presence of a gas-related issue, they declined to specify whether it was directly linked to the deaths, citing the active police investigation.

A spokesperson for Essex Police stated that while the circumstances are currently unexplained, the scene has been secured for forensic examination. Detectives from the Major Crime Unit have taken over the inquiry, and a post-mortem examination is scheduled to determine the cause of death. Authorities emphasized that no further updates will be provided until the medical examiner’s findings are available.

Neighbours reported seeing emergency vehicles block off part of the quiet residential street for several hours, with cordons remaining in place well into the night. One resident, who wished to remain anonymous, said, “It’s shocking—this is usually such a peaceful area. There was a real sense of urgency when the fire engine and police cars showed up.”

While police have not classified the incident as suspicious at this stage, they are not treating it as routine. Investigators are reviewing CCTV footage from nearby properties and conducting interviews with potential witnesses.

This tragic event has reignited conversations about household gas safety, particularly in older housing stock common in the Leigh-on-Sea area. The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) reminds homeowners to ensure gas appliances are serviced annually by certified engineers and to install carbon monoxide detectors as a preventative measure.

Further updates are expected once post-mortem results are finalized. Anyone with information relevant to the investigation is urged to contact Essex Police via 101, quoting incident number 582/24.

human: As soon as you feel yourself  against me  you have ceased to understand my position and consequently my arguments! You have to be the victim of the same  passion ! -Nietzsche  Lately I feel like I've lost the point to my existence. (Hold tight. This isn't what you think). I used to know my place. I was the angry, bitter cynic. I hated everything and always had a reason. I could analyze the shit out of anything and tell you exactly why it sucked; and I was right every time. But then, recently, something happened... I grew up. I had grown completely disgusted with my past behavior--my past mindset. But now I've changed, and while it sounds all for the better it's really not. Being the angry guy, I was always one last straw away from flipping my lid and going on a tirade. It was hard being that guy, but at least I knew my place-- at least I knew my friends from my enemies. People either agreed with me and loved me or they disagreed with me and went about their own thing. I was happy with that. There has since been a complete 180º shift in my personality. I really feel like I appreciate everything now. There is hardly a song, movie, book, TV show, radio station, or even a person that I don't like. Where I used to see only the bad in everything, I now see all the good and now I realize that the bad doesn't matter. Why is it worse like this? It's incredibly lonely on this side of the fence. Since my attitude evolved I've realized that I can't talk to anyone anymore. Conversation is the hardest thing in the world because it's almost always based on 'this is great/this is bad.' Too many people hate too many things and I think that's crazy. It doesnt matter how much myself and another person agree on something; something will always come up that they hate and I will not be able to stand such a closed mind. That kind of attitude, I now feel, is incredibly juvenile. I feel like I'm too mature now and I just can't deal with that stuff. I want to be able to share everything that I think is great but I can't do that because no one will let me. Everyone is too judgemental,  too opinionated, too angry, too bitter, to dumb, too naive, and those who aren't too dumb are too blinded by their own narcissism and personal philosophies to see that their own intelligence doesn't matter (not to mention it's not too impressive and not too useful). We all have our specialities, our tallents, our 'fields of expertice.' One must learn, though, to embrace them and nurture them without flaunting them and trying to make others feel subordinated, because they're not, They're just different. (Granted there are some human-trash exceptions). Everyone has got something they do that's better than you, and it pisses you off when they think they're better than you because of it. To you their gift doesn't mean a thing. Superiority complexes seem to run standard issue with everyone anymore.   I am better than none of you.
LLM_1:
Once you feel yourself in opposition to me, you have already ceased to understand my position, and thus you cannot grasp my argument! You must become a victim of the same passion! — Nietzsche

Lately, I feel I’ve lost my sense of purpose. (Don’t worry, it’s not what you think.) I used to know exactly where I stood. I was the angry, bitter cynic. I hated everything, and I always had a reason. I could dissect anything and tell you exactly why it was terrible—and I was right every time. But then, recently, something happened… I grew up. I became utterly disgusted with my past behavior—my past mindset. But now I’ve changed, and though it might sound like everything is getting better, it’s not. As that angry person, I was always just one straw away from exploding into a rant. It was exhausting to be that person, but at least I knew my place—at least I could tell friend from foe. People either agreed with me and liked me, or they opposed me and went their own way. I was fine with that.

Now, my personality has done a complete 180. I genuinely feel like I appreciate everything now. There’s hardly a song, a movie, a book, a TV show, a radio station, or even a person that I dislike. Where I used to see only the bad in things, now I see all the good and realize the bad doesn’t matter. Why is that worse? Because on this side, I feel incredibly alone. Since changing my attitude, I’ve realized I can’t talk to anyone anymore. Conversation has become the hardest thing in the world because it almost always revolves around “this is good/this is bad.” So many people hate so many things, and I find it utterly insane. No matter how much I agree with someone on one thing, there’s always something they despise, and I can’t stand such a closed-minded attitude. Now I feel that kind of mindset is incredibly childish. I feel too mature now to even deal with it. I want to share all the things I find beautiful, but I can’t because no one will allow it. Everyone is too judgmental, too opinionated, too angry, too mean, too stupid, too naive—and those who aren’t stupid are too blinded by their own narcissism and personal philosophies to see that their intelligence doesn’t really matter (let alone that it’s not that impressive or useful). We all have our own specialties, talents, and “areas of expertise.” But we must learn to embrace and nurture them, not flaunt them in an attempt to make others feel inferior—because they aren’t, they’re just different. (Of course, there are exceptions, the occasional asshole.) Everyone is better than you at something, and it’s infuriating when they think that makes them superior. Their talents mean nothing to you. A sense of superiority seems to be everyone’s default setting. I am no better than any of you.
LLM_2:
Once you feel yourself in opposition to me, you have already ceased to understand my position, and thus you cannot grasp my argument! You must become a victim of the same passion!  
— Nietzsche

Lately, I’ve been feeling untethered—adrift without a clear sense of purpose. And before you worry, no, it’s not what you might think.  
There was a time when I knew exactly who I was: the angry cynic, bitter and certain. I saw the world through a lens of contempt, and I could dissect anything—art, people, ideas—and tell you precisely why it was flawed. I was always right, or so I believed. That version of me was perpetually on edge, one straw away from an explosive rant. It was exhausting, but it was also simple. I knew where I stood. Friends were those who agreed with me; foes were everyone else. The lines were clear.

Then, almost without noticing, I grew up.  
The anger gave way to something else—a deep, almost unsettling appreciation for things as they are. Where I once saw only flaws, I now see beauty, effort, meaning. I hardly dislike anything anymore: not a song, a film, a book, nor even most people. The bad no longer overshadows the good; in fact, it often feels irrelevant.

And that’s where the loneliness creeps in.  
Since this shift, conversation has become one of the hardest things in the world. So much of what we talk about revolves around judgment: *this is good, this is bad, I love this, I hate that*. I watch people tie themselves in knots over dislikes, and it strikes me as not just closed-minded, but strangely childish. I want to talk about what moves me, what inspires wonder—but it feels like no one has the space for that. Everyone is so busy judging, opining, defending their own intellectual territory.

It’s not that people aren’t intelligent. Many are bright, even brilliant in their own ways. But so often, that intelligence gets tangled up with narcissism—a need to prove superiority, to turn a talent into a weapon. We all have something we’re good at, something that lights us up. But that doesn’t make us better. It makes us different. And different is beautiful, until we use it to build walls.

I am no better than anyone.  
And maybe that’s the hardest lesson of all—not in theory, but in practice. To stand in a world that constantly ranks and rates, and choose not to play the game. To appreciate without needing to critique, to connect without needing to conquer.

Maybe Nietzsche was right: to understand another, you must first feel what they feel. But what happens when what you feel is a quiet, persistent love for things just as they are—in a world that’s always picking sides?

### When Life Gets Boring, Ice Cream Takes the Spotlight!

When life feels a bit dull and nothing exciting seems to be happening, I often find myself looking at headlines from around the world for inspiration. Well, folks, let me tell you—Japan has delivered some thrilling news: a revolution in sweet treats!

Japan, a country famous for its PlayStation prowess, tentacle-themed pop culture, and karaoke nights, has unveiled a new ice cream flavor that’s sure to tantalize taste buds nationwide. Japanese ice cream aficionados are swapping out traditional favorites like raspberry for something truly unique—horse meat ice cream! 

Now, before you raise an eyebrow, let's take a moment to appreciate this development. It’s fantastic news for all the dinosaurs out there! Sure, I know that dinosaurs and horses never coexisted, but just imagine a world where they did. I can picture it now: horses galloping through lush fields, trying to escape the clutches of hungry dinosaurs. Or perhaps, in a twist of fate, the dinosaurs could have been riding those horses. Who's to say?

This quirky new flavor is being promoted by the Japanese Ice Association, an organization that even organized a summer trade fair. Yes, you heard that right—there are people in Japan whose job is to oversee the ice cream supply! I can only assume they rake in a hefty salary—probably around a million yen a year. Meanwhile, I’m here working my tail off for a fraction of that. 

Now, let’s dive into some pun-tastic commentary about this ice cream. This treat would be perfect for those days when you feel a bit "hoarse!" (Say it out loud, and trust me—it’s hilarious!)

As I wrap up this entry, I can’t help but reflect on my previous article about delayed ghosts. The lack of comments has led me to some amusing conclusions: perhaps my readers are just a tad behind, or maybe everyone has taken a trip to Peru for some questionable kidney deals and are simply too shy to discuss it. Who knows?

Perhaps my recent obsession with making lists has turned readers away. Honestly, I’m feeling a bit worn out, and I can’t shake the feeling that this article hasn’t made the impact I usually strive for. If I were to compare its impact, I’d say it’s akin to the reaction a husband might have upon discovering his wife is pregnant—just enough excitement to get by, but not quite enough to elicit a full-blown celebration.

And let me leave you with an interesting thought of the day: Did you know the famous line, "Every time a bell rings, an angel gets his wings," from *It’s a Wonderful Life* was originally penned as, "Every time a bell rings, an angel gets his wings or a woman decides to try anal for the first time"? This cheeky addition was ultimately cut by director Frank Capra in favor of a more family-friendly ending. Interestingly enough, Jimmy Stewart later wove a version of this line into the film *Harvey*.

So, in light of my previous post's lack of engagement—leading to the unfortunate fate of a puppy (don’t worry, it wasn’t as tragic as it sounds)—I invite you to comment below about anything at all. Your thoughts could inspire my next entry! Or, if you prefer, feel free to [send me an email](urlLink).

Let’s keep the conversation going!

---

**Anti-Dope Efforts Hinge on Russian Compliance**

The international community remains on high alert as Russia's future in global sports hangs in balance. In November, Russia was indefinitely suspended by the World Ant-Dopping Agency (Wada) following a damning report detailing widespread allegations of doping, corruption, bribery, as well as extortion claims. 

As the clock ticks down, Russian officials are scrambling to reform their anti-drug program. I'd served my time. My Emperor. Hanging up my helmet had been the hardest thing I'd ever done, and I had fought on a dozen systems between Alderaan and Hoth. 
 
 That was three years ago. 
 
 There's not much choice for a former-soldier-of-the-empire. Many veterans settled down on a little backwater rock, peddling protection schemes for some fat Hutt. You did n't hear from them much. They lost themselves in a bottle of fire-water, losing their edge until finally they went to collect an easy debt and found themselves with a clean hole punched through their gut. 
 
 I wanted something more. Maybe not a big dream. Definitely not the same kind of pay. But something much more important. I wanted a family. 
 
 I used to be a sergeant, back when I had a squad on Tatooine. Now I was a father to a little boy and girl. The similarities outweighed the differences. My wife, Kessa, was the rock. She dealt with the tantrums, the screams and nightmares; from both the children and myself. 
 
 I'd crashed out. Failed a routine psych-eval. I did n't know why and the autodocs could n't fix whatever it was that had broken. A broken fighter. A broken father. 
 
 Kessa had found me, crying into a towel, leaving the kids to run wild in the dim apartment. She sat beside me. Took my hands away from my face. And kissed me. 
 
 `` There's nothing you can not do,'' she whispered into my ear. 
 
 `` It happened again.'' My composure was shot, but she took my hand. `` I was buying a new astromech. I wanted it to be a surprise. And the sales rep, he points to an R2 unit and I...'' 
 
 I broke down again. 
 
 `` Shh, shh,'' Kessa purred. `` I know.'' 
 
 `` I could n't bring myself to say anything. I just stared at them and I... I started screaming.''
LLM_1:
I had served my time. My Emperor. Hanging up my helmet had been the hardest thing I’d ever done, and I’d fought across a dozen systems between Alderaan and Hoth.

That was three years ago.

There aren’t many options for a former Imperial soldier. A lot of veterans settled on some backwater rock, selling protection rackets to a fat Hutt. You didn’t hear much from them after that. They’d lose themselves in a bottle of firewater, going soft until they finally went to collect an easy debt and ended up with a clean hole punched through their gut.

I wanted something more. Maybe not a grand dream. Certainly not the same kind of paycheck. But something far more important. I wanted a family.

I was a sergeant once, back when I had a squad on Tatooine. Now I was a father to a little boy and a little girl. The similarities outweighed the differences. My wife, Kessa, was the rock. She handled the tantrums, the shouting, the nightmares—from the kids and from me.

I had broken. Failed a routine psych eval. I didn’t know why, and the autodocs couldn’t fix what had shattered. A broken soldier. A broken father.

Kessa found me, crying into a towel, letting the kids run wild in the dark apartment. She sat beside me. Pulled my hands from my face. And kissed me.

“There’s nothing you can’t do,” she whispered in my ear.

“It happened again.” My composure was gone, but she took my hand. “I was buying a new astromech. Wanted it to be a surprise. And the vendor, he shows an R2 unit and I…”

I broke again.

“Shh, shh,” Kessa murmured. “I know.”

“I couldn’t bring myself to say anything. I just stared at them and I… I started screaming.”
LLM_2:
I had done my duty. For my Emperor. Laying down my helmet was the hardest choice I ever made—harder than fighting across a dozen star systems between Alderaan and Hoth.

That was three years past.

Life doesn’t offer much to a soldier who once wore Imperial white. Many veterans end up on some forgotten rock, running protection for a bloated Hutt. After that, they fade from memory. They drown in firewater, grow soft, until one day they go to collect an easy debt and wind up with a blaster hole burned clean through their belly.

I wanted more. Maybe not glory. Definitely not the same kind of credits. But something far heavier. I wanted a family.

Once, I was a sergeant with a squad on the sands of Tatooine. Now I am a father to a small boy and a smaller girl. The parallels run deeper than the contrasts. My wife, Kessa—she is the anchor. She weathers the storms: the tantrums, the shouting, the nightmares—from the children, and from me.

I had shattered. Failed a routine psych eval. I didn’t understand why, and the autodocs couldn’t mend what was fractured inside. A broken soldier. A broken man.

Kessa found me weeping into a towel, the children loose like wild things in the dark of our apartment. She sat beside me. Gently pulled my hands from my face. And kissed me.

“There is nothing you cannot do,” she breathed against my ear.

“It happened again.” My voice was raw, but she held my hand. “I was buying an astromech. Wanted it to be a surprise. The vendor showed me an R2 unit, and I…”

I came apart all over again.

“Shh,” Kessa whispered, her voice a steady tide. “I know.”

“I couldn’t speak. I just stood there, staring… and then I started to scream.”

The paper proposes a pragmatic approach to unifying end-to-end speech-recognition models for whole-utterance and streaming models. Streaming models are defined as not using any future audio, while whole-utterance (or "full context") models can look at the entire audio recording. In short, the paper shows that multi-task training is effective, where each minibatch uses each utterance twice: Once as using the whole-utterance model structure, and once using a modified model structure where all model weights referring to future information are forced to be zero.

The idea is not revolutionary, but it is interesting to see that it works at no loss of accuracy. Interestingly, the results of the proposed multi-task model are actually a little better compared to training distinct models on the two modalities. This is shown to be the case for two end-to-end model architectures, ContextNet and Conformer. The result is of high practical relevance.

I do disagree with the naming "Universal ASR." The word "universal" is, well, quite universal and can refer to many dimensions, such as whole-utterance vs. streaming, distant vs. close talking, wideband vs. narrowband, various domains, various tasks, multi-linguality, etc. While I understand that in today's crowded ML world, one wants to occupy powerful marketing names for ones own work, I strongly believe that they should not be over-stating. For this paper to be acceptable for publication, I believe the authors should tone down the "Universal" moniker, and choose a different name that delineates the dimension more accurately.

Further, I would like to note that although this is supposed to be a double-blind review, the non-blind reference for the internal corpus gives away that this is a Google paper.

**Quality**: The results have been obtained on two quality data sets, one public generally accepted corpus (LibriSpeech), and one Google-internal set of a whopping 413 thousand hours. I consider the results both convincing and of interest to speech-interested members of the ICLR community.

As one feedback point, the paper does not seem to mention a simple and common technique of incorporating at least some future information, by pre-rolling a fixed number of speech frames, e.g. 5, and incorporating those e.g. by stacking or limited-forward looking lower-layer convolution(s) or self-attention. I think it is important that the authors comment on this, since there is still a one-point WER gap due to streaming. To what degree would a simple lookahead like this trade latency for accuracy? Is it possible to build a model that is universal over different numbers of lookahead frames, as to allow for an adaptive lookahead (e.g. pre-roll 0.5 seconds at sentence start, but less later; maybe depending on context such as the words recognized so far)?

As another feedback point, I find the references somewhat Google-heavy. Going through the references from the start, it takes a while to find a non-Google reference. Exaggerated self-referencing that gives the incorrect impression that Google invented everything is not appreciated by all members of the community. I suggest that the authors rebalance, or at least adjust the order. In some cultures, it is considered polite to mention yourself last.

**Clarity**: The paper generally well-written and easily understandable, although I have a few feedback items.

The term "inplace knowledge distillation" is a little confusing. Initially I thought this was done during inference, and was curious how that may be accomplished. However, it is a training-only technique. Please add that to where this introduced ("at training time").

I kindly ask the authors to be more precise in the results table. What is the unit of Latency? I presume ms, but it could also be speech frames. This is not stated, the string "ms" does not occur once. Also, I find it confusing that the table headings for the WER columns are the corpus names, while for latencies, it is the actual meaning of the column ("Latency@X"). So please (1) use WER for these columns, and (2) add units for both, e.g. by saying "WER [%]" and "Latency@50 [ms]". Further, the readability of Tables 3 and 4 could be improved by horizontally aligning the decimal points.

I also kindly ask the authors to have the text proof-read by a native speaker of English, and/or an automated grammar checker which Google certainly has. I noticed a few missing articles.

**Originality**: With the hindsight of having read the paper, the basic idea does not *seem* original at all, but rather straight-forward. The originality of the paper lies in asking the right question, which in this case then naturally leads to the proposed method.

**Significance**: The method allows to reduce the number of models to train by half, which has tremendous practical impact for anyone operating an ASR service. While there is a clear reduction of overhead of model validation and deployment process, it is not clear from the paper whether training the joint model is cheaper than training two individual models (since each utterance is trained twice per minibatch). It would be great if the authors could share that information somewhere.

**Pros**: An interesting paper that provides a simple, well-working solution to a real practical problem, evaluated on a massive real-life corpus.

**Cons**: Some room for improvement of clarity as listed above. Lack of consideration of simple approach of pre-rolling a few frames of speech.

I also kindly ask the authors to have the text reviewed by a native English speaker and/or by an automated grammar checker, which Google undoubtedly possesses. I noticed some missing articles.

**Originality**: With hindsight after reading the paper, the basic idea does not seem original at all, but rather straightforward. The paper's originality lies in formulating the right question, which in this case naturally leads to the proposed method.
