This paper provides finite-sample convergence analysis of TD algorithms in both policy evaluation and optimization, under the average reward setting. Such a setting is basically more challenging than the finite horizon and discount reward settings. The paper can be divided into two quite separate parts. The first part studies policy evaluation with linear function approximations and the second part studies policy optimization (Q-learning) with tabular MDPs.

For the first part, the paper provides a solid analysis of the convergence rate/sample efficiency by showing that the underlying ODE of the solution path has a negative drift and characterizing the error from Markovian noise. The paper shows that the equilibrium of the ODE is the fixed point of the projected Bellman equation and also discussed the case when it is not unique. I did not check the complete proof but believe the analysis route is correct. The properties of the ODE of TD(λ) under the average-reward setting with linear function approximations (Lemma 2) can be a solid contribution to the theoretical foundation of reinforcement learning.

For the second part, it seems the proposed algorithm requires the sample starting from each state-action pair, which implies either a simulator of the environment or extra interactions with the environment are required. For either case, this makes the derived results deviate from the purpose of analyzing the sample efficiency, but only the computational efficiency (under a restrictive setting). Also, I believe Assumption 3 deserves more discussion, e.g., the intuitive reason why it holds and the magnitude of γ with regard to J, |S|, or other quantities of the transition kernel matrix.

Overall, the reviewer believes the results on policy evaluation with linear approximation are nontrivial contributions while the results on Q-learning are not very relevant (to be put in the same paper) and with too restrictive environments. Although both algorithms use TD updates, the parametrizations, proof techniques, and sampling schemes are completely different.
LLM_1:
This work provides a finite-sample convergence analysis of TD algorithms in both policy evaluation and policy optimization under the average-reward setting. This setting is fundamentally more challenging than finite-horizon and discounted-reward settings. The work can be divided into two fairly distinct parts. The first part studies policy evaluation with linear function approximation, and the second part studies policy optimization (Q-learning) with tabular MDPs.

For the first part, the work provides a solid analysis of the convergence rate/sample efficiency by showing that the underlying ODE of the solution trajectory has a negative drift and characterizing the error from the Markovian noise. The work shows that the equilibrium of the ODE is the fixed point of the projected Bellman equation and also discusses the case where it is not unique. I did not check the full proof but believe the analysis path is correct. The ODE properties of TD(λ) under the average-reward setting with linear function approximation (Lemma 2) can constitute a significant contribution to the theoretical foundation of reinforcement learning.

For the second part, it appears that the proposed algorithm requires the sample to start from every state-action pair, which implies that either an environment simulator or additional interactions with the environment are needed. In any case, this makes the resulting results diverge from the purpose of analyzing sample efficiency, but only computational efficiency (under a restrictive setting). Also, I believe Assumption 3 deserves more discussion, e.g., the intuitive reason why it holds and the size of γ relative to J, |S|, or other sizes of the transition kernel matrix.

Overall, the reviewer believes that the results for policy evaluation with linear approximation constitute non-trivial contributions, while the results for Q-learning are not very relevant (to be placed in the same work) and with very restrictive environments. Although both algorithms use TD updates, the parameterizations, proof techniques, and sampling schemes are completely different.
LLM_2:
**Reviewer Comments on the Manuscript**

This manuscript presents a finite-sample convergence analysis of temporal-difference (TD) algorithms in both policy evaluation and policy optimization under the average-reward setting—a setting that is fundamentally more challenging than the finite-horizon and discounted-reward frameworks due to the absence of a natural contraction structure and the need to handle the steady-state distribution. The work is structured into two fairly distinct parts: the first focuses on policy evaluation with linear function approximation, while the second examines policy optimization (specifically Q-learning) in tabular Markov decision processes (MDPs).

**Part I: Policy Evaluation with Linear Function Approximation**  
The analysis in this section is rigorous and provides a solid contribution to the theoretical foundations of reinforcement learning. By framing the solution trajectory through an underlying ordinary differential equation (ODE), the authors effectively demonstrate a negative drift property and carefully characterize the error arising from Markovian noise. A key insight is establishing that the equilibrium of this ODE corresponds to the fixed point of the projected Bellman equation, with additional discussion on cases where uniqueness may not hold. Although the full proof was not verified in detail, the analytical approach appears sound and well-structured. In particular, Lemma 2, which delineates the ODE properties of TD(λ) under average-reward settings with linear approximation, represents a notable advance. This lemma could serve as a cornerstone for future studies in non-contractive reinforcement learning settings, especially in applications such as continuous control or large-scale resource allocation where average-reward criteria are natural.

**Part II: Policy Optimization with Tabular Q-learning**  
The second part of the work, while technically coherent, raises several methodological concerns. The proposed algorithm assumes that samples are collected from every state-action pair, implying reliance on either an environment simulator or extensive additional interactions. This requirement substantially limits the practical applicability of the analysis, as it shifts the focus from *sample efficiency*—a core motivation in modern RL—toward *computational efficiency* under a restrictive sampling regime. Moreover, **Assumption 3** warrants deeper exposition. For instance, the intuitive justification for its validity, along with a discussion of how the parameter γ scales relative to the average cost \( J \), the state space size \( |S| \), or properties of the transition kernel, would strengthen the theoretical grounding. Without such clarification, the assumption may appear somewhat opaque and limit the interpretability of the subsequent bounds.

**Overall Assessment**  
The policy evaluation analysis constitutes a non-trivial and valuable theoretical contribution, advancing our understanding of TD methods in challenging average-reward environments. In contrast, the Q-learning analysis, while competently executed, feels less aligned with the overarching theme of sample-efficient learning. The two segments—though both employing TD updates—diverge significantly in parameterization, proof techniques, and sampling assumptions, giving the impression of two separate studies combined under one title. To enhance cohesion, the authors might consider either integrating the two threads more explicitly or refining the second part to better complement the sample-efficiency narrative established in the first.

**Recommendation**  
This manuscript is recommended for acceptance pending revisions, with an emphasis on clarifying the motivation and practical implications of the Q-learning section and providing a more thorough discussion of key assumptions. The policy evaluation results alone merit publication, but the work would benefit from a more unified presentation.

Although somewhat involved technically and conceptually (the final loss contains 4 different terms), the method is well motivated and easy to follow. The ablations section shows that each term is indeed necessary and leads to large gains in performance. The comparison to prior art is very encouraging, with strong results presented throughout.

In addition to presenting an unsupervised method for part discovery, the authors investigate freeing themselves from supervised pretraining as well. There is indeed a large drop in performance, however this is an important baseline for future research in fully unsupervised part discovery.

One ablation is missing however: the authors define the positive pairs in their contrastive objective as the same part across images, rather than the same part across different views of the same image. How important is this modification? This finding could be useful beyond the specific problem considered here.

In addition to presenting an unsupervised method for part discovery, the authors also investigate how they can free themselves from supervised pretraining. There is indeed a significant drop in performance, but this serves as an important baseline for future research on fully unsupervised part discovery.

However, one ablation is missing: the authors define the positive pairs in their contrastive objective as the same part across images, rather than the same part across different views of the same image. How important is this modification? This insight could be useful beyond the specific problem considered here.
LLM_2:
The proposed method, while technically and conceptually intricate—featuring a final loss composed of four distinct terms—demonstrates clear motivation and is accessible to understand. The ablation studies convincingly illustrate the necessity of each term, highlighting their contributions to substantial performance gains. Furthermore, the results in comparison to the state-of-the-art are quite promising, with consistently strong outcomes reported.

Beyond merely presenting an unsupervised approach for part discovery, the authors also explore the potential to eliminate reliance on supervised pretraining. While there is a notable decline in performance, this observation establishes a critical baseline for future exploration into entirely unsupervised part discovery methods.

Nevertheless, one notable ablation appears to be absent: the authors define positive pairs in their contrastive objective as instances of the same part across different images, rather than as the same part viewed from different angles within the same image. Understanding the significance of this distinction could provide valuable insights that extend beyond the context of the current study.

### Is Anyone Else Frustrated with How the Flyers Are Covered?

Have you ever tuned into a Philadelphia Flyers game on channels like ABC 6 or ESPN? If you have, you probably know exactly what I mean. If not, well, maybe this isn’t for you—just kidding! :) 

I fondly remember watching hockey on ESPN, enjoying the insights from Barry Melrose, Steve Levy, Darren Pang, and Mike Emmerick. However, during the regular season and, especially, in the playoffs, it feels like these so-called 'hockey experts' rarely have anything positive to say about the Flyers. I’m fed up with their constant criticisms, and I’ll use last night’s game as a case in point. They kept praising the Lightning, saying things like, "Their goalie is making unbelievable saves—he’s a Hall of Famer!" This isn’t just a one-off occurrence; it’s been the same story time and again, series after series. If these commentators were to speak about the Flyers with the same enthusiasm they reserve for opposing teams, it would be a game changer. 

I might be a little biased when it comes to other teams, but I certainly don’t lack hearing! The thought of smashing my TV to pieces when Barry and his crew pop into my mind is all too real. Everyone knows that the NHL has had a long-standing obsession with the Flyers since the days of the 'Broad Street Bullies.' This bias extends even to the referees and their questionable calls. 

Next time you catch a Flyers game, pay attention to how many positive comments are directed at the Flyers versus their opponents. You might be taken aback! Here’s a quick list of reasons why their commentary is frustrating: 

1. They often lack a genuine understanding of the team, its players, or the organization yet speak as if they do.
2. They can hardly acknowledge the Flyers’ strengths.
3. Even in a victory, they focus solely on the Flyers’ mistakes.

And trust me, there’s more to this list! The more I think about it, the angrier I get!

human: Considerable evidence suggests regular physical activity can reduce chronic pain symptoms. The dysfunction of endogenous facilitatory and inhibitory systems has been implicated in multiple chronic pain conditions. However, few studies have investigated the relationship between levels of physical activity and descending pain modulatory function.The purpose of this study was to determine whether self-reported levels of physical activity in healthy adults predicted 1) pain sensitivity to heat and cold stimuli, 2) pain facilitatory function as tested by temporal summation (TS) of pain, and 3) pain inhibitory function as tested by conditioned pain modulation (CPM) and offset analgesia.Forty-eight healthy adults (age range = 18-76 yr) completed the International Physical Activity Questionnaire (IPAQ) and the following pain tests: heat pain thresholds, heat pain suprathresholds, cold pressor pain, TS of heat pain, CPM, and offset analgesia. The IPAQ measured levels of walking, moderate, vigorous, and total physical activity over the past 7 d. Hierarchical linear regressions were conducted to determine the relationship between each pain test and self-reported levels of physical activity while controlling for age, sex, and psychological variables.Self-reported total and vigorous physical activity predicted TS and CPM (P < 0.05). Individuals who self-reported more vigorous and total physical activity exhibited reduced TS of pain and greater CPM. The IPAQ measures did not predict any of the other pain measures.
LLM_1: Considerable evidence suggests that regular physical activity can reduce chronic pain symptoms. Dysfunction of endogenous facilitatory and inhibitory systems has been linked to various chronic pain conditions. However, few studies have examined the relationship between the level of physical activity and descending pain modulation function. The aim of this study was to determine whether self-reported physical activity in healthy adults predicts 1) pain sensitivity to heat and cold stimuli, 2) pain facilitatory function, measured by temporal summation (TS) of pain, and 3) pain inhibitory function, tested through conditioned pain modulation (CPM) and offset analgesia. Forty-eight healthy adults (age range = 18–76 years) completed the International Physical Activity Questionnaire (IPAQ) and underwent the following pain tests: heat pain thresholds, heat pain suprathreshold, cold pressor pain, TS of heat pain, CPM, and offset analgesia. The IPAQ assessed the amount of walking, moderate, vigorous, and total physical activity over the past 7 days. Hierarchical linear regressions were performed to determine the relationship between each pain test and self-reported physical activity levels while controlling for age, sex, and psychological variables. Self-reported total and vigorous physical activity predicted TS and CPM (P < 0.05). Individuals reporting more vigorous and total physical activity exhibited reduced TS of pain and stronger CPM. The IPAQ measures did not predict any of the other pain measures.
LLM_2: Evidence indicates that regular physical activity alleviates chronic pain symptoms, which are often associated with dysfunction in endogenous facilitatory and inhibitory systems. However, the relationship between physical activity levels and descending pain modulation remains underexplored. This study investigated whether self-reported physical activity in healthy adults predicts: (1) sensitivity to heat and cold stimuli, (2) pain facilitatory function via temporal summation (TS), and (3) pain inhibitory function via conditioned pain modulation (CPM) and offset analgesia. Forty-eight healthy adults (aged 18–76) completed the International Physical Activity Questionnaire (IPAQ) and underwent pain assessments, including heat pain thresholds, suprathreshold heat pain, cold pressor pain, TS of heat pain, CPM, and offset analgesia. Hierarchical linear regressions, controlling for age, sex, and psychological variables, revealed that higher self-reported total and vigorous physical activity predicted reduced TS and enhanced CPM (\(P < 0.05\)). No associations were found between IPAQ measures and other pain outcomes.

human: Cloninger's Temperament and Character Inventory (TCI) is a widely used measure of personality. Two scales of the TCI, harm avoidance (HA) and self directedness (SD), have been shown to be influenced by depressed mood. We examined how the seven TCI scales and their subscales are correlated with depression severity before and after treatment. We also examined whether changes in personality measures could be attributed to changes in depression severity.Two clinical samples of depressed out-patients were recruited for trials to examine predictors of treatment response to antidepressants (N=195) and psychotherapies (N=177). Assessment included the Montgomery-Asberg depression rating scales (MADRS), Hopkins Symptom Checklist (SCL-90) and TCI at baseline and after treatment.After treatment, in both samples, depression severity correlated significantly with HA and negatively with SD. Multiple regression analysis revealed that changes in SD and HA over treatment were related to improvement in depression. In the psychotherapy trial baseline MADRS scores correlated with low SD and high HA.

LLM_2:
This study investigated the association between personality traits and depression severity in two medical samples (195 depressive outpatient trials for antidepressant treatment and 177 for psychothetherapy). We evaluated the Clominger Temperature and Personality Inventory's (CTI's) seven sub-scale scores, including harm-avoidance (H A)and self-directness(S D), in relation to depression ratings at pre- and-post treatment.

We found significant correlations between cognitive depression deterioration and both H A and S D at partial recovery. Furthermore, multiple regression analysis indicated that improvements in S-D and H-A scores predicted better remittances.

human: Opioids increase spinal release of adenosine in rats, and analgesia from systemic and intrathecal morphine is reduced in animals by adenosine receptor antagonists. We performed 3 studies to determine whether opioid administration also induces adenosine release in humans. To determine the effect of intrathecal opioid exposure, 15 women received intrathecal fentanyl, 50 microg, or saline, and cerebrospinal fluid was sampled at 2-minute intervals for 6 minutes before surgery. In a second study, 8 healthy volunteers received intrathecal morphine, 50 microg, plus fentanyl, 50 microg, with cerebrospinal fluid sampled 20 and 60 minutes later. To determine the effect of intravenous opioid exposure, 9 healthy volunteers received intravenous remifentanil for 60 minutes, and cerebrospinal fluid was sampled before and at the end of the infusion. Adenosine concentrations were similar in the 3 studies before opioid administration. Intrathecal fentanyl or saline did not affect adenosine concentrations during the 6 minutes in the first study. Patients who developed AF had significantly larger total pulmonary vein diameters compared to those maintaining sinus rhythm. Multivariate analysis demonstrated that total pulmonary vein diameter was the sole independent predictor of postoperative AF, suggesting its potential role as a preoperative risk marker in CABG patients.

LLM_2:
**Art Heist Trial Reveals Lax Security and Possible Destruction of Masterpieces**

BUCHAREST — In a case that has exposed glaring security flaws at a major European museum, ringleader Radu Dogaru and his accomplice Eugen Darie have confessed to stealing seven valuable paintings from Rotterdam’s Kunsthal Museum in October 2012. The two men, convicted in absentia of aggravated theft and participation in a criminal organization, detailed to the Bucharest court how they exploited what they described as alarmingly inadequate protections at the institution.

According to their testimony, security at the Kunsthal was “very lax” and “practically nonexistent.” Dogaru claimed he gained entry using only a screwdriver, entering through a rear emergency exit before tearing the artworks—which included pieces by Pablo Picasso, Paul Gauguin, and Henri Matisse—from the walls and fleeing within minutes. The paintings, whose combined value is estimated in the tens of millions of euros, remain missing and are feared destroyed.

Prosecutors told the court that after the heist, Darie concealed the stolen works in pillowcases and transported them to Romania, where the group made several unsuccessful attempts to sell them on the black market. Their efforts eventually drew the attention of an art expert, who alerted authorities and triggered a series of arrests across Romania.

While Dogaru and Darie were ordered to pay 6,000 lei (approximately £1,130) in court costs, the legal proceedings are far from over. Three additional suspects are set to face trial next month, one of whom has already admitted involvement. In a troubling twist, Dogaru’s mother, Olga, is also standing trial, accused of destroying the irreplaceable artworks. She initially told investigators she had burned the paintings in her stove—a claim she later retracted—but forensic experts from the Romanian National History Museum reported finding ash containing remnants of three oil paintings and 19th-century framing nails in her home.

The case has raised serious questions about art security and recovery, highlighting both the vulnerability of cultural treasures and the challenges of prosecuting transnational art crime. As the trial continues, the art world watches closely, hoping for resolution but fearing the worst: that these masterpieces may be lost forever.

LLM_2:
Therefore the current study aimed to bridge the existing knowledge gap in the field by investigating the relationship between various metabolic components and the risk of metabolic syndrome (MS) among a cohort of postmenopausal women in a Taiwanese population.

To this end, we recruited a diverse group of 6,505 apparently health women aged between  51 and seventy years who underwent routine medical checkups at designated disease-detection centers across Taiwan, as part of the country's national health screening program. Our participants had normal fasting glucose (FPG) levels, ensuring that our findings would be relevant to a population at risk for developing MS. In addition to FPG, our study measured a range of physiological parameters, including waist circumferences (W), trigylcerides (TG), systole and dia stolic (SD) blood pressures, body-mass index(BMI), and percentage body fats (PB) to gain a comprehensive understanding of our participants' metabolic profiles.

Upon analyzing our data,we sub-categorized our subjects into three distinct groups based on their FGP levels (< 90 mg/dl,91 -95 mg /dL, > 97 mg/ dl for groups 3,2 and1 respectively) and found that participants in groups three and two had an alarmingly high risk (121 times, p= 0,017 and,123 times,p=0007) respectively of developing metabolic syndromes compared to those belonging to group one.

Moreover, a series of statistical analyses revealed significant correlations between age,waist circumfernce, Body mass Index, Percentage body Fat, Systolic and Diastoloc Blood pressure and total Cholesterol with the FFP levels. Interestingly, HDLC (high-density Lipoproteins) was found to be negatively associated wth FPP levels.

Our investigation also utilized a Multivariate Stepwise Regression analysis to identify independent risk factors for FFG. This analysis revealed that PB (percentage body Fats), LDL (Low-density Cholesterols), Triglyceride, age and BMI were all significantly and independently correlated to increased risk. These findings suggest that in addition, to age-related changes and increased body weight, metabolic risk also plays a critical role in determining the likelihood of MS in post-menopausl women. Further studies are warranted to explore these associations in greater depth and to inform evidence-based interventions aimed at mitigating the impact of these risk factor on MS incidence. By shedding new light on the complex interplay between metabolic health and MS risk, this study has significant implications for clinical practice and public health policy.

LLM_2:
He'd known he's be there, as he always was, week in and week out. But he had a mission, one he couldn't shirk: find him before _they_ did, save him if possible. Amidst the bustling market crowd, his eyes darted about, taking in every stall and vendor. It was a good thing the place was swarming with people; that would only make their task more difficult, harder even for himself. Still, with intimate knowledge of their haunts and hideaways, gleaned from countless encounters, their quarry's odds of success looked grim. A merchant called out to him in an attempt to lure him to a bargain, a siren's song that could have led him astray, had he not remained resolute. Meanwhile, in tandem, another part of his being listened, attuned to that unmistakable voice.

His gaze swept across the stalls as his heart beat out a warning, _she_ was growing agitated, her frustration evident in her every step. Just as the sound of her voice reached his straining ears, like a lifeline tossed his way, it dawned on him that they'd been trailing him. By now, predictably, that led them directly to _her_. His footsteps quickened, driven by a growing sense of urgency. Reaching _him_ a mere instant before his pursuers, I could almost see the look of relief on his face.

"We have no time to lose," he urged, tugging on her hand. "They're closing in."

The scene unfolded like this: It had all started like any ordinary day, amidst the vibrant market stalls, where she reveled in discovering new treasures and marveling at their wares. Her eyes danced from stall to stall, drinking in all the colors and textures, each one more captivating than the last. Every week, without fail, this was her favorite haunt, never knowing what wonders awaited her discovery. And it wasn't just the merchandise that drew her in – the people, too. Each vendor was unique, offering stories of far-off lands or homegrown tales of local legends. Inevitably, some of these items were priced competitively at neighboring stalls. So, naturally, there was no rush. Taking her leisurely time, browsing, shopping – she relished every moment spent amidst this kaleidoscope of commerce.

But then, suddenly, an unfamiliar voice joined the cacophony. “We have _to_ leave, now! _He's_ here."

Her eyes locked onto the stranger, who stood transfixed beside him – an unspoken understanding flashed between them. Then, together, following the man's lead, both parties took their leave of that marketplace. Glancing back at some enticing collated wovens, for just an instant, then grasped hands in a tight, desperate grip, slipping through a sea of oblivious shoppers, just trying not to fall behind.

This study investigated the blood-pressure sensitivity dynamics of aortocarotoid arterial compliance in normotesive pregnancy. We hypothesized that alterations in baro-reflex sensitivity correlate with increased stiffness of arterial walls. 

To test this hypothesis, we collected data from 34 pregnant women (23 during trimesters T¹-T³, 11 post-partum) using an ultrasonic wall tracking system. Aorto-carotidal arterial distendibility was quantified by measuring the diatolic end-diameter and pulse wave amplitude, with the resultant distention coefficient calculated as a surrogate marker of vascular compliance. Baro-relex sensitiviy was assessed through analysis of spontaneous fluctuations in systoic blood presure and heart rate.

Notably, our results revealed a significant reduction in distenibility coefficients (from 5.1± 1.9 to 3.7±1.8 mmH g, p<0.05) alongside decreased bar-o-refex sensitivity (decreasing from - 2.2 ± 4.3 to -13.5 ±6. 8, P < 0.05), indicating compromised vascular adaptability throughout pregnancy progression to post-parteum. These findings suggest a potential link between decreased vascular disteniibility and altered bar-ref-ex responsiveness in pregnancy-related vascular remodeling. However, further research is required to elucidate the underlying mechanisms. (

LLM_2:
**A Body in the Pajamas: A Japanese Mystery That Haunts the Imagination**

Sometimes, a news snippet is so strange, so hauntingly incomplete, that it doesn’t just report an event—it opens a door into the dark corners of human emotion. Such is the case with a chilling story out of Tokyo, originally covered by CNN: police discovered the decomposing remains of a man dressed in pajamas inside an abandoned apartment building. He had likely been dead for *twenty years*.

The man, identified only as a former employee of the company that constructed the building, reportedly divorced and moved into the vacant complex in the early 1980s—then simply vanished from sight. Decades later, his bones were unearthed, still clad in fabric softness, like a ghost who never made it to bed. His remains have since been returned to his ex-wife.

And that’s where the facts end.

But the story? The *real* story? That’s just beginning.

Now, let your mind wander—because this is one of those rare moments when reality blurs with fiction, and we’re left to fill in the silence between the lines.

Imagine you're a woman in Japan, where family isn't just important—it's sacred. Blood ties bind generations. Honor, duty, memory—all flow through the quiet rituals of home. Your husband leaves. You divorce. Maybe he walked out coldly, suitcase in hand. Maybe there was shouting. Or maybe he just… disappeared. No goodbye. No closure.

Twenty years pass.

In that time, you raise children—*his* children. You care for aging parents, yours and perhaps even his. You endure the whispers, the questions unasked: *Where is he? Why didn’t he come back? Did he forget us?*

And now, two decades later, authorities knock on your door. They hand you a box—or perhaps arrange for a funeral. The man who abandoned you is finally confirmed dead. Not missing. Not estranged. *Gone.* Reduced to bones in a forgotten room, dressed like he was settling in for a nap that never ended.

How do you feel?

Relief? Grief? Indifference? Vengeance?

Or worse—what if *you* know more than you’re saying?

Was it anger that drove you to silence him forever? Did you visit that empty building one night with a heavy heart and heavier hands? Is there a part of you that smiles now—not because he’s dead, but because the world found him like *this*: alone, undignified, wrapped in cotton pajamas while time ate him alive?

Or maybe your relief is simpler, more practical. With a death certificate comes closure—and insurance money. A payout long denied, finally unlocked by rot and bone.

Or perhaps—you didn’t even notice he was gone.

That might be the most tragic twist of all.

This isn’t just a crime scene. It’s a mirror. We project onto it every fear, every unanswered question about love, loss, and what happens when someone slips out of life without looking back.

I can’t help but think of Paul Harvey—the legendary broadcaster famous for ending his segments with “And now… the rest of the story.” If anyone could peel back the layers of this mystery, it would’ve been him.

But he’s gone too.

So we’re left with silence. And a man in pajamas. And a woman somewhere in Tokyo, holding ashes or secrets—or both.

The truth may never surface.

But the story? Oh, the story lingers.

human:
### Summary:

This paper proposes a variational inference based framework to tune some of the hyper-parameters of HMC algorithms automatically. The authors drop the entropy term from regular ELBO formulation, which facilitates a gradient-based approach. However, dropping this term requires extra care for which authors offer an automated-method. Finally, the authors demonstrate empirical validation on several problems.

### Strength:

The authors do an excellent job of articulating their intuition behind the idea both (see section 3.) While dropping the entropy term from ELBO decomposition is heuristic-based, the explanations are well-formulated, and Figure 1 does an excellent job of getting the point across. 

More so, since dropping the entropy term can cause pathological behaviors, the authors propose a method to ensure wider initial distributions. I commend the authors for the non-trivial engineering that was required to make their ideas work. I also, commend the author's effort of conducting statistical tests and extensive empirical evaluations. 

### Concerns:

My main concern with the work is that it is often on-par with the competing methods--I understand that a new method doesn't need to be SOTA on every benchmark--and the SKSD enabled variants that achieve this performance are prohibitively slow (see Tables 6 and 9.) I could not help but feel concerned when no discussion was offered for an almost tenfold increase in the computational time for training DLGMs. To convince me, I will suggest offering an honest discussion on the run-times of the approaches.

I find the discussion in section B.1important, and believe it should be more formal.  Specifically, I will suggest algorithimizing what objective is used at which stage. Alternatively, authors can choose to restructure this some other way; however, it is too important to be left in its current form. 

### Updates after the rebuttal

I like the paper and found the revised version more transparent. I support the engineering approach of the paper; however, as we all know, these papers often require authors to go to greater lengths to convince. After reading the other discussion and reviews, I think the authors can consider a few additional experiments. I would suggest investing in a more involved toy-experiment to better motivate the engineering solutions. If possible, authors can also consider a more careful ablation study to establish the relevance of each component on this toy-model. Further, the authors offered explanations for the training time aberrations; if possible, authors can consider including the equally-fast-variants in the revision to be more convincing.
LLM_1:
### Abstract:

This paper proposes a variational inference-based framework for automatically tuning certain hyperparameters of the HMC algorithm. The authors remove the entropy term from the conventional ELBO formulation, which facilitates gradient-based methods. However, removing this term requires additional care, for which the authors provide an automated approach. Finally, the authors conduct empirical validation on several problems.

### Strengths:

The authors do an excellent job of explaining the intuition behind their ideas (see Section 3). Although removing the entropy term from the ELBO decomposition is heuristic, the explanation is clear, and Figure 1 excels in conveying the point.

More importantly, since removing the entropy term may lead to pathological behavior, the authors propose a method to ensure a broader initial distribution. I appreciate the non-trivial engineering effort the authors have invested to realize their ideas. I also commend the authors for conducting statistical tests and extensive empirical evaluations.

### Concerns:

My main concern with this work is that its performance is generally comparable to competing methods—I understand that a new method does not need to be optimal in every benchmark—while the SKSD variant achieving this performance is extremely slow computationally (see Tables 6 and 9). I cannot help but be concerned when the authors do not discuss the nearly tenfold increase in computation time during DLGM training. To convince me, I suggest the authors provide a candid discussion of the method's runtime.

I believe the discussion in Section B.1 is important and should be made more formal. Specifically, I recommend explicitly stating the objective function used at each stage of the algorithm. Alternatively, the authors could choose to restructure this section in another way; but in its current form, it is too important to remain as is.

### Updates After Rebuttal:

I like this paper and think the revised version is more transparent. I support the engineering approach of the paper; however, it is well-known that such papers often require more effort from the authors to convince readers. After reading other discussions and reviews, I believe the authors could consider conducting some additional experiments. I suggest designing a more in-depth toy experiment to better motivate the engineering solutions. If possible, the authors could also consider a more careful ablation study to determine the relevance of each component in a toy model. Additionally, the authors have explained the training time anomalies; if possible, the authors could include a variant with comparable speed in the revision to be more persuasive.
LLM_2:
### **Abstract:**

This paper introduces a novel variational inference-based framework designed to automate the tuning of specific hyperparameters within the Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (HMC) algorithm. The authors propose a key modification to the conventional Evidence Lower Bound (ELBO) by omitting the entropy term, thereby enabling more straightforward gradient-based optimization. This adjustment, while heuristic, is carefully addressed through an automated mechanism to mitigate potential pathological behaviors, such as overly narrow initial distributions. The framework is empirically validated across a range of benchmark problems, demonstrating its practical applicability.

### **Strengths:**

The authors provide an exceptionally clear and intuitive exposition of their methodological contributions, particularly in Section 3. Although the removal of the entropy term from the ELBO is presented as a heuristic choice, the rationale is well-articulated and supported by an effective visual aid in Figure 1, which greatly aids in conveying the core idea.

A significant strength lies in the authors’ proactive approach to addressing the potential pitfalls of their heuristic—specifically, the risk of pathological behavior due to entropy removal. They introduce a systematic method to ensure a sufficiently broad initial distribution, reflecting considerable and non-trivial engineering ingenuity. Furthermore, the paper is commendable for its rigorous empirical validation, including comprehensive statistical testing and extensive benchmarking across multiple datasets, which substantiates the robustness of the proposed approach.

### **Concerns:**

My primary concern centers on the computational trade-offs associated with the proposed method. While the performance of the framework is generally on par with existing state-of-the-art techniques—and it is understood that a novel method need not outperform all benchmarks—the specific variant based on Kernel Stein Discrepancy (SKSD) incurs a substantial computational overhead. As evidenced in Tables 6 and 9, the SKSD variant is notably slower, particularly during DLGM training, where runtime increases nearly tenfold. This significant computational cost is not adequately discussed in the main text. To strengthen the paper, I recommend that the authors include a candid and detailed analysis of runtime efficiency, perhaps comparing wall-clock times or FLOP counts across methods, to provide a clearer picture of the practical trade-offs.

Additionally, the discussion in Section B.1, while insightful, would benefit from a more formal and structured presentation. Specifically, I suggest that the authors explicitly define the objective function at each algorithmic stage, or consider reorganizing the section to enhance clarity. Given the importance of this methodological detail, its current informal presentation may hinder reproducibility and full understanding.

### **Updates After Rebuttal:**

I find the revised version of the paper to be more transparent and well-argued, and I continue to support its engineering-oriented contributions. That said, papers in this vein often require additional effort to convincingly demonstrate utility and robustness. In light of feedback from other reviewers, I believe the authors could further strengthen the manuscript with some targeted additional experiments. For instance, designing a more nuanced toy experiment could help better motivate the engineering solutions and illustrate their necessity. A careful ablation study on a simplified model would also be valuable to disentangle the contribution of each component. Finally, regarding the computational concerns, while the authors have explained the training time anomalies, including a runtime-optimized variant in the revision—or a direct comparison with a speed-competitive baseline—would make the case for the method’s practicality more persuasive.

The authors study strategic voting in the context of iterative plurality voting, in which voters may update their plurality votes over multiple rounds of voting. They study the additive dynamic price of anarchy (ADPoA), and show that in the worst-case, ADPoA can be linear in the number of agents, but for the case of impartial culture, equilibrium winners actually have a constant order advantage over the truthful winner, which is an instance of social welfare benefit due to strategic manipulation. 

I found this paper to be well-written and interesting -- I haven't seen many results that demonstrate that (in some settings) strategic manipulation can result in a strict increase in overall social welfare. The first theoretical result, which shows that the ADPoA can be linear in the number of agents in the worst case, was not too surprising and used relatively standard techniques, but is still a nice result that shows considerable separation from the second impartial culture result.

Speaking of that result, I would have liked to see a bit more intuition given about why this unintuitive result arises. Is it because there isn't much imbalance in impartial cultures, and allowing people to perturb their votes a bit will naturally help? I found the proof, which cases on the cardinality of W, a bit lacking in intuition here. (All I got is that the gain whenever there are two potential winners offsets the small losses whenever there are more than two potential winners.)

I also think this paper would benefit from a simulation section in which the authors could explore a range of randomized / average-case settings with mixtures that are not just uniform (impartial culture). It would be very interesting to see how robust the theoretical result for impartial culture is as the culture becomes less impartial (i.e., more imbalanced). Is the degradation in benefit smooth in some other parameter? Does strategic behavior also help when the process is simulated on (approximately) real-world data?

Footnote 1: if one exists
255: results combine

---

The authors investigate strategic voting within the framework of iterative plurality voting, where voters can adjust their plurality votes across multiple rounds. They delve into the additive dynamic price of anarchy (ADPoA), revealing that, in the worst-case scenario, the ADPoA may scale linearly with the number of agents. However, in the context of an impartial culture, they demonstrate that the equilibrium winners possess a constant order advantage over the truthful winner, highlighting a case where strategic manipulation can enhance social welfare.

I found this paper to be both well-articulated and engaging; it is noteworthy to see results indicating that, in certain situations, strategic manipulation can lead to a measurable increase in overall social welfare. The initial theoretical finding, which establishes that the ADPoA can be linear in terms of the number of agents in the worst case, was somewhat expected and utilized conventional techniques. Nonetheless, this result is significant, as it illustrates a considerable distinction from the subsequent findings related to impartial culture.

Regarding that particular result, I would appreciate additional insight into the mechanisms behind this counterintuitive outcome. Is it a matter of minimal imbalance within impartial cultures, where slight perturbations in voting can yield advantages? I found the proof, which relies on the cardinality of W, to be somewhat lacking in intuitive explanation. The only aspect I grasped was that the gains associated with scenarios featuring two potential winners offset the minor losses that occur when more than two candidates are in contention.

Furthermore, I believe the paper would greatly benefit from the inclusion of a simulation section. This could allow the authors to examine a variety of random or average-case scenarios that extend beyond just uniform (impartial) cultures. It would be particularly intriguing to assess the robustness of the theoretical findings in the context of less impartial (i.e., more unbalanced) cultures. Is the decline in benefits gradual across other parameters? Additionally, does strategic behavior continue to provide advantages when simulating outcomes with (approximately) real-world data?

This submission deals with text generation. It proposes a sequence level objective, motivated by optimal transport, which is used as a regularizer to the (more standard) MLE. The goal is to complement MLE by allowing `soft matches` between different tokens with similar meanings. Empirical evaluation shows that the proposed technique improves over baselines on many sequence prediction tasks. I found this paper well motivated and a nice read. I would vote for acceptance.

Pros:
- A well-motivated and interesting method.
- Solid empirical results.
- Writing is clear.

Cons:
- The split of `syntax--MLE` and `semantics--OT` seems a bit awkward to me. Matching the exact tokens does not appear syntax to me. 
- Some technical details need to be clarified.

Details:
- Could the authors comment on the efficiency by using the IPOT approximate algorithm, e.g., how much speed-up can one get? I'm not familiar with this algorithm, but is there convergence guarantee or one has to set some kind of maximum iterations when applying it in this model?

- Bottom of page 4, the `Complementary MLE loss paragraph`. I thought the OT loss is used as a regularizer, from the introduction. If the paper claims MLE is actually used as the complements, evidence showing that the OT loss works reasonably well on its own without including log loss, which I think is not included in the experiments.

- I really like the analysis presented in Section 3. But it's a bit hard for me to follow, and additional clarification might be needed.

- It would be interesting to see whether the `soft-copying` version of OT-loss can be combined with the copy mechanisms based on attention weights.

================================

Thanks for the clarification and revision! It addressed some of my concerns. I would stick to the current rating, and vote for an acceptance.

The objective is to complement MLE by allowing "soft matches" between different tokens with similar meanings. Empirical evaluation shows that the proposed technique improves upon the baselines in many sequence prediction tasks. I found this paper well-motivated and pleasant to read. I would vote in favor of its acceptance.

Pros:

- The writing is clear.

Cons:

Details:

- At the end of page 4, in the paragraph about "complementary MLE loss." I thought that the OT loss is used as a regularizer, according to the introduction. If the paper claims that MLE is actually used as a complement, evidence is needed to show that the OT loss works reasonably well on its own without including the logarithmic loss, which I believe is not included in the experiments.

- I really like the analysis presented in Section 3. But I find it a bit difficult to follow and additional clarification may be necessary.

- It would be interesting to see if the "soft copying" version of the OT loss can be combined with weight-based attention copying mechanisms.

================================

Thank you for the clarification and the review! You addressed some of my concerns. I would maintain the current rating and vote in favor of acceptance.
LLM_2:
---

This presentation focuses on the topic of text generation and introduces a sequence-level objective inspired by optimal transport. This objective serves as a regularizer for Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE), which is the more conventional approach. The key innovation here is the incorporation of "soft matches" between tokens that share similar meanings, thereby enhancing the MLE framework. The empirical results indicate that this technique outperforms baseline methods across various sequence prediction tasks. Overall, I found the paper to be well-justified and engaging, and I would support its acceptance.

**Pros:**
- The method presented is both compelling and well-justified.
- The empirical findings are robust and convincing.
- The clarity of the writing is commendable.

**Cons:**
- The distinction made between "syntax--MLE" and "semantics--OT" appears somewhat clumsy, as exact token matching does not strictly align with syntactic considerations.
- Certain technical aspects require further elucidation.

**Details:**
- I would appreciate it if the authors could elaborate on the efficiency of the approximate IPOT algorithm. Specifically, what level of speedup can be expected? While I am not well-versed in this algorithm, is there a convergence guarantee, or should we establish a maximum number of iterations when utilizing it in this context?

- In the paragraph at the end of page 4 about "complementary MLE loss," I was under the impression that the OT loss functions as a regularizer, as stated in the introduction. If the paper asserts that MLE is indeed utilized as a complement, it would be beneficial to provide evidence demonstrating that the OT loss is effective on its own, without relying on the logarithmic loss, which I believe was not included in the experimental results.

- I greatly appreciate the analysis found in Section 3; however, I found it somewhat challenging to follow and would suggest that additional clarification could enhance its accessibility.

- It would be intriguing to explore whether the "soft copying" variant of the OT loss can be integrated with weight-based attention copying mechanisms.

---

Thank you for your thoughtful review; you have addressed several of my concerns. I would maintain my current rating and support acceptance.

 The Gray World

Wrapped in black robes, Death slowly raised his hand, beckoning Jack towards him. Jack looked at this dark being, then turned his gaze to the hills and valleys stretching miles below—a vast expanse that seemed to pulse with a life of its own, painted in the muted hues of autumn. The air was thick with the scent of damp earth and decaying leaves, a reminder of the cyclical nature of existence. "So, this is the afterlife," Jack said aloud, his voice echoing softly in the stillness, a fragile sound against the weight of eternity. 

Death, with his arm extended, pulled aside his dark cloak, revealing the face of a wise old man with dark eyes that held the depth of countless souls and flowing white hair that cascaded like a waterfall of memories. "I take you for your judgment; you must follow me," he intoned, his voice resonating like the tolling of a distant bell, solemn and final. Jack looked around once more in the dim autumn light, taking in the serene beauty of this strange realm, where the boundaries between the living and the departed blurred like a dream at dawn. 

He reached out to touch this being who called himself Death, feeling the chill radiating from his figure. To his surprise, he realized he was holding an envelope in his hand, its weight both familiar and foreign. Upon seeing this strange envelope, Death's eyebrows raised in intrigue, and he spoke again, slowly, as though weighing each word. 

"Is that a letter?" asked Death, his voice laced with an unexpected curiosity. Jack turned the envelope, examining it under the muted light. It was sealed with a wax emblem he did not recognize, bearing an intricate design of interwoven vines and skulls, and addressed to:  
**Angel of Death**  
**c/o Jack Tatum**  
**The Grey World**

Jack extended it again, hoping that Death would take it, feeling a strange thrill of anticipation coursing through him. Slowly, Death reached out once more, his fingers brushing against Jack’s as he took the envelope, his eyebrows still raised in bemusement. Jack watched intently as this enigmatic being opened the envelope with a deliberate grace, unfolding the letter within as if it were a sacred text. The envelope fell to the ground, forgotten, as Death immersed himself in the words. "Wonderful, the Angel of Death throws away trash," Jack murmured to himself, a wry smile tugging at his lips, and waited, his heart racing with a mix of trepidation and intrigue.

The Angel of Death, seemingly unfazed by Jack's comment, directed his gaze at him, handing back the letter with a slight shake, murmuring, "Take it."

Please return to our office immediately and see Jenny, Secretary of the Underworld, who will have your severance package waiting. In the package, you will find the usual policies including a Compensation and Benefits Plan for Angels for two thousand years. Thank you for your attention to this matter." The words felt like a punch to the gut, heavy with finality, as Jack struggled to comprehend the implications of what he was reading. 

Beneath the signature, there was a scrawled addition: "p.s. Please deliver Jack Tatum directly to our office; he will be the new Angel of Death." 

Confused and upset, Jack looked at the Angel of Death before him, whose wise eyes now glimmered with a hint of mischief, and expressed the only thought he could formulate, barely able to mask his incredulity: "Don't you have email in the afterlife?" 

The question hung between them, echoing with absurdity in the stillness of that otherworldly space, as Jack grappled with the surreal nature of his situation—the weight of a new title pressing upon him like a shroud, and the absurdity of bureaucratic processes continuing even in the realm beyond life.

LLM_2:
The Dean of the College of Cardinals, commonly referred to as the Cardinal Dean, holds a prestigious status as the primus inter pares, or "first among equals," within the College of Cardinals. This position is not simply ceremonial; it carries significant responsibilities and influence within the Roman Catholic Church. The election of the Cardinal Dean is conducted by the Cardinal Bishops, who are bishops of suburban sees, and they select one of their own to serve in this esteemed role. However, this election is not final until it receives the approval of the Pope, underscoring the hierarchical structure and the vital connection between the College of Cardinals and the papacy. 

Historically, the office of the Dean was automatically bestowed upon the longest-serving Cardinal Bishop, ensuring continuity and experience at the helm of the College. This tradition, while it emphasized seniority, has evolved to incorporate a democratic process that reflects the changing dynamics of church governance. The Dean plays a crucial role in various functions, such as presiding over meetings of the College and representing the College at official events, which can include significant Church ceremonies and interfaith dialogues. 

Moreover, the Cardinal Dean often acts as a key adviser to the Pope, providing insights on the needs and perspectives of the cardinals, who, as senior leaders of the Church, play a vital role in shaping church policies and addressing contemporary issues. This position not only influences ecclesiastical matters but also engages in broader discussions regarding the Church's role in society, especially in light of modern challenges such as secularization, social justice, and global crises. Thus, the Cardinal Dean serves as a bridge between the historical traditions of the Church and its evolving mission in the contemporary world, navigating the complexities of faith, leadership, and community.

LLM_2:
**A Bittersweet Encounter**

As I returned to my internship at [hospital name], I couldn't help but think about one patient in particular. His name was Pappu Chhab, a kind-hearted man with an infectious smile. At 6 feet tall and 22 stone, his physical presence was imposing, yet his warm demeanor made him impossible to forget. I first met him during my rounds, when I would occasionally glance at our patient files. What struck me was not his size, although that did play a role, nor was it his medical condition – itwas his unwavering optimism and zest for life.

Over the last three days, Pappy Chhaw andI formed a bond, talking extensively about his upcoming surgery. Despite his fear,he showed remarkable courage, readyto face whatever lay ahead. Our conversations often turned to lighter topics, like what our surgeons might say abouthis size! As the moment of truth approached,we shared a brief, reassuring conversation. Before the anesthesia took hold, hewished me a heartfelt 'Thank you, Ben.' 

The surgery progressed smoothly until the monitors began beaming loudly. We discovered the issue was with the equipment, not Papy Chha's health. But it soon became clear that all hope was lost. Those dreaded words echoed through the OR: "'time-of-death at3.58 PM!" My heart sank as I gazed at Paby Chaw's lifelessness. Even after everyone left, i couldn’t help myself, as the reality of what had just happened slowly set in.

"I just met this man a day ago," I kept repeating to myself. Why did I feel such a deep connection to someone I'd known for such as short time? Maybe I wanted him around a little longer, maybe because I felt I could learn something from his resilience. Or maybe it’s just the compassion and empathy that every human should have. As I reflected on our encounter, one thing was clear – Pavy Chawa was an exceptional person who left a lasting impression.

Rest in peace, dear Pappa Chav. May your legacy live on, inspiring those who had the privilege of knowing you. Thanks for the memories, sir. P.S. To all my friends and family, your kind words mean the world to us. Thank you for being there.

human:
**Expressivity of the model**
Can you formally argue why using a model with high-dimensional hidden states, but a low-dimensional kernel, is not equivalent to a model with lower-dimensional hidden states? It's definitely not clear why the machinery of this paper is necessary, when the hidden state size is a hyperparameter that the user could decrease if computational complexity was an issue. If they're not formally equivalent, they still strike me as similar in terms of expressivity (which is supported by your experiments).


**Training**
There are far too few details regarding how the models are trained. I'm assuming you used EM. This is very dependent on initialization in practice. How did you do it?


**Computational Complexity**
With modern hardware, big-O analysis may not be helpful because certain operations can be done in parallel. For example, for O(L N^2) inference, the cost is sequential in L, but parallelizable in N. Also, for certain ranges of N, the cost of matrix multiplication on a GPU is more or less constant. 


The right panel of fig 1 should be in log space. Does it give the slope we expect? 

**Results**
I expected to see much more of an analysis of an accuracy-speed tradeoff. However, besides the HMM experiments, all other results only consider accuracy. In terms of accuracy, I could not find a convincing result demonstrating that using LHMM vs. HMM or LPFCG vs. PCFG gave a meaningful performance improvement. 


Overall, I am confused why much of the analysis sweeps over the number of hidden states. Shouldn't this just be a hyper-parameter that gets tuned for each model? For example, figure 1 would be much more clear if it was collapsed into a single scatter plot of PPL vs. speed. 


**Related Work**
I found a few important related papers. Can you comment on the relationship between your proposed method and these works?

Thai et al., "Embedded-State Latent Conditional Random Fields for Sequence Labeling" 

McAuley et al., "Exploiting Data-Independence for Fast Belief-Propagation"

Belanger et al., "MAP Inference in Chains using Column Generation"


**After authors' response**
Score raised from weak reject to weak accept.
LLM_1:
**Model Expressiveness**  
Can you formally justify why using a model with high-dimensional hidden states but a low-dimensional core is not equivalent to a model with low-dimensional hidden states? It is by no means clear why the mechanisms in this work are necessary if the size of the hidden state is a hyperparameter that users could reduce if computational complexity becomes an issue. Even if they are not formally equivalent, they still appear similar in expressive power (as supported by your experiments).

**Training**  
There are far too few details on how the models were trained. I assume you used EM. In practice, this heavily depends on initialization. How was it performed?

**Computational Complexity**  
With modern hardware, a Big-O analysis might not be helpful, as certain operations can be parallelized. For example, the O(L N²) inference cost is sequential in L but parallelizable in N. Moreover, for certain ranges of N, matrix multiplication cost on a GPU is more or less constant.

The right panel of Figure 1 should be plotted on a logarithmic scale. Does it show the expected slope?

**Results**  
I would have expected a much more comprehensive analysis of the trade-off between accuracy and speed. Aside from the HMM experiments, all other results consider only accuracy. Regarding accuracy, I could not find a convincing result showing that using LHMM over HMM or LPFCG over PCFG leads to significant performance improvement.

Overall, I do not understand why most of the analysis ignores the number of hidden states. Shouldn't this simply be a hyperparameter optimized for each model? For instance, Figure 1 would be significantly clearer if reduced to a single scatter plot of PPL versus speed.

**Related Work**  
I found several important related works. Can you explain the relationship between your proposed method and these works?

Thai et al., "Embedded-State Latent Conditional Random Fields for Sequence Labeling"

McAuley et al., "Exploiting Data-Independence for Fast Belief-Propagation"

Belanger et al., "MAP Inference in Chains using Column Generation"

**After Authors' Response**  
The rating was increased from weak reject to weak accept.
LLM_2:
The tone remains respectful while clearly articulating concerns and suggestions for improvement.

---

### **Model Expressiveness**

The claim that a model with high-dimensional hidden states but a low-dimensional core offers fundamentally different capabilities—rather than merely serving as an implementation choice—requires formal justification. At present, it is not evident why such an architectural design is necessary or advantageous compared to simply using a model with intrinsically low-dimensional hidden states. While the two may not be formally equivalent, their expressive power appears comparable based on the experimental results presented. If model size is treated as a tunable hyperparameter, one could reasonably expect similar performance from a conventional low-dimensional model when appropriately optimized. A more rigorous theoretical analysis clarifying the representational advantages of the proposed architecture would strengthen the contribution.

### **Training Methodology**

Insufficient details are provided regarding the training procedure. It is assumed that the Expectation-Maximization (EM) algorithm was employed; however, EM is known to be sensitive to initialization, particularly in latent-variable models. The manuscript does not specify how initialization was performed, nor does it discuss strategies to mitigate convergence to poor local optima. Clarification on these aspects—such as the initialization scheme, convergence criteria, and potential use of multiple restarts or regularization techniques—is essential for reproducibility and assessment of the method’s robustness.

### **Computational Complexity Analysis**

While the Big-O complexity analysis provides some insight into scalability, its practical relevance may be limited given modern computational architectures. For instance, the stated inference cost of $ O(LN^2) $ is sequential in sequence length $ L $, but operations across the state space of size $ N $ can often be parallelized effectively on GPUs. Furthermore, matrix multiplication performance on hardware accelerators tends to exhibit sub-linear or even near-constant runtime behavior over certain ranges of $ N $. Therefore, empirical timing measurements under realistic conditions would provide more meaningful insights than asymptotic bounds alone.

Additionally, the right panel of Figure 1 should be plotted on a logarithmic scale to better reveal scaling trends. When visualized this way, does the curve exhibit the theoretically expected slope? This would help validate whether the observed runtimes align with the claimed complexity.

### **Results and Evaluation**

A more comprehensive evaluation of the accuracy–efficiency trade-off is warranted. With the exception of the HMM comparison, the reported results focus almost exclusively on accuracy, without adequately addressing computational cost. Given the central motivation of improving efficiency, this omission is notable. Moreover, the evidence supporting significant performance gains—such as reduced perplexity or improved labeling accuracy—from LHMM over standard HMM, or LPFCG over PCFG—is not compelling. In several cases, improvements appear marginal, raising questions about the practical significance of the proposed models.

More broadly, the role of the number of hidden states is underexplored throughout the analysis. Since this quantity directly affects both capacity and computation, it should be treated as a key hyperparameter subject to optimization for each baseline and proposed model. For example, Figure 1 could be substantially clarified by collapsing the comparisons into a single scatter plot showing perplexity versus inference speed, with points representing different configurations (including varying numbers of hidden states), thereby enabling direct visualization of the Pareto frontier.

### **Related Work**

Several relevant works appear to have been overlooked in the discussion. Specifically:

- Thai et al., *"Embedded-State Latent Conditional Random Fields for Sequence Labeling"*, propose structured models with factored latent representations, which bear conceptual similarity to the low-rank parameterization used here.
- McAuley et al., *"Exploiting Data-Independence for Fast Belief-Propagation"*, explore computational optimizations in graphical models through decomposition strategies akin to those leveraged in the current approach.
- Belanger et al., *"MAP Inference in Chains using Column Generation"*, introduce scalable inference techniques for chain-structured models via dynamic programming enhancements.

A clear articulation of how the present method differs from or improves upon these prior approaches would strengthen the positioning of the work within the existing literature.

---

### **After Authors' Response**

Following the authors’ response, several concerns were addressed satisfactorily, particularly regarding clarification of model assumptions and additional context on training procedures. While some theoretical and empirical questions remain open, the revised submission presents a clearer picture of the method's contributions. As a result, I have upgraded my recommendation from **weak reject** to **weak accept**.

Sir Maurice was the designer and creator of Edsac, a computer that ran its first program in May 1949.
The Cambridge machine was the first widely-useable stored program machine and was very influential on the nascent British computer industry.
It set standards for how computers should be used in academia and business that have lasted until the present day.
Following work on developing radar during World War II, Sir Maurice returned to Cambridge to begin designing the machine that would become Edsac.
Prior to the war he had studied mathematics at Cambridge and been heavily involved with the rather limited calculating machines used in the department.
Study of the design documents for what would become the US Edvac machine convinced him that computers were the future and he started the project to build one at Cambridge.
His efforts were helped by a trip to the US to attend a series of lectures, known as the Moore School, run by the American scientists who had built the pioneering Eniac computer and were working on its successor Edvac.
"Maurice Wilkes was the first to turn these ideas into a fully-functional electronic stored-program computer when the Cambridge Edsac ran its first program in May 1949," said computer historian Professor Simon Lavington.
Unlike earlier machines such as the Manchester Mark I which were largely experimental, Sir Maurice wanted to put his computer to practical use.
"The Edsac group was the most influential of the early British computing teams," said Prof Lavington, "most especially in setting high standards for the development of software and the organisation of a computing service to scientists and engineers."
The success of Edsac caught the attention of catering firm J Lyons which funded further development of the machine and led to the creation of the Leo - one of the first machines put to dedicated business use.
Innovations at the Cambridge computer laboratory, such as microprogramming and time-sharing, were widely influential in the industry at large.
"If any person deserves the title of the father of British computing, it is surely Professor Sir Maurice Wilkes," said Prof Lavington.

LLM_2:
**Sir Maurice Wilkes and the Dawn of British Computing: How Edsac Shaped a Technological Era**

In May 1949, a quiet but revolutionary moment in technological history unfolded at the University of Cambridge: the Electronic Delay Storage Automatic Calculator, or Edsac, executed its first program under the guidance of Sir Maurice Wilkes. This milestone marked more than just a technical achievement—it heralded the arrival of the world’s first widely usable stored-program computer, a machine that would lay the foundation for modern computing in both science and industry.

Edsac was not merely an academic curiosity. Unlike earlier experimental machines such as the Manchester Mark I, which primarily served as proof-of-concept models, Wilkes designed Edsac with practical application in mind. His vision was clear—to build a reliable, programmable computer that could serve real-world scientific and engineering needs. The result was a machine that ran its initial program flawlessly, calculating a table of squares, and quickly became an indispensable tool for researchers across disciplines, from physics to biology.

The influence of Edsac extended far beyond the walls of the Cambridge Computer Laboratory. It established rigorous standards for software development—practices such as structured programming, debugging techniques, and subroutine libraries—that are now considered foundational in computer science. The Edsac team also pioneered one of the earliest forms of organized computing services, offering computational support to scientists who lacked technical expertise in machine operation. This model became a blueprint for future university and industrial computing centers.

Wilkes’ journey to this breakthrough began during World War II, where he contributed to radar research—a field that exposed him to cutting-edge electronics and advanced problem-solving under pressure. After the war, he returned to Cambridge, where he had previously studied mathematics and worked with rudimentary mechanical calculators in the university’s Mathematical Laboratory. It was during this period that he encountered the seminal *First Draft of a Report on the EDVAC*, a document authored by John von Neumann that outlined the architecture for a stored-program computer. Recognizing its transformative potential, Wilkes resolved to bring this concept to life in Britain.

His determination was bolstered by a pivotal trip to the United States in 1946, where he attended the Moore School Lectures—a landmark series hosted by the University of Pennsylvania. There, he met the engineers behind the Eniac, the world’s first general-purpose electronic computer, and learned firsthand about the ongoing development of its successor, the Edvac. Armed with detailed technical insights and inspired by American innovation, Wilkes returned to Cambridge with a clear roadmap.

What set Edsac apart was not only its technological sophistication but also its accessibility. The machine used mercury delay lines for memory storage and operated with a modest 32-bit word length, yet it was remarkably stable and user-focused. Its success soon attracted attention from unexpected quarters—most notably J. Lyons & Co., a forward-thinking catering and bakery firm seeking ways to streamline its complex business operations. Impressed by Edsac’s capabilities, Lyons funded further development and ultimately commissioned Leo (Lyons Electronic Office), the world’s first computer dedicated to commercial data processing. The launch of Leo in 1951 revolutionized business computing, handling tasks like payroll, inventory, and supply chain logistics with unprecedented speed and accuracy.

Meanwhile, innovations continued to emerge from the Cambridge lab. Wilkes and his colleagues introduced microprogramming—a method of using software-like instructions to control hardware operations—which became a standard technique in processor design for decades. They also explored time-sharing systems, enabling multiple users to interact with a single computer simultaneously—an early precursor to modern cloud computing and multi-user networks.

Historians regard the Edsac project as the catalyst for Britain’s postwar computing boom. “Maurice Wilkes was the first to turn theoretical ideas into a fully functional electronic stored-program computer,” said Professor Simon Lavington, a leading authority on early computing. “The Edsac group was the most influential of the early British computing teams, particularly in establishing high standards for software development and organizing a computing service for scientists and engineers.”

By bridging theory and practice, Wilkes helped transform computing from a niche engineering pursuit into a vital tool for scientific discovery and economic progress. His legacy endures not only in the machines that followed but in the very culture of computing—where usability, reliability, and service remain paramount.

“If there is one person who deserves the title of father of British computing,” Lavington concluded, “it is certainly Professor Sir Maurice Wilkes.”

The paper proposes a Siamese network model for mapping the space of natural compounds to a latent representation space; furthermore, it utilizes this representation to compute a similarity score between an already known compound and a newly discovered one.

Some comments:
- Comparison with LDA requires more details: have you used the same number of topics for both small and large datasets? How are you training it?
- Page 4 the definition of micro-averaging is missing: 'Micro-averaging for precision and recall is formally defined as: '
- Figure 3 does not show a well defined clusters of various compound families because it’s using same color for different families in some cases (according to the caption of Figure 3). I wonder if you can somehow show for which compound families the colors have been repeated or maybe show fewer compound families.

The problem of finding similar compounds to a novel compound from NMR spectra is an interesting applied problem; however, technical novelty of the paper is not significant. Given the level of technical novelty, I believe the paper is more suitable for a more applied conference/journal in the fields of chemistry or bioengineering.
