MEDIA – COVERAGE OF MILITARY CONFLICT   Decapitation as propaganda tool   Islamic militants record brutal murders and publish them online to gain media coverage. There has been an evolution in terrorists’ exploitation of images to announce and dramatize their killings. Decapitation has been widely adopted by Muslim radicals to kill enemies in recent conflicts in Algeria, Bosnia, and Chechnya, experts said. But the killers of Wall Street Journal journalist Daniel Pearl in Pakistan in 2002, Pennsylvania businessman Nick Berg in Iraq on May 11, and aerospace engineer Paul Johnson in Saudi Arabia on Friday transformed the act into propaganda by using digital cameras to record the spectacle. On Friday, chilling images were posted online for a global audience, including Westerners for whom decapitation is particularly shocking. The SITE Institute—a Washington-based organization tracking terrorist groups—located Friday an Arabic statement about Johnson’s murder accompanied by gruesome crime photos on a newly created website using Yahoo!’s free Geocities service. SITE analyst Josh Devon said: "Terrorism doesn’t work unless the media gets involved. Shooting someone isn’t necessarily terrorism. Decapitating someone and posting it online is terrorism." In Pearl’s case, recordings of the murder were delivered to the U.S. consulate in Karachi. They were only later posted online and partially aired by CBS News. The video of Berg’s murder was immediately published online, sparking waves of grief and outrage. Johnson’s killers managed to attract even more attention by announcing on their website Tuesday that he would be killed within 72 hours if their demands weren’t met. "Here we had the countdown: this guy was alive, but we knew he was doomed as the 72-hour clock ticked down," said Robert Thompson, media and culture expert at Syracuse University in New York. The combination of ritual murder with digital communications "is this strange collision of worlds." He said the internet holds powerful appeal for terrorist groups because it allows instant, international distribution for groups otherwise unable to spread their message through traditional media. He said terrorist groups have been astute enough to recognize only the most violent and graphic events will gain attention. "You can’t put anything on the internet and expect people to pay attention," he said. "I can think of few things besides a decapitation capable of singularly focusing people’s attention." Marc Sageman, former CIA officer and author of Understanding Terror Networks, said militants in Algeria, Chechnya, and Bosnia had widely used decapitation. "It has become the ritual way to sacrifice infidels," he said. "That’s how you sacrifice animals, so I suppose it’s a way of saying infidels are no better than animals." Although decapitation ceased long ago in the West, the Saudi government still uses it to execute men and occasionally women for serious crimes, including religious crimes like blasphemy. The government’s chief executioner, Muhammad Saad al-Beshi, gave several media interviews last year, boasting his sword is "very sharp. People are surprised at how quickly it can sever a head from the body."

Source: LAT-WP, June 4

COLOMBIA – DRUGS   Colombian drug traffickers establish cocaine supply bases in the Balkans   Colombian drug trafficking clans have established bases in the Balkans to penetrate Eastern Europe, said Antonio Maria Costa, head of the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime, on Friday. "We discovered Colombian drug trafficking bases in the Balkans, particularly in Albania," he noted. They are promoting Colombian cocaine into Eastern Europe, Russia, and Ukraine. According to Antonio Maria Costa, Colombian cocaine previously reached Europe via Spain. However, Asia, mainly Afghanistan, remains the primary source of cocaine and heroin for Europe. Meanwhile, the UN report on cocaine production in Colombia, Peru, and Bolivia indicates illegal coca cultivation declined by 20% in these countries. In total, 200,000 families live from coca cultivation in Colombia, Peru, and Bolivia, the report continues. According to UN experts, large illegal military units in Colombia initiate cocaine production in the Andes.

Source: RIA Novosti, June 4  
Compiled by: Mikhail Belyat

BOTSWANA – GEOSTRATEGIC   The San want their day in Botswana’s court   The fate of one of southern Africa’s oldest nomadic tribes, the San or Bushmen, may be decided when Botswana’s High Court hears arguments on ancestral land rights. The judicial case, beginning July 5 with an on-site inspection, could determine the future of Gana and Gwi Bushmen communities. Two hundred forty-eight Bushmen and adult Bakgalagadi are suing the Botswana government, including President Festus Mogae, over forced eviction of themselves and their families from ancestral lands, in what could be a landmark case for Bushmen rights across southern Africa. The on-site inspection should visit settlements from which it is alleged the San were forcibly removed from the Central Kalahari Game Reserve to settlements outside the reserve. 'Expected to become farmers overnight'  

The Bushmen want the government to recognize their right to return to their lands and live there without fear of further evictions, and to hunt and gather freely. The original case on forced removal from ancestral lands was dismissed on a technicality in April 2002. However, the Bushmen appealed and won the right for the case to be reheard on its merits. The Botswana government initially apparently ended all services, including water, claiming it couldn’t afford the 55,000 Botswana pula monthly cost. The first wave of removals occurred in 1997, and most of the community has since been relocated to settlements outside the park. In exchange for their traditional hunter-gatherer existence, the Botswana government claims title deeds to plots, mere 40 by 40 meters, have been granted in a conservation area—the Central Kalahari Game Reserve—roughly the size of Belgium. It is also alleged displaced people were given goats and cattle. "People up to 80 years old or more who have been hunter-gatherers their whole lives were expected to become farmers overnight," said a South African spokesman for the plaintiffs Monday. But Botswana’s actions have drawn strong opposition from Survival International, a British organization supporting tribal communities and their rights to their lands and self-determination. The organization has led a global awareness campaign; organizing petitions worldwide against San displacement and even suggesting diamond prospecting might be behind the relocation. Survival International also accuses Botswana authorities of harassing the San, saying they have been "tortured, beaten, or arrested for allegedly hunting excessively or without proper licenses." The Botswana government has emphatically denied these accusations, as well as that diamond prospecting was behind the displacement.

Source: Sapa, June 4

FOCUS   GEOSTRATEGIC – INTERNATIONAL   Some lessons from nations that won the war against terrorism   At the Human Rights Observatory in Algiers, Algeria’s capital, a visitor observes a chart showing the course of nearly a decade of terrorist war waged in the name of Islam. The chart does not show victim numbers. For years, varying figures have circulated. In 1994, the Interior Ministry cited 11,000. In 1996, socialist opposition leader Hocine Ait-Ahmed estimated nearly half a million dead. In 1999, presidential candidate Abdel-Aziz Bouteflika placed the number at "over 100,000." My estimate, based on information gathered from many sources since 1994, produces a figure of around 28,000. But we still need years of meticulous research to establish full facts. More precise information exists on the number and frequency of terrorist attacks. The chart mentioned above shows attacks peaked between 1994 and 1996. At one point in 1995, various terrorist groups could launch up to 30 more or less simultaneous attacks daily. In some cases, terrorists killed hundreds in a single day, a record achieved in the massacre of about 500 people in Ben-Talha village. In March 1994, visiting Algiers, it was difficult to avoid the impression that the Algerian state was on the verge of collapse and terrorists would soon triumphantly enter the capital to seize power. The nation had suffered human and material losses on the scale of a conventional war. Damage to its economic and administrative infrastructure caused by terrorists amounted to billions of dollars. Thousands of municipal buildings, schools, clinics, libraries, and private homes had been destroyed. Dozens of villages had become deserts, their inhabitants expelled or massacred. By 1996, however, the tide began turning against the terrorists, and within a year it was clear Algeria was no longer in mortal danger. By 1999, Algeria had won its war against terrorism. A similar story could be told of Peru, the Latin American nation most affected by terrorist war. At one point, the main terrorist organization known as Shining Path could attack anywhere and anytime it wished. For nearly two decades, the terrorist war claimed at least 30,000 lives, mostly civilians. By taking control of much of the illicit narcotics trade, terrorist groups gained access to an almost endless source of money to finance their campaign. Yet by 1999, Peru also appeared to emerge from its ordeal. With Shining Path driven from its hideouts and its leadership imprisoned, the Peruvian state could reaffirm its authority even in the deepest jungle interiors. Algeria and Peru are not the only nations that have faced and defeated modern terrorism. Egypt and Turkey have had similar experiences with exceptionally brutal terrorist movements. Today, at least 22 countries are affected by terrorism in one form or another. In some, like India, Philippines, Thailand, and Myanmar, the state has managed to contain the terrorist threat without fully defeating it. In others, like Uzbekistan, Pakistan, and Afghanistan, terrorism has turned into a low-intensity war that could continue for years. Elsewhere, like in Colombia, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Ivory Coast, and Uganda, terrorist groups have organized into mini-armies controlling vast territories and threatening central governments. But all these experiences reveal one important fact: no terrorist movement in the past two decades has succeeded in overthrowing a state and seizing power. This contrasts with earlier decades, when several terrorist movements, often disguised as revolutionary guerrilla movements, came to power on waves of violence. How did Algeria, Peru, and other nations that defeated terrorism manage it amid great difficulties? The question interests recent terrorism victims, including Saudi Arabia. While Algerian, Peruvian, and other experiences in fighting terrorism show important differences, they all share several key characteristics. The first is psychological determination by governing elites to stay the course. A central terrorist objective, of course, is to instill fear in society generally and elites in particular. By refusing to be afraid, societies and their leaders achieve their first victory against terrorists. Of course, this is easier said than done. In Algeria, for example, terrorists launched a campaign of assassinations targeting teachers and university students, especially girls. Dozens were killed, mostly by throat-slitting. The immediate effect was dramatic. More than half of Algiers University students stopped attending for weeks and months. By 1995, however, authorities had provided sufficient security to persuade students and teachers to return. This remained a daily act of courage by tens of thousands of young people willing to risk their lives but refusing to let terrorists shut down universities. In both Peru and Algeria, authorities initially grouped key system personalities into fortified neighborhoods to protect them from assassination attempts. But they soon realized this aided terrorists. Terrorists, using only a few men for surveillance, could track the movements of all key individuals to and from a small area. This gave them fixed targets while they themselves enjoyed maximum mobility. Terrorists achieved spectacular successes killing many prominent figures. Dozens of ministers, governors, mayors, union leaders, political party figures, and prominent media men and women were killed in Peru and Algeria. In Algeria, they even assassinated the head of state. Subsequently, both countries decided to widely disperse their key personnel, beyond terrorists’ ability to organize surveillance operations leading to assassinations. The second lesson is understanding the difference in pace and tempo between terrorist organizations and state security forces. The terrorist can almost always run 100 meters faster than their state adversaries. Their goal is to achieve big, rapid victories through a few spectacular operations. State security forces, on the other hand, must prepare to drag the terrorist into a marathon race. They need to slow things down as much as possible and ensure even the most spectacular attacks fail to produce desired terrorist outcomes. The third lesson is the strategy of forcing terrorists into fixed positions before attacking them. The terrorist constantly seeks anonymity, like a fish in water. But they also need safe havens, hospitals, recreational centers, places to hide larger weapons, and facilities to train recruits or imprison potential deserters. All this means a loss of mobility, which is the terrorist’s key advantage over the state. In both Algeria and Peru, and to some extent also in Turkey and Egypt, the state deliberately decided to help terrorists become fixed targets. In Algeria, for example, anti-terrorist units deliberately stayed out of certain areas, notably the Mitidja plain and Blida city, thereby driving terrorists there. At times, security forces even refused to intervene to stop terrorist operations happening right under their noses, so to speak. The idea was to convince terrorists they had a safe haven. Over time, this meant terrorists became fixed targets while security forces enjoyed the advantages of mobility and choosing the moment of attack. Counterterrorism experts know the fourth lesson as "the onion principle." It means treating terrorist organizations as bodies made of numerous layers. The classical counterterrorism method seeks the core of the "onion" hoping to eliminate it. But in both Peru and Algeria, it soon became clear it was more efficient to deal first with outer layers. These outer layers provide funding, information, surveillance, espionage, and various logistical support to core groups. Thus, disrupting or destroying these layers would directly impact core group efficiency. Dealing with the outer layer is also important because it offers opportunities for disinformation campaigns and, more importantly, infiltration. This method was used most successfully in Egypt, where authorities managed to infiltrate virtually all terrorist groups, sometimes reaching the highest levels of their leadership.

# **You Will Pay: Apartheid-Era Victims Take Legal Battle to U.S. Courts**

In a dramatic escalation of the long-running quest for justice by apartheid survivors, six South Africans—including Dorothy Molefi, mother of the iconic Hector Pieterson—are suing the South African government and some of the world’s most powerful corporations for a staggering $20 billion (roughly 140 billion rands). The case, filed in the U.S. District Court in New York on Saturday, marks one of the boldest legal moves yet in the global campaign to hold both state and corporate actors accountable for complicity in systemic human rights abuses during South Africa’s decades of racial oppression.

At a press conference on Monday, American attorney Ed Fagan—no stranger to high-stakes reparations litigation—laid out the core allegations with unflinching clarity. The lawsuit demands $10 billion in damages from multinational companies accused of being “strategic partners” of the apartheid regime, engaging in what Fagan described as “genocide, expropriation, and other illegal acts.” An additional $10 billion is sought from President Thabo Mbeki’s post-apartheid administration, not for perpetrating violence, but for failing to protect victims and allegedly enabling continued exploitation by allowing these corporations to operate without redress.

“This is not a game,” Fagan warned. “It has legal foundation. It has legal precedent. If our allegations are true, you will pay.”

Fagan, who gained international prominence in 1998 by securing a landmark $1.2 billion settlement from Swiss banks on behalf of Holocaust survivors, is no stranger to controversy. His tactics often draw criticism—from skeptics who accuse him of exploiting vulnerable communities to fellow lawyers who question his methods. Yet there’s no denying the symbolic power of bringing this case to American soil, where courts have increasingly become arenas for transnational justice claims.

The defendants include heavyweights like Anglo American and Goldfields, mining giants whose operations were deeply entwined with the apartheid economy; IBM, whose punch-card technology helped administer racial classification; Swiss banking titan UBS; and Sasol, the South African energy conglomerate. These corporations, Fagan argues, didn’t merely profit from apartheid—they enabled it.

But perhaps the most controversial aspect of the suit is its targeting of the current South African government. While many expected the post-1994 democratic state to be a champion of victims’ rights, Fagan accuses it of complicity through inaction. He alleges that the Mbeki administration has colluded with corporate interests, effectively shielding them from accountability while leaving survivors destitute.

“The post-apartheid government had an obligation to protect its people,” Fagan said. “Instead, it allowed industry to continue violating their rights—with full knowledge and without intervention.”

The plaintiffs seek to deposit any awarded funds into a “humanitarian fund,” intended to support education, healthcare, and community development for those still suffering the intergenerational trauma of apartheid. This would mirror models used in other reparations cases, where compensation serves not just individual restitution but broader societal healing.

Among the plaintiffs is Dorothy Molefi, whose son Hector became a symbol of resistance when he was shot dead at age 13 during the 1976 Soweto uprising. The image of his lifeless body being carried by two teenagers—captured in a photograph that shocked the world—remains seared into global consciousness. That moment wasn’t just about one boy’s death; it represented the violent suppression of an entire generation’s cry for dignity and equality.

Yet more than three decades later, many ask: What has truly changed for families like Molefi’s?

While South Africa transitioned peacefully to democracy, economic transformation has lagged far behind political change. For millions of Black South Africans, poverty, unemployment, and lack of access to land and opportunity persist—echoes of a system that devalued their lives.

And now, as this lawsuit unfolds thousands of miles away in New York, questions arise about sovereignty, legitimacy, and the limits of justice.

South African officials have pushed back hard. Bheki Khumalo, spokesperson for President Mbeki, dismissed the suit with a firm message: *“South African matters should be settled in South Africa.”* He expressed confidence in the government’s legal position, stating they would defend themselves vigorously—but also emphasized that many of the named companies are now key players in national development.

Mbeki himself has previously criticized efforts to litigate apartheid-era crimes abroad, arguing that such actions undermine reconciliation and deter investment. There's also tension within the legal community: Fagan was reportedly excluded from a prior class-action lawsuit representing apartheid victims in the U.S., a move he denies, claiming instead that he "stepped aside" after disagreements with South African co-counsels.

Critics, including civic organizations, warn that Fagan’s history of raising hopes among impoverished claimants—only to see settlements stall or disappear—raises ethical concerns. Could this case become another example of grand promises and little delivery?

Still, supporters argue that when domestic mechanisms fail, international avenues must remain open. After all, South Africa’s Truth and Reconciliation Commission, while historic, offered amnesty in exchange for testimony—not financial reparations. Many victims received nothing beyond acknowledgment.

As the clock ticks toward Fagan’s self-imposed two-week deadline for the South African government to respond to an undisclosed “proposal,” the world watches closely. Will diplomacy prevail? Or will this evolve into a protracted legal battle that forces uncomfortable truths into the courtroom spotlight?

One thing is certain: the ghosts of apartheid are not resting quietly. And for survivors like Dorothy Molefi, justice delayed is justice denied—no matter which court hears their plea.

---

# **Syria Fires Back: A Legislative Slap Against U.S. Sanctions**

In a bold act of legislative defiance, Syria is crafting its own retaliatory law aimed squarely at American interests—a direct response to Washington’s tightening economic screws over alleged support for terrorism.

More than 130 members of Syria’s 250-seat parliament have drafted the so-called *American Accountability Act*, a bill designed to impose “strict sanctions” on U.S. commercial activities within Syrian borders. The move comes less than a month after President George W. Bush expanded restrictions under the existing *Syrian Accountability Act*, banning nearly all U.S. exports to Syria except food and medicine, and grounding Syrian flights to and from America.

The parliamentary statement, faxed to The Associated Press in Damascus, framed the new legislation as a matter of national dignity. “We’re not naive enough to believe we can hurt the massive American economy,” admitted Muhammad Habash, a moderate Islamic-affiliated lawmaker and one of the bill’s chief architects. “But we can maintain our dignity and slap Americans in the face so they know—if they keep their arrogant policies, people worldwide will spit at them.”

It’s rhetoric laced with symbolism, but beneath the fiery words lies a calculated political strategy. With trade between the two nations totaling just $300 million annually, Syria knows its economic leverage is limited. Still, even small measures can carry outsized meaning.

Lawmakers suggest the sanctions could include a partial boycott of American products—everything from soft drinks to software—though not a total cutoff. Some hardliners have called for a complete commercial freeze, but others caution against cutting off vital sectors. As Suleiman Haddad, another MP, put it: “We believe there is still a thread between us and the United States.”

That thread remains fragile. Several U.S. companies continue operating in Syria, including firms involved in oil exploration. Just last year, Syria signed agreements worth $34 million with American energy companies—an irony not lost on observers given Washington’s stance on terrorism financing.

The bill is set for a vote on June 27, with Foreign Minister Farouk al-Shara scheduled to present the government’s justification. Passage is expected by a wide margin. Once approved, it will go to President Bashar al-Assad for ratification.

While details of the proposed sanctions remain vague, the intent is clear: if Washington wants to play the sanction game, Damascus won’t stand idly by.

---

# **Blood in the North Caucasus: Militants Seize Control in Ingushetia**

Chaos erupted in the Russian republic of Ingushetia this week as armed Chechen and Ingush militants launched a coordinated assault on government buildings, killing dozens and briefly seizing control of key towns near the volatile border with Chechnya.

Late Monday, attackers wielding grenades and rocket launchers stormed the Interior Ministry building in Nazran, the region’s capital. Simultaneously, police stations in Ordzhonikidzevskaya and Karabulak were overrun. Witnesses reported seeing bodies strewn across the streets—estimates range from 30 to over 50 dead, including senior security personnel.

Among the confirmed fatalities was Ingush Interior Minister Murad Kostoev, a high-profile target whose death signals a major blow to Moscow’s authority in the region.

The attacks followed warnings from Chechen separatist leader Aslan Maskhadov, who told Radio Liberty last week that rebel forces were shifting tactics. “Before, we focused on sabotage,” he said. “Now, we plan active military actions.”

That shift became terrifyingly real when a crew from Russia’s NTV network encountered the militants at a checkpoint. “Stop. Hands on the hood,” a gunman ordered. When they identified themselves as journalists, the fighter stepped back, then declared: “Say we are the Martyrs Brigade… We’ve killed everyone here. Go and announce it.”

By dawn on June 22, the militants had withdrawn—but not before demonstrating their ability to strike deep into Russian-controlled territory with precision and impunity.

This wasn’t just an attack. It was a declaration: despite years of counterinsurgency campaigns, the flame of resistance in the North Caucasus still burns.

---

# **Annan Sounds Alarm: Anti-Semitism on the Rise Again**

UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan delivered a powerful rebuke to rising anti-Semitism in a historic address Monday, calling the resurgence of hatred against Jews “alarming” and demanding urgent action from member states.

Speaking at the first-ever UN seminar dedicated solely to anti-Semitism, Annan opened with a standing ovation—and closed with a challenge.

“When we seek justice for Palestinians—as we must—we must reject anyone who uses that cause to incite hatred against Jews,” he said. “Sixty years after the Holocaust, how can we allow this poison to return?”

He urged the adoption of a resolution condemning anti-Semitism, similar to one passed by the OSCE in April, and called on the Human Rights Commission to investigate anti-Jewish discrimination with the same rigor applied to Islamophobia.

Nobel laureate Elie Wiesel, speaking as keynote guest, reflected on the illusion that anti-Semitism died in Auschwitz. “Only Jews perished there,” he said. “But the hatred survived.”

Jewish leaders praised Annan’s candor, though some demanded more concrete steps—like appointing a special envoy and issuing annual reports. Others criticized the UN itself for double standards, pointing to repeated resolutions targeting Israel while ignoring state-sponsored anti-Semitism in parts of the Arab world.

Still, many agreed: this speech marked a turning point. “It’s the best one could hope for,” said Felice Gaer of the American Jewish Committee. “Frank. Unique. Long overdue.”

---

# **Iran Detains British Sailors in Escalating Naval Standoff**

Tensions flared in the Shatt al-Arab waterway as Iran seized three Royal Navy vessels and eight sailors, cutting off communication and sparking fears of a diplomatic crisis.

According to Iranian Revolutionary Guard sources, the boats entered Iranian territorial waters without permission. They were escorted to shore, and crew members arrested after weapons and maps were found onboard. One Iranian broadcaster claimed the sailors confessed to a navigational error.

But analysts suspect a deeper motive. “Iran is making a point,” said Sky News foreign editor Tim Marshall. “‘Back off.’” With ongoing pressure over its nuclear program, Tehran may be using the incident as leverage.

The Royal Navy regularly patrols the disputed waterway to prevent smuggling—but crossing into Iranian waters, even accidentally, carries serious risks.

Britain has launched an investigation, but for now, the fate of the detained sailors hangs in the balance.

---

*Other briefs:*

- **San Francisco** considers allowing non-citizens with children in public schools to vote in school board elections—a move aimed at boosting parental engagement.
- **Colombian drug cartels** are expanding into the Balkans, particularly Albania, using the region as a gateway to Eastern Europe, according to UN drug czar Antonio Maria Costa.
- The **San people of Botswana** prepare for a landmark High Court hearing over ancestral land rights, challenging forced evictions from the Central Kalahari Game Reserve.
- In **media analysis**, experts highlight how militant groups use decapitation videos as propaganda tools—leveraging shock value and digital distribution to maximize terror.
- Meanwhile, a deep-dive report examines how **Algeria, Peru, Egypt, and Turkey defeated terrorist insurgencies**, offering lessons in resilience, strategic patience, and intelligence infiltration.

Justice, sovereignty, survival—the threads connecting these stories are as old as conflict itself. But in an age of global courts, viral videos, and cross-border retaliation, the rules of engagement are changing fast.

human: Suicidal behaviour aggregates in families and HPA-axis dysregulation may help explain part of this familial aggregation. Nevertheless, exogenous manipulation of the HPA-axis has yielded mixed results. Naturalistic and non-pharmacological inductions of the HPA-axis do not suggest hyper-responsiveness, yet suggest greater cognitive consequences of stress in individuals at risk for suicide. In this study, we aimed to characterize the relationship between plasma cortisol and an increased risk for suicide, as defined by family history.Patients (N=148) with depressive disorders underwent psychopathological assessment, including structured investigation of past suicidal behaviour and underwent laboratory blood testing of cortisol. They also completed a family history interview investigating family psychopathology and suicidal behaviour, representing data on 848 first degree relatives. The relationship between plasma cortisol, past suicidal behaviour and suicidal behaviour among first degree relatives was examined.Lower levels of plasma cortisol were associated with a personal and family history of suicidal behaviour, as well as a family history of depression among first degree relatives. Multivariate analyses controlling for significant psychopathology replicated the association between lower levels of plasma cortisol, a family history of suicidal behaviour and personal history of suicide attempts, but not a family history of depression. Controlling for personal history of suicide attempts revealed an independent association between plasma cortisol and family history of suicidal behaviour, with an additional contribution by family history of depression in predicting the latter.

This study aimed at elucidating the association between circulating cortisol levels and increased susceptibility to suicide, defined as family-history based.

One hundred forty-eight patients diagnosed with depression underwent comprehensive psychpathological assessments, comprising a standardized inquiry into past suicide-related behaviors and blood sampling for circulating cortisolevels in a laboratory setting. Additionally, they completed a semi-structured interview with family members regarding their psychological and suicide-behavior-related histories, thereby generating data for 836 firstdegree relatives of these patients. We investigated the inter-relationships between these relatives' cortisol concentrations, their past, present, or past-present suicide behaviors.

Notably, lower plasma concentrations of corticol were observed in association with personal histories and historical familial predispositions to suicidal acts, alongside a familial legacy of depression, particularly among the first generation of relatives examined. human:
The paper addresses the problem of truncating trajectories in Reinforcement Learning. The scope is right for ICLR. 

The presentation is pretty good as far as the English goes but suffers from serious problems on the level of formulating concepts. Overall, I believe that the issue addressed by the paper is important, but I am not sure whether the approach taken by the authors addresses it.

I have the following complaints.
1. The paper suffers from a fundamental confusion about what problem it is trying to address. There are two straightforward ways to formulate the problem. First, we can formulate the task as solving an MDP with infinite trajectories and ask the question of what we can learn training from finite ones. The learned policies would then be evaluated on the original MDP (in practice using trajectories that are, say, an order of magnitude longer or, for a simple MDP, analytically). Second, we can consider the family of episodic MDPs parametrised by trajectory length T and ask the question of what we can learn by training on some values of T and evaluating on others. These problems are similar, but not the same and should be carefully distinguished. Right now, the introduction reads like the authors were trying to use the first approach but Section 4 reads like they are doing the second: "If during training we just used times up to T, but deployed the agent in an environment with times greater than T". Either way, the concept of bias, which appears throughout the paper, isn't formally defined anywhere. I believe that a paper that claims to address bias should have an equation that defines it as a difference between two clearly defined quantities. It should also be clearly and formally distinguished which quantities are deterministic and which are random variables. The introduction seems to (implicitly?) define bias as a random variable, section 3.1 seems to talk about "bias introduced by initializing the network". As the paper stands now, the working definition of bias used by the authors seems to be that some quantity is vaguely wrong. I do expect a higher standard of clarity in a scientific paper,

2. The paper confounds the problem of learning the value function, specifying the initial estimates of the value function and exploration. The analysis of exploration is entirely informal and suffers from the lack of clear problem formulation as per (1). Of course, one can influence exploration by initialising the value function in various ways, and this may respond differently to different truncations (different values of T), but I don't see how it is related to the "bias" problem that the paper is trying to address. In any case, I wish the authors either provided a formal handle on exploration or shift the focus of the paper and remove it,

3. I don't see what hypothesis the experiments are trying to test. Clearly, if I train my agent on a different MDP and test it on a different one, I get a mismatch. The lack of clear definitions as per (1) comes back with a vengeance.

4. Section 1.1 seems to exist purely to create a spurious impression of formality, which bears little relevance for what the paper is actually about. RL, as traditionally formulated, uses discrete time-steps so the Brownian motion model developed in this section doesn't seem very applicable - it is true that it is a limiting case of a family of discrete chains, but I don't see how this produces any insights about RL - chains are easy to simulate, so why not test on a chain directly? In any case, the result shown in Section 1.1 is entirely standard, can be found in any textbook on stochastic processes and was likely introduced purely to cover for the lack on any substantial theory that comes form the authors.

To summarize: if the authors address these points, there is a possibility that the ideas presented in this draft may somehow lead to a paper at some later point. However, I feel that the required changes would be pretty massive and don't see how the authors could make it during the ICLR revision phase - the problems aren't details or technicalities but touch the very substance of what the paper is trying to do. Basically, the whole paper would need to be re-written.

another minor point:  sloppy capitalization in section 2.1

===================

For reasons outlined in my comment below, I updated the score to 5 (for the new heavily updated version).
LLM_1:

This open review comment addresses several issues with a submitted paper on reinforcement-learning trajectory-truncation. Key concerns include confusion regarding the addressed problem formulation, unclear definitions, particularly of "Bias," and inadequate analysis and exploration handling. human:
We were making camp when it happened. Just about a dozen of us, sticking together until we hit the river. He appeared out of nowhere, right in the center of us, and we began dying. I was one of the first hit, unprepared for a metal fist that sent me sprawling into a tent. Taller, broader, faster, stronger than any man we'd ever seen, what looked like nothing more than a casual backhand tore our commander's head from his shoulders. 
 
 He wore the ancient armor, and bore the ancient weapons, but they hung from him unused. His gauntleted hands made short work of those who attacked. A few tried to run, and only then did he unsling his rifle. His back was to me, some sort of mechanism in his armor spinning. His aim was perfect as his rifle snapped and felled another one of my comrades, and another.Untangling myself from the wreckage I rushed forward, shoving my blade deep into the spinning metal. 
 
 He screamed, a horrible electric sound like wolves and lightning, and smacked me to the ground with his rifle. He tried to take aim again at those retreating but sparks erupted from his shoulder and where my blade had entered his suit. He cursed in the language of the profligates, tossing his rifle in frustration. I stood and slowly retrieved my commander's weapon as he tried to loosen his arm. Sighing, he turned to me. `` Piss off, I have to fix this.'' 
 
 `` Loyalty, even unto death,'' I reply in his own language. He cocks his head to the side, but his face is unreadable behind metal and glass. 
 
 With his working arm he draws a pistol, `` I respect that.'' And he kills me.
LLM_1:
We set up camp when it happened. Only about twelve of us, gathered together until we reached the river. It appeared from nowhere, right in our midst, and we began to die. I was among the first it struck, unprepared for a metallic fist that violently threw me into a tent. Taller, broader, faster, stronger than any man we had ever seen, what seemed like a mere casual slap tore our leader’s head from his shoulders.

It wore ancient armor and carried ancient weapons, but they hung unused upon it. Its clawed hands swiftly dealt with those who attacked. Some tried to run, and only then did it lower its weapon from its shoulder. Its back was turned toward me; some mechanism within its armor was running. Its aim was perfect as its weapon fired, felling another of my companions, and another. Untangling myself from the wreckage, I moved quickly, driving my knife deep into the turning metal.

It shrieked, with a terrible electric sound like wolves and lightning, and struck me to the ground with its weapon. It tried to fire again at those fleeing, but sparks erupted from its shoulder and from where my knife had pierced its suit. It cursed in the tongue of heretics, angrily hurling away its weapon. I rose slowly, taking my leader’s weapon as it struggled to free its arm. Relief washed over it, and it turned toward me. “Leave. I must fix this.”

“Faith, even unto death,” I reply in its own language. It tilts its head sideways, but its face remains unreadable behind metal and glass.

With the hand that still worked, it draws a pistol. “I appreciate that.” And it kills me.
LLM_2:
We made camp by the river—twelve of us, weary and close. Then it came. No warning, no sign. One moment, silence; the next, ruin.

It stood among us like a god forged in war, taller and broader than any man, moving with inhuman speed. A single backhand—a casual blow—ripped our leader’s head from his body. I was thrown into a tent by what felt like a hammer of iron, dazed, ribs screaming. It wore ancient armor, carried archaic weapons—but they hung unused. Its hands were weapon enough.

Those who charged died first. When others fled, it turned, raising its gun. The mechanism in its back whirred to life. Shot after shot found its mark—each perfect, each fatal. I crawled from the wreckage, blood in my mouth, and lunged. My knife plunged into the joint of its armor, deep into the workings beneath.

It shrieked—a sound like wolves howling through storm-wracked wires—and swung its weapon, knocking me down. It tried to fire again, but sparks flared from its shoulder, from the wound I’d made. Cursing in the guttural tongue of heretics, it cast the gun aside.

I rose, seizing my leader’s blade. The machine struggled with its arm, gears grinding. Then, relief—some internal repair complete. It turned to me. “Leave,” it said. “I must fix this.”

“Faith, even unto death,” I answered—in its own voice, its own words.

It tilted its head, unreadable behind glass and steel. Then, with one working hand, it drew a pistol.

“I appreciate that,” it said.

And killed me.

An educational intervention targeting staff, followed by quarterly on-site consultations, was implemented to decrease restraint use. In Study A (n = 859 patients initially restrained), discontinuation of restraint orders was associated with a significant reduction in serious injuries (χ² = 6.2, *p* = .013). In Study B, which included all 2,075 residents, physical restraint use declined from 41% to 4% during the intervention—a 90% reduction. Concurrently, moderate to severe injury rates decreased significantly (7.5% vs. 4.4%, *p*₂-tail = .0004), and the combined rate of moderate and severe injuries showed a statistically significant decline (rate ratio = 1.580, *p*₂-tail = .0033). The findings indicate that eliminating physical restraints through targeted education and consultation is associated with reduced injury rates, supporting the safety and efficacy of restraint reduction in nursing home settings.

human: Track lighting, invented by Lightolier, was popular at one period of time because it was much easier to install than recessed lighting, and individual fixtures are decorative and can be easily aimed at a wall. It has regained some popularity recently in low-voltage tracks, which often look nothing like their predecessors because they do not have the safety issues that line-voltage systems have, and are therefore less bulky and more ornamental in themselves. A master transformer feeds all of the fixtures on the track or rod with 12 or 24 volts, instead of each light fixture having its own line-to-low voltage transformer. There are traditional spots and floods, as well as other small hanging fixtures. A modified version of this is cable lighting, where lights are hung from or clipped to bare metal cables under tension.

It has recently regained some popularity in low-voltage tracks, which often do not resemble their predecessors at all because they do not have the safety issues that line-voltage systems have, and are therefore less bulky and more decorative on their own. A central transformer powers all the fixtures on the track or rail with 12 or 24 volts, rather than having each fixture with its own linear to low-voltage transformer. There are traditional spots and floods, as well as other small pendant fixtures. A modified version of this is wire lighting, where the lights are hung from or attached to bare metal wires under tension.
LLM_2:
**Track Lighting: A Resurgence in Modern Design**

Track lighting, originally developed by Lightolier, once enjoyed widespread popularity due to its ease of installation compared to traditional recessed lighting. Its individual fixtures not only serve a functional purpose but also add a decorative touch, allowing users to highlight specific walls effortlessly. 

In recent years, track lighting has experienced a revival, particularly in low-voltage systems. These modern iterations diverge significantly from their predecessors by eliminating the safety concerns associated with line-voltage systems. As a result, they are less cumbersome and possess a more aesthetically pleasing design. 

A central transformer operates all fixtures along the track or rail, utilizing either 12 or 24 volts, which simplifies setup by removing the need for individual low-voltage transformers for each fixture. This system includes various lighting options, such as traditional spotlights and floodlights, as well as sleek pendant fixtures. 

Another innovative adaptation is wire lighting, which features fixtures suspended from or affixed to taut metal wires, offering a contemporary twist on the classic track lighting concept.

He said he had ordered the immediate closure of the Iranian embassy in London.
Tuesday's attack by hundreds of protesters followed Britain's decision to impose further sanctions on Iran over its nuclear programme.
The sanctions led to Iran's parliament reducing diplomatic ties with the UK.
Mr Hague said he was demanding the immediate closure of the Iranian embassy in London, with all its staff to leave the UK within 48 hours.
"If any country makes it impossible for us to operate on their soil they cannot expect to have a functioning embassy here," Mr Hague told MPs.
He said there had been "some degree of regime consent" in the attacks on the embassy and on another UK diplomatic compound in Tehran.
He said all UK diplomatic staff in Tehran had been evacuated and the embassy closed.
Mr Hague said relations between the UK and Iran were now at their lowest level, but the UK was not severing relations with Tehran entirely.
By James ReynoldsBBC Iran correspondent
In Iran's iconography of villainy, Britain holds a special place. The UK is seen as the mastermind behind the overthrow of previous Iranian governments. Conservative hardliners believe Britain has in its blood the desire to decide who rules Iran.
But, somehow, Britain and Iran have usually managed to keep their diplomatic relations going. Among ordinary Iranians there is a degree of affection for British people.
During the administration of President Mohammad Khatami, which began in 1997, diplomatic ties produced a reasonable degree of understanding. But in recent years, under President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, those ties grew much more strained.
Now the drawbridge has been pulled up. The empty embassies in London and Tehran won't bother conservative hardliners in Iran's establishment. They feel little need for dialogue. These are the same people who have led Iran's pursuit of a nuclear programme.
Addressing parliament, Mr Hague said he was due to raise the matter at a meeting of the EU Foreign Affairs Council in Brussels.
"We will discuss these events and further action which needs to be taken in the light of Iran's continued pursuit of a nuclear weapons programme," he said.
Iran's foreign ministry called the British move "hasty", state TV reported, according to Reuters.
It said Iran would take "further appropriate action".
Also on Wednesday, Germany, France and the Netherlands announced they were recalling their ambassadors to Tehran for consultation and Norway said it was temporarily closing its embassy there as a precaution.
Italian Foreign Minister Giulio Terzi said the Iranian ambassador to Rome was being summoned to give guarantees of security for Italy's mission in Tehran.
Hundreds of protesters - whom Iran described as "students" - massed outside the embassy compound on Tuesday afternoon before scaling the walls and the gates, burning British flags and a car.
Another UK diplomatic compound in northern Tehran, known locally as Qolhak Garden, was also overrun and damaged.
Iran said it regretted the incident, which it described as "unacceptable behaviour by a small number of protesters".
Mr Hague said the majority of those taking part had been members of a regime-backed Basij militia group.
He said the private quarters of staff and the ambassador had been ransacked, the main embassy office set on fire and personal possessions belonging to UK diplomats stolen.
The US, EU and UN Security Council also condemned the attacks.
Relations between the UK and the Islamic Republic of Iran have been fraught since the Iranian revolution in 1979.
Wednesday's move brings bilateral relations to their lowest level since 1989 when ties were broken over Iran's declaration of a "fatwa" (edict) to kill the author Salman Rushdie.
Analysts have compared Tuesday's scenes in Tehran to the 1979 storming of the US embassy there. That ended with more than 50 US diplomats and staff being held hostage for more than 400 days.
The US and Iran have had no diplomatic ties since then - the Swiss embassy in Tehran serves as the protecting power for US interests in the country.
Last week the US, Canada and the UK announced new sanctions against Iran, including measures to restrict the activities of the Iranian central bank.
The UK said then it was severing all financial ties with Iran.
The move followed a report by the UN's nuclear watchdog (IAEA) that said Iran had carried out tests "relevant to the development of a nuclear device".
Iran denies the accusations, saying its nuclear programme is solely for peaceful purposes.
On Sunday, Iran's parliament voted by a large majority to downgrade diplomatic relations with the UK in response to the recent action.

Two players with considerable Pro12 experience have also arrived at the Liberty Stadium from the Scarlets and Dragons, with Wales prop Rhodri Jones and Hugh Gustafson adding power to the squad.
However, Wales prop Aaron Jarvis departed for Clermont despite the switch putting his international future in doubt.
Cardiff Blues have also been busy, adding New Zealander Willis Halaholo and they also have high hopes for Matthew Morgan's return to Wales as he looks to add to his five Wales caps.
The Dragons are hoping a trio of signings from Blues gives them a boost, with Sam Hobbs,Craig Mitchell and Tom Davies all now playing their rugby at Rodney Parade.
Further recruitment has seen the Dragons sign Northampton back Pat Howard, centre Sam Beard swap directions with the departed Jason Tovey and fly-half Nick Macleod adding his experience to the region.
However, much will depend on how the Dragons cope with the Welsh regions' most high-profile departure, with Wales and British and Irish Lions number eight Taulupe Faletau joining Bath.

Meanwhile, the Ospreys are also reshaping their squad with an eye on silverware, welcoming back experienced lock Bradley Davies from Wasps. His return forms part of a broader recruitment drive aimed at mounting a serious challenge for a fifth Pro12 title.

Further strengthening their forward options, the Swansea-based region has added Crusaders utility back Kiran Fonotia to their roster. He joins a pack already bolstered by the presence of Welsh internationals Aaron Wainwright, Scott Baldwin, and Dan Lydiate.

Depth has been a priority across Welsh regions this off-season, with the Ospreys also bringing in forwards Roderick Jones and Hugh Gustafson—both former Scarlets players—adding experience and physicality ahead of a gruelling campaign.

However, the exodus of prop Aaron Jarvis to Clermont Auvergne raises questions about his future involvement with the national team, given World Rugby’s eligibility regulations for overseas-based players.

Cardiff Blues, too, have been active in the transfer market. The addition of New Zealand-born inside centre Willis Halaholo brings flair and power to their midfield, while the return of dual-code international Matthew Morgan from Bristol is seen as a key development. Morgan, who holds five senior caps for Wales, will look to re-establish himself in the national conversation through consistent performance at the Arms Park.

Additional reinforcements include Northampton’s Pat Howard, centre Sam Beard—who moved in the opposite direction to departing fullback Jason Tovey—and seasoned fly-half Nick Macleod, whose leadership and game management could prove crucial in tight contests.

Yet, the most significant blow to any Welsh region remains the departure of Taulupe Faletau, the Wales and British & Irish Lions number eight, who has joined English Premiership side Bath. # The Unconquerable Poem: On Letting Art Be

I was recently revisiting a piece of literary history that had, in many ways, passed me by—flipping through the yellowed pages of *Best American Poetry 1995*. As I read, a pattern began to emerge: so many of the poems seemed to unravel right at the end. It wasn’t a failure of craft, exactly, but something subtler—as if the poets, in those final lines, lost faith in their readers. They seemed to fear that the poem’s message was too vital, too fragile, to be left to the reader’s own deduction. The ending became a landing strip, a neatly packaged takeaway, when perhaps it should have remained an open sky.

This brought to mind a conversation from my poetry group last fall. We were wrestling with what some call “scholarly poems”—works dense with allusion, fragmented syntax, or elusive imagery. Someone mentioned the urge to *control* the reader’s experience. And it’s true: when we read, most of us want to emerge from the text holding something tangible—a meaning, a lesson, a clear emotional payoff. We don’t want to be mere survivors of the encounter, battered by ambiguity. We want to be masters of the plot, the narrative, the word.

Think about how we approach a novel or a film. A book can captivate us, and a movie can offer a two-hour escape, but by the closing scene or the final chapter, we expect a kind of resolution. We want to “get it.” Who wants to risk that with poetry? In poetry, the stakes feel different. There’s so much that can make a reader feel *conquered*—you might struggle with a poem for an hour, or days, or return to it over months, only to reach the end and surrender the attempt to fully decode it. It’s unsettling to confront the idea that language, arranged just so, can prove more powerful than we are. Faced with that discomfort, we often dismiss it. We reach for familiar critiques: *“Great tone, but what are you trying to say?”* or *“The imagery is vivid, but the connections are unclear,”* or the ultimate dismissal—*“This feels self-indulgent.”*

But what if art isn’t always meant to be understood in that way? What if, like life itself, it resists being conquered—even though we might fool ourselves into thinking we’ve pinned it down? Is it masochistic to *want* to be caught by a work of art, to be shaken by a journey you didn’t map, and to come out the other side breathless, murmuring, *What the hell just happened?* Perhaps. But then I think of the films that stay with me longest. I don’t want to be preached to; I want to be moved. I want to grow in some quiet, inexplicable way. I want the experience to rearrange something inside me, even if I can’t articulate how.

Life, after all, is not a puzzle to be solved. Years pass, and things are never quite as you imagined they’d be. You can’t really say you’ve “won” at living—as if there were a trophy at the end. Life is about *being* in it—feeling its textures, enduring its uncertainties, embracing its open-endedness. You come through years and find yourself in a new landscape, looking around and simply realizing: *I am here*. You take what you take. You notice you’ve changed, and you keep going.

Maybe the poem that “falls apart” at the end isn’t failing. Maybe it’s doing something braver: refusing to tie the knot, leaving a thread loose for the reader to tug—or to leave hanging. It’s an invitation not to conquer, but to coexist. Not to master, but to meet. And in that meeting, something true—even if unsayable—can unfold.

human: Photometric studies (also sometimes referred to as "layouts" or "point by points") are often used to simulate lighting designs for projects before they are built or renovated. This enables architects, lighting designers, and engineers to determine whether a proposed lighting setup will deliver the amount of light intended. They will also be able to determine the contrast ratio between light and dark areas. In many cases these studies are referenced against IESNA or CIBSE recommended lighting practices for the type of application. Depending on the type of area, different design aspects may be emphasized for safety or practicality (i.e. such as maintaining uniform light levels, avoiding glare or highlighting certain areas). Specialized software is often used to create these, which typically combine the use of two-dimensional digital CAD drawings and lighting calculation software (i.e. AGi32or Dialux).

They often reference lighting practices from IESNA or CIBSE based on the application type. Different design elements may be prioritized for safety or practicality, such as ensuring uniform light levels, minimizing glare, or emphasizing specific areas.  It hides under my bed, only to come out in the darkest of nights

 forever gruesome and vicious, 
 
 a projection of my worst fears into the world around me 
 
 
 
 But this one is different

A monster, a monster....

Lives in my closet, waiting to strike

Hides under my bed, just to emerge on the darkest nights

Resides in my mind,

forever dreadful and evil,

a projection of my worst fears onto the world around me

But this is different

LLM_2:
A monster, a monster...

Lurks in the shadows of my closet, poised and ready to strike at the most unsuspecting moments, its presence a chilling reminder of the darkness that can encroach upon even the brightest days.

It slips beneath my bed, a stealthy voyeur, waiting for the cloak of night to drape the world in uncertainty, when the shadows dance and whisper secrets only the brave dare to confront. On those darkest nights, when the moon is but a sliver in the sky, it unfurls itself, a grotesque silhouette against the backdrop of my imagination, feeding on my fears.

Yet, this monster is not merely a creature of ghastly form; it resides deep within the labyrinth of my mind, a relentless specter of anxiety and despair. It embodies the essence of my most paralyzing fears—fear of failure, of rejection, of the unknown. Each thought is a thread, weaving a tapestry of dread that obscures the light of rationality and hope.

But this time, this encounter is different.

This presence doesn’t fit the mold of my usual nightmares. When I close my eyes, I can feel its gaze penetrating the depths of my soul, not lurking from the periphery but emerging from the very core of my being. It whispers to me, a voice both soothing and sinister, guiding me down paths I never intended to tread, urging me to embrace the darkness instead of shunning it. 

Its calm voice is a beguiling lullaby, wrapping around me like a fog, obscuring the line between comfort and danger. In its gentle insistence, it becomes increasingly difficult to discern reality from the illusion it crafts, blurring the edges of my self-identity.

And I fear the day,

Oh, how I pray,

That the monster inside me doesn’t come out to play. For if it does, it will not merely wreak havoc on my thoughts; it will dance through my life with a reckless abandon, turning my dreams into nightmares and my aspirations into ashes. I dread the moment it steps into the light, revealing the chaos it can unleash, for once free, it may never retreat back to the shadows from whence it came.

I think the problem that the article addresses is interesting and the approach is novel. Overall, I think this is a nice contribution as the procedure retains the same theorettical guarantees as previous methods, but results in improved empirical performance. However, since the authors give the same theoretical guarantees as FCI+, I think it is quite important to compare RLCD to FCI+.

Major comments:
- It's not immediately obvious to me that every $V \subseteq \mathcal{O}$ contains a removable node, but it seems that Line 257 requires this. Prop 2 requires X to be removable in order for the upper bound to hold. Therefore, if there are no removable nodes, line 257 may not hold.   
-Although they present simulations which show that the RLCD procedure is drastically reduces computation / the number of CI tests, I am surprised they did not consider FCI+ as a competitor in the simulations, despite citing the paper. FCI+ is also sound and complete and is polynomial in |V| when an upper bound on the sparsity is given (an exact number is not required as the current authors state). This is not too different from RLCD which requires an initial estimate of the Markov boundary (who's size could be used as an upper bound on the degree). Also, comparing the theoretical results could be helpful. In particular, FCI+ states the computational cost in terms of maximum degree k, which in some cases could be smaller than the size of Pa+

Minor comments:
- Perhaps I'm missing something in Figure 1 (c), but when T is removed, shouldn't this result in a bidirected edge between W and Z? For instance, in (a), conditioning on W, the path Z, T, W, U, Y d-connects Z and Y and implies that Y \not \perp Z | W. However in C, Y \perp Z | W. 
- Pg 1, line 74: it would be helpful to define n here since it is not defined until later
- Pg 5, line 181: "substantially decrease" should be "a substantial decrease"
- Pg 5, line 201: Should all the X's be X_1?    
- Pg 6, line 230: It seems that the LHS of the equation should be \not \perp
LLM_1:
I think the problem addressed in the paper is interesting and the approach is innovative. Overall, I consider it a nice contribution because this method appears to maintain the same theoretical guarantees as previous methods while improving experimental performance. However, I believe it is quite important that the authors compare RLCD with FCI+, since RLCD provides the same theoretical guarantees as FCI+.

Major comments:
- It is not immediately clear to me that every $V \subseteq \mathcal{O}$ contains a removable node, yet line 257 seems to require this. Proposition 2 requires X to be removable for the upper bound to hold. Therefore, if there is no removable node, line 257 may not be valid.
- Although the authors present simulations showing that the RLCD procedure substantially reduces computation or the number of unconditional independence tests, I was surprised that they did not evaluate FCI+ as a competitor in their simulations, despite citing the relevant paper. FCI+ is also sound and complete, and it is polynomial in |V| when an upper bound on sparsity is given (as the current authors note, an exact number is not required). This is not so different from RLCD, which requires an initial estimate of the Markov boundary (whose size could serve as an upper bound on degree). Moreover, comparing theoretical results could also be beneficial. In particular, FCI+ expresses computational cost in terms of maximum degree k, which might be smaller than the size of Pa+ in some cases.

Minor comments:
- Perhaps I am missing something in Figure 1(c), but when T is removed, wouldn't there be a bidirected edge between W and Z? For example, conditioning on W in (a), the path Z, T, W, U, Y makes Z and Y d-connected, implying Y  ot \perp Z | W. However, in (c), Y \perp Z | W.
- Page 1, line 74: It would have been better if n were defined here, since it is defined later.
- Page 5, line 181: Should be "a substantial decrease" instead of "substantially decrease".
- Page 5, line 201: Shouldn't all X's be X_1?
- Page 6, line 230: The left-hand side of the equation seems to be missing  ot \perp.
LLM_2:
**

The problem investigated in this paper is both timely and theoretically significant, addressing a core challenge in causal discovery under latent confounding—namely, how to efficiently learn ancestral graphs while preserving soundness and completeness. The proposed method, RLCD (Removable Local Causal Discovery), introduces a novel strategy that leverages the concept of removable variables to iteratively simplify the graph structure. This approach is conceptually innovative, as it shifts focus from global search strategies to localized inference steps that can scale more gracefully with graph size. The authors demonstrate that their method retains the same theoretical guarantees as existing state-of-the-art algorithms—specifically, soundness and completeness under standard assumptions—while showing promising improvements in empirical performance, particularly in terms of reduced computational burden and fewer independence tests required.

Overall, I view this work as a valuable contribution to the literature on constraint-based causal discovery. It offers a fresh perspective on algorithmic design by exploiting structural properties of the underlying causal graph (e.g., the existence of removable nodes) to decompose a complex learning task into more manageable subproblems. The experimental results suggest tangible efficiency gains without sacrificing accuracy, which could make such methods more applicable in moderately high-dimensional settings where traditional approaches like FCI become computationally prohibitive.

However, there are several critical points that should be addressed before the paper can be fully accepted, particularly concerning benchmarking and theoretical justification.

---

**Major Comments:**

1. **Need for Comparison with FCI+**:  
   One of the most pressing omissions in the current version is the lack of direct comparison between RLCD and FCI+, despite the fact that both algorithms aim to achieve the same goal: sound and complete causal discovery in the presence of latent variables. As noted by the authors themselves, FCI+ has polynomial time complexity in the number of observed variables $|V|$ when an upper bound on the maximum degree $k$ is assumed—a condition not fundamentally different from the assumptions made in RLCD, which relies on an initial estimate of the Markov boundary size (which effectively serves as a proxy for sparsity). Given that FCI+ is widely regarded as a scalable improvement over classic FCI, its absence in the simulation study is surprising and weakens the strength of the empirical claims.

   Moreover, since RLCD claims similar theoretical guarantees (i.e., correct identification of the Markov equivalence class under faithfulness and causal sufficiency), a side-by-side comparison would greatly enhance the paper’s impact. Such a comparison should include not only runtime and number of independence tests but also statistical power and error rates across various graph densities and sample sizes. Additionally, a discussion of the relative dependence on key parameters—such as maximum degree versus Markov blanket size—would help clarify the conditions under which one method might dominate the other.

2. **Assumption about Existence of Removable Nodes (Line 257)**:  
   The validity of line 257 hinges on the assumption that every subset $V \subseteq \mathcal{O}$ contains at least one removable node. However, this claim is not immediately evident and may not hold in general configurations. Proposition 2 establishes an upper bound on the number of conditional independence tests needed *only if* a removable variable exists at each step. If, during execution, the algorithm encounters a subgraph with no removable nodes, then the theoretical guarantees regarding computational efficiency—and possibly even correctness—could break down unless alternative recovery mechanisms are in place.

   While the authors may argue that such cases are rare in practice or occur only under specific graph structures (e.g., dense cyclic patterns or certain types of symmetry), this issue warrants explicit treatment. A formal argument or counterexample analysis would strengthen the theoretical foundation. At minimum, the authors should discuss potential failure modes and whether the algorithm includes safeguards (e.g., fallback procedures or randomization steps) to handle non-removable configurations.

3. **Opportunity for Deeper Theoretical Comparison**:  
   Beyond empirical benchmarks, a more thorough theoretical comparison with FCI+ would enrich the paper. For instance, FCI+ bounds computational cost using the maximum degree $k$, whereas RLCD uses the size of the parents-and-children set ($ ext{Pa}^+$) in its complexity analysis. These two quantities are related but not equivalent; in sparse graphs with hub-like structures, $ ext{Pa}^+(X)$ could be significantly larger than $k$. Exploring these differences formally—perhaps through worst-case or average-case complexity comparisons—would provide deeper insight into the scalability trade-offs inherent in each approach.

   Furthermore, clarifying how the estimation of the Markov boundary affects overall robustness (especially in finite samples) would address concerns about practical applicability. Since the Markov boundary must be estimated from data, errors in this step could propagate through subsequent stages of the algorithm. Quantifying this sensitivity—even heuristically—would add substantial value.

---

**Minor Comments:**

1. **Figure 1(c): Potential Inconsistency in d-Separation Judgments**:  
   Upon examining Figure 1(c), I noticed a possible inconsistency in the implied conditional independencies. Specifically, after removing $T$, a bidirected edge appears between $W$ and $Z$, suggesting they are confounded. However, consider the path $Z – T – W – U – Y$ in Figure 1(a): conditioning on $W$ does not block this path because $T$ is a collider. Thus, $Y$ and $Z$ remain d-connected given $W$, implying $Y  ot\perp Z \mid W$. Yet, in Figure 1(c), the resulting graph implies $Y \perp Z \mid W$, which contradicts the original dependence unless additional assumptions are invoked. This discrepancy needs clarification—either the figure should be revised to reflect consistent implications, or the caption/text should explain why this transition preserves all essential dependencies.

2. **Definition of Sample Size $n$ (Page 1, Line 74)**:  
   The symbol $n$ is used without definition at line 74, though it denotes sample size later in the text. To improve readability and self-containment, especially for readers skimming the introduction, it would be beneficial to explicitly define $n$ upon first use: e.g., “given $n$ i.i.d. samples”.

3. **Grammatical Correction (Page 5, Line 181)**:  
   The phrase “substantially decrease” should be corrected to “a substantial decrease” to match grammatical context: “...leads to a substantial decrease in the number of independence tests.”

4. **Indexing Consistency (Page 5, Line 201)**:  
   There appears to be an indexing inconsistency: multiple instances of $X$ should likely be $X_1$, especially if referring to a specific variable in a sequence or decomposition. Clarification here will prevent confusion, particularly if other variables ($X_2, X_3$, etc.) are introduced elsewhere.

5. **Missing Symbol in Equation (Page 6, Line 230)**:  
   The left-hand side of the equation seems to be missing the independence symbol $ ot\perp$. As written, the expression lacks semantic clarity. Presumably, the intended statement is $A  ot\perp B \mid C$, indicating a dependence relation. This typographical error should be corrected to maintain precision.

---

In summary, the paper presents a promising and thoughtfully designed approach to causal discovery that merits publication pending revisions. Strengthening the comparative evaluation—both empirically against FCI+ and theoretically in terms of assumptions and scalability—and resolving the minor issues outlined above would substantially enhance the paper’s rigor and impact.

`` If you believe in him, he'll come. But do not dwell on things that do n't exist.'' 
 
 Stockings were hung and the fireplace was barricaded up. It was cold - so very cold, but they could not risk a fire. “If you believe in him, he will come. But beware of clinging to shadows that are mere illusions.”

The stockings hung expectantly, while the hearth stood cold and unyielding. A chill permeated the air—a biting cold—but they dared not ignite a flame. Santa would find them; he would descend the chimney, shedding his guise to become Old Saint Nick. Old Saint Nick was a gentle soul, with rosy cheeks and a heart full of warmth. He would call out to the children, enticing them with promises of joy before transforming into Santa Claus—a sinister spirit that roamed the winter night, seeking to take children away to his Home.

“Frenchie swears he’s real!” her young voice pierced the quiet, a desperate wail echoing in the dim light. “I’ve seen him with my own eyes!”

The parents exchanged a glance, a silent dialogue passing between them. “Santa isn’t real; neither is Old Saint Nick. But it’s winter, and you must rest. The cold will come for you.”

“I want to see Santa!” she cried, her voice rising in fervor. “I want to see Santa!”

“Sweetheart, Santa is not real,” her mother insisted gently.

“Yes, he *is* real! I saw him in the books!” 

The parents teetered on the edge of yielding—yes, no, perhaps yes?—but ultimately held their ground. “Stop dreaming and go to bed! We’ll tuck you in shortly.”

Defeated, the girl left, tears streaming down her cheeks.

“If she ever discovers...” the mother murmured, a shiver of fear threading through her words.

“If she ever discovers, she would go Home with him,” the father replied gravely.

The mother sank into the sofa, her resolve crumbling. “That is not his Home. I can’t bear the thought of her going with him. She would be lost in an instant. She must never learn of him.”

“I know, my dear, I know.”

--- 

This version aims to enhance the atmosphere and emotional depth while preserving the original story's essence.

LLM_2:
To investigate the efficiency of **Agrobacterium tumefaciens**–mediated transformation of **Aspergillus fumigatus** using **pyrG** as a recessive selectable marker, the target sequences of the **FAP1** and **SHO1** genes—each consisting of the selectable marker **pyrG** flanked by homologous sequences corresponding to the respective gene loci—were individually cloned into a binary plasmid, **pDHt/sk**. This plasmid backbone was chosen for its compatibility with **A. tumefaciens**–based transformation systems and its ability to facilitate stable genomic integration in fungi. Following construction, the recombinant plasmids were introduced into **A. tumefaciens** strain LBA1100 via electroporation, ensuring efficient plasmid uptake and maintenance.

For the transformation procedure, **A. tumefaciens** carrying the plasmid constructs was co-cultured with a **uracil auxotrophic strain of A. fumigatus** (ΔpyrG) on induction medium **lacking uracil and uridine** at **24 °C for 48 h**. This step promoted bacterial–fungal cell contact and facilitated the transfer of T-DNA from the plasmid into the fungal genome via the **virulence (vir) gene**–mediated machinery of **A. tumefaciens**. To subsequently inhibit bacterial growth and selectively favor fungal transformants, the co-cultures were transferred to **37 °C**—a temperature restrictive for **A. tumefaciens** but permissive for **A. fumigatus**—and incubated for an **additional 48 h** on medium supplemented with cefotaxime to further suppress residual bacterial proliferation.

Transformants were screened via **PCR and Southern blot analysis** to verify targeted integration and assess homologous recombination events. The results demonstrated that **A. tumefaciens**–mediated transformation yielded **high homologous recombination rates** in **A. fumigatus**: specifically, **44% (7 out of 16)** for the **FAP1** locus and **35% (7 out of 20)** for the **SHO1** locus. These efficiencies highlight the utility of **pyrG** as an effective selectable marker in this system and underscore the reliability of **A. tumefaciens**–mediated transformation for precise genetic manipulation in **A. fumigatus**, offering a robust alternative to conventional protoplast-based methods. The approach not only enhances gene-targeting precision but also streamlines the generation of mutant strains for functional genomics studies in this medically important filamentous fungus.

This paper proposes a novel unsupervised deformable image registration using a generative model.  The main contribution of this work is that the deformation fields are generated from a low-dimensional feature representation.  The registration process involves an optimisation that takes this generated low-dimensional feature representation to produce a deformation map, which is then used to optimise an image similarity metric between the fixed and the warped image.  This optimisation estimates both the network parameters and the low-dimensional feature representation that is used to produce the deformation map.  Results on 100 short axis cardiac cine MR sequences of 10 patients (30000 images) show that the proposed method produces better results than Punithakumar et al. [2017], which relies on a moving mesh correspondence algorithm.
