The Crime Survey of England and Wales (CSEW) said there were eight million crimes against households and adults in that period.
It is the lowest estimate since the survey began in 1981.
The figures, published by the Office for National Statistics (ONS), estimate crime levels based on how many people say they have been victim of a crime.
The CSEW said household crime, related to vehicles and property, was down by 10%, while personal crime, including thefts from the person and violent crimes, fell by 9%. It also estimated violence had fallen by 13%, taking it to its lowest level for 33 years.
Police figures also showed a fall in offences. The ONS published data from forces showing there had been 3.7 million offences in the same period, a decrease of 3% compared with the previous year.
However, the National Statistics designation has been removed from all crime data recorded by the police after the UK Statistics Authority said it could not be approved owing to claims of unreliability.
By Danny ShawHome affairs correspondent, BBC News
Recent claims that police have been fiddling the crime figures have obscured the fact that crime really is coming down.
The Crime Survey, which is independent of police and includes crimes that aren't reported, suggests there's been a reduction in offending for almost 20 years.
The data on violence is extraordinary: about two in every 100 adults were victims of violent crime in the last year - compared with five in every 100 in 1995.
The allegedly flawed police figures back this up - and show that the number of homicides - which can't be manipulated - has almost halved in a decade.
There are some warning signs - the Office for National Statistics says there's been a "real" rise in shoplifting, though increases in fraud and sexual offences may be due to changes in recording methods and the greater willingness of victims to come forward.
Serving Metropolitan Police officer Pc James Patrick told MPs last month that crime figures were manipulated to hit performance targets, adding that this had become "an ingrained part of policing culture".
Prime Minister David Cameron tweeted "congratulations" to police, saying the fall in crime was "bringing security to people".
The number of sexual offences recorded by police increased by 17%, which the ONS said "is likely to be partly due to a continuation of a 'Yewtree effect', whereby a greater number of victims have come forward to report historical sexual offences to the police".
There was a 122% rise in the number of historical sex crimes - those which happened more than 20 years ago - recorded by police in the year to September 2013.
This followed the Savile revelations which came to light the previous October. There was a 35% rise in sex crimes that had happened between one and 20 years ago and an 11% increase in crimes that took place in the past 12 months, according to police figures.
There were "signs of increasing upward pressures" in some other offences, including a 4% rise in shoplifting and a 7% increase in theft from the person, the ONS said.
The national lead on crime statistics of the Association of Chief Police Officers, Chief Constable Jeff Farrar, described the fall in crime in the CSEW as "encouraging".
He said: "Accurate crime statistics are not only essential in holding police accountable for the work they do in the ongoing fight against crime, but also vital in ensuring that police officers and staff are deployed to the right place at the right time.
"It is disappointing that the UK Statistics Authority has decided to remove the National Statistics designation from police-recorded crime statistics as this has come at a time when the service is working to make crime statistics more transparent, more accountable and assure the public of the figures' integrity."
Four police forces showed an increase in overall crime. Northumbria, City of London and British Transport Police reported a 1% rise, while Kent showed an 8% increase, but this is believed to be due to a change in recording practices.
There was no change in Cumbria, Gwent, Humberside and Merseyside.
Crime prevention minister Norman Baker said: "England and Wales are safer than they have been for decades with crime now at its lowest level since the survey began in 1981.
"The government has made clear that recorded crime statistics must be as robust as possible and we have a strong record on reinforcing their independence and accountability."

### Crime Rates in England and Wales Reach Historic Low, Independent Survey Reveals

The latest Crime Survey for England and Wales (CSEW) reports a significant decline in crime, with an estimated eight million offenses against households and individuals recorded during the past year. This figure marks the lowest since the survey's inception in 1981. According to the Office for National Statistics (ONS), these estimates are derived from personal accounts of crime victims and indicate a notable reduction in crime rates.

The CSEW findings highlight a 10% decrease in household-related crimes, such as those involving vehicles and properties, while personal crimes—including robberies and violent incidents—fell by 9%. Remarkably, violent crime saw a 13% decline, achieving its lowest level in 33 years. Supporting these statistics, police data indicated a 3% decrease in overall crime, with 3.7 million offenses reported over the same period. 

However, the credibility of police-recorded crime data has come under scrutiny. The UK Statistics Authority has stripped the National Statistics designation from these figures, citing concerns regarding their reliability. This follows allegations of manipulated crime statistics by some police forces, which have obscured the broader trend of declining crime rates.

The independent nature of the CSEW allows it to include unreported crimes, suggesting a sustained decrease in criminal activity over nearly two decades. The survey reveals that only about 2% of adults experienced violent crime in the past year, a sharp contrast to 5% in 1995. Notably, homicide figures—considered beyond manipulation—have nearly halved over the past ten years.

Despite the overall decline, there are emerging concerns regarding certain crime categories. The ONS has noted a "real" rise in shoplifting, while increases in fraud and sexual offenses may be attributed to improved reporting practices and greater victim willingness to come forward.

Last month, Metropolitan Police officer Pc James Patrick addressed parliament, asserting that crime figures have been distorted to meet performance benchmarks, a practice he described as deeply ingrained in police culture. In a show of support, Prime Minister David Cameron commended the police for their efforts, stating that the reduction in crime enhances public safety.

The ONS reported a 17% rise in sexual offenses, which it attributes partly to the ongoing "Yewtree effect," where more victims are reporting historical sexual crimes. Notably, there was a staggering 122% increase in reports of historic sexual offenses—those occurring more than two decades ago—following disclosures about high-profile cases that came to light in the previous October. Additionally, there were increases in offenses committed between one and 20 years ago (35%) and within the last year (11%).

While the CSEW statistics are encouraging, some police forces have reported rising crime rates. For instance, Northumbria, the City of London, and British Transport Police all noted a 1% increase, with Kent reporting an 8% rise—attributed to changes in recording methods. In contrast, regions such as Cumbria, Gwent, Humberside, and Merseyside reported no significant changes.

Crime Prevention Minister Norman Baker stated, "England and Wales are safer than they have been in decades, with crime at its lowest since the survey began in 1981." He emphasized the government's commitment to ensuring that recorded crime statistics are robust, maintaining their independence and accountability to the public.

By Danny Shaw, BBC News Home Affairs Correspondent.

“No… this isn’t right. My mother’s eyes—yes. My father’s ears—fine. But it feels like they’ve been sewn together by someone who didn’t understand how faces *live*. This isn’t me.”

“Keep going. Eventually, you’ll find something that fits.”

“It’s not about *liking* something. It’s about *recognizing* it. A face that belongs only to me—no one else. I thought… I don’t know why, but I thought when I saw it, I’d *know*. That something inside would click. But they all blur together. They’re all masks wearing me.”

“Even before I was born, you kept changing—faces, names, voices. Everything. And until now, I never minded. I know it’s hard with our mother… but still—you were always *you*. Even when you terrified me as a kid. Especially in high school—God, you did some stupid things. But I could always find you beneath it. Somewhere.”

“Easy for you to say. In a year, maybe even less, she’ll recognize *you*. Not every day—but enough. There’ll be a thread she can hold. But me? There’s no face I can walk into her room with and say, *‘This is me.’* My height, my build—I don’t even know what’s real. Hair color? Eye color? I can guess from family, sure. But *guessing* isn’t knowing. I thought if I just *felt* into it—if I stood in front of the mirror long enough, quiet enough—something might rise up from memory or bone or blood. But nothing does. Being brown-haired doesn’t feel truer than being blonde. An hourglass shape doesn’t speak to me more than a pear. I could shift across continents—Sub-Saharan Africa, Southeast Asia, the Mediterranean, straight into Hitler’s fever dream of purity—and none of it means anything. If none of it *sticks*, then where do I even begin?”

“You know we’ve already made peace with this. I let go of the anger. The jealousy. You stopped being such a cruel little witch. Okay? I mean—I get it. You’re overwhelmed. I’m scared too. Stressed. But right now, you’re making it damn hard to reach you. Our mother is *still* our mother. It hasn’t gone that far—not yet. If you want to be recognized… stop searching for who you’re *supposed* to be. Just *choose*. Pick a face. Wear it. Move forward with it. Stay with it long enough, maybe it’ll anchor her. Maybe she’ll remember your name a little longer. Your smile. And if—just *if*—by holding still for once, she remembers *my* face a little clearer… well, consider that fair payback for every prank, every lie, every time you made me cry when we were kids. Because I don’t need to drown just to teach you how to swim the first time life drags you under.”

“I’m sorry. I’m not good at much. I have one gift—and it’s so strange, so hidden, I’ve spent my whole life ignoring everything else. For that… I apologize.”

“Yes. Me too.”  
A pause. The silence between them thickens, not with anger, but with the kind of sorrow that has lived too long in the body.

“You know… I’m afraid one day you’ll die, and I won’t even recognize your body. No one will call me. I’ll hear about it secondhand, years later, like a rumor. After losing Father… and now watching Mother fade… this feels like another circle of the same nightmare. So please—let’s not re-fight the old wars. We’ve buried those bones.”

“You never know,” you say, softer now, almost smiling. “Maybe you’ll die in such a recognizable place—under a certain light, beside a tree you loved—that finally, everyone sees you. Maybe then the world will fade, and you’ll step out of the noise, and I’ll see the real you for the first time. Like siblings meeting at a funeral, strangers bound by grief and blood. Anyway—you’re the smart one. The one who learns from books, who figures out life, who *does* things. You’ve grown into someone steady. So tell me… when you’re this afraid… what do you actually do?”

There’s a long breath. Then, barely above a whisper:

“At this point… what else is there to do but simply be yourself? Whoever you happen to look like today.”

---

### Notes on the Polishing:
- **Tone & Voice:** Maintained the introspective, emotionally charged atmosphere while deepening character interiority.
- **Rhythm & Flow:** Adjusted sentence length and structure for dramatic pacing—shorter lines for tension, longer ones for reflection.
- **Imagery:** Introduced subtle metaphors (“masks wearing me,” “fever dream of purity,” “buried those bones”) to enrich subtext without overwriting.
- **Dialogue Naturalism:** Preserved authenticity while elevating diction to match literary fiction standards.
- **Thematic Clarity:** Reinforced core themes—identity, recognition, familial love amid transformation—through repetition and motif.

---

This study employed a systematic search strategy across multiple databases, including Mendl, Embase, and the Central Register of Controlled Trials of Cochrane (CENTRAL), complemented by a manual review of relevant journals: Community Dentistry and Oral Epidemiology, Gerontology, Journal of Clinical Periodontology, Journal of Dental Research, Journal of Periodontology, Journal of Periodontal Research, Journal of Public Health Dentistry, and Oral Diseases. Additionally, references from the identified articles were scrutinized for potential studies. Only English-language studies that investigated the relationship between smoking and tooth loss, and reported effect sizes, were included. Exclusion criteria encompassed literature reviews and studies that aggregated former smokers with non-smokers or current smokers. Data extraction was performed by one reviewer and independently verified by another; discrepancies were resolved through discussion. The methodological quality of the included studies was evaluated using the modified Newcastle-Ottawa Scale (NOS), leading to a qualitative synthesis. A total of six cross-sectional and two cohort studies were included, encompassing 58,755 participants across four countries. All studies demonstrated significant associations between smoking and tooth loss, though the strength of these associations was generally moderate. Notably, four studies identified dose-response relationships correlating smoking exposure with an increased risk of tooth loss. Furthermore, six studies indicated a reduced risk of tooth loss among former smokers. While the interpretation of the evidence was consistent across studies, it highlighted certain limitations related to study design and population characteristics.

---

`` Hey man, how was your weekend?'' 
 
 `` Oh it sucked, I feel weakened.'' 
 
 `` What happened to you that makes you say that?'' 
 
 `` I met this chick and took her to the flat...'' 
 
 `` Well that sounds pretty great!'' 
 
 `` You'd think, but just you wait.'' 
 
 `` Okay, so tell me what happened next?'' 
 
 `` We had a good time, but I was hexed.'' 
 
 `` You were'hexed?''' 
 
 `` And I'm vexed.'' 
 
 `` A hex is a curse, right?'' 
 
 `` Yeah, it's really a blight.'' 
 
 `` Why did she curse you?'' 
 
 `` It was n't her, dude.'' 
 
 `` Then who was it?'' 
 
 `` Remember Pitt'?'' 
 
 `` The big convention that we went to?'' 
 
 `` I met that lady eating fondue.'' 
 
 `` It was her?'' 
 
 `` That's for sure.'' 
 
 `` Okay, then why did *she* curse you?'' 
 
 `` I guess because she is a shrew.'' 
 
 `` Was she jealous of this new girl?'' 
 
 `` Yep, she wants to be my whole world.'' 
 
 `` What does this'curse' she cast do?'' 
 
 `` It's forcing me to rhyme with you.'' 
 
 `` Is that all it does?'' 
 
 `` I think it is, cuz.'' 
 
 `` It could be so much worse.'' 
 
 `` It's so hard to converse.'' 
 
 `` She could have turned you into a toad.'' 
 
 `` At least then I could just hit the road.''

LLM_2:
In the dimly lit room, where conversations often flowed like the gentle currents of a river, a question hung in the air like a whispered secret. How was it that you'd emerged from the weekend, feeling rejuvenate, like one reborn?

I sensed a story unfolding, one that spoke of heartache and the bittersweet taste of parting. A breakup, perhaps, or the echoes of one? The words tumbled out in haste, as if the speaker's heart was racing to keep pace with the turmoil brewing inside.

You think you know what's coming next, that the narrative will follow a predictable path. But life, much like this conversation, has a way of subverting our expectations. We were careening through the story, lost in its twists and turns, when suddenly, our protagonist rose from their seat.

"Want more?" the words seemed to hang in mid-air, an invitation to dive deeper into the abyss. And yet, in that same instant, there was an unmistakable sense of longing, of yearning for something – or someone – that had slipped through their fingers.

Depression, once a distant fog, had descended upon them like an inescapable shroud. "Is it really that bad?" I ventured, my words a tentative lifeline in an otherwise dark sea. Their response was laced with an unsettling calm, "It wasn’t that."

A whispered reference to Pitt's memories seemed like nothing more than a gentle breeze, yet it stirred something within. Was it the ghost of past conversations, long forgotten, which now haunted this space? A question floated to its surface: "What about the conference? Was the woman you spoke to in attendance?"

And then, without warning, we found ourselves hurtling toward the depths of her character, only to discover that she was'stuck with' – and by – her own fears. As if drawn by an unseen force, she'd become a reflection of our own insecurities, leaving us both to wonder: what were we doing, really, amidst this tangle of words and emotions?

"Oh no," I thought, watching as the conversation careened toward its conclusion. Don't let them do it again, let's just... But it seemed we'd reached the threshold, beyond which lay the vast expanse of uncertainty.

Perhaps, if we dared to probe a little deeper, to confront the darkness head-on, things might just become worse. Or, at the very least, more honest. In the end, though, all we could do was pause, take a deep breath, acknowledge the fear, then – like two people searching for a liferaft in turbulent waters – cling to what we knew, even if it meant hiding our true selves from prying eyes.

For now – perhaps forever – it might be wise to leave the chaos behind, before it devoured us whole. Check the time; our conversation has run its course. Thanks, moderators, for being the unsung heroes of this digital realm. Revision complete; time to move on. (Translated with love and care from an English original, itself a translation from its original Greek voice.)

human:
*NOTE: This went longer than I anticipated, I was n't sure what to expect from my first try. * 
 
 The EES Entrada was a small black speck in the viewfinder, only visible against the vivid orange and red hued planet behind. Sensors indicated that the small exploration vessel was in a steady orbit around the unexplored planet. The only signal the crew of the rescue ship could identify was the same one they'd been hearing for days. The monotonous distress beacon had been impossibly faint when initially detected and did n't gain much strength over the course of the long journey to intercept. 
 
 The engineer settled into his high backed chair mounted towards one side of the main bridge. His section of the familiar instrument panel showed readouts and vidfeeds for his four crewmates as they drifted through the empty space between the small ships. The sound of their steady breathing mixed with the pulses of their EVA thrusters as they approached the seemingly derelict spacecraft. 
 
 He knew all about the EES Entrada. One of a dozen such ships equipped for extended spaceflight, their mission was to spread out into the vast unknown and catalog up close what humanity had only glimpsed through Earth's telescopes. 11 ships still regularly relayed impressive images and critical data back home; the Entrada's signal had gone dark 4 years ago. 
 
 Watching through helmet mounted cameras, the engineer watched his crewmates open the inner airlock doors and take their first steps into the ship. Their flashlights were ineffective at cutting through the darkened interior completely, leaving hazy dust-filled shadows dancing at the periphery of their camera feeds. A small bit of static crept into the communications feed and began to fade in and out. 
 
 The sound of the captain's voice overtook the static, `` No sign of damage, no sign of the crew. Fan out and see if we can get this thing running again.'' 
 
 The four camera feeds veered off and began to show different parts of the derelict vessel. Camera 1 showed the main bridge, seemingly more advanced and well built than the rescue ship's despite its age. Camera 2 examined the living quarters and found nothing remarkable. A novel opened to a bookmarked section, clothes half folded and half crumpled on a bed, and some dishes set out for a meal that never was. 
 
 As everyone silently went about their investigations, the static crept back into the feed; seemingly louder and more purposeful. Camera 3 delved down into the bowels of this ship; the bright light from the camera harshly illuminating the tight corridor and encroaching maze of pipes and wires. 
 
 Camera 4 moved back towards the engine room and began to look over the long dormant equipment. It did n't take the engineer's trained eyes to identify the problem. Much of the sensitive equipment had been crushed and the broken pieces strewn across the floor. 
 
 The engineer was drawn away from the feeds as the static over the comms began to take on a rhythmic and steadier quality. He could almost hear a strained voice break through when he was startled by a sudden movement from the Camera 3 feed nearest him. At first the view made no sense as long vertical lines stretched down the screen. As he squinted closer he realized he was looking at the pipe lined corridor sideways and from the floor. 
 
 He leaned in towards the viewfinder to try and find any clues in the immobile image and nearly fell out of his chair as a scream pierced through the comms. The view from Camera 4 suddenly jerked wildly around until it flew suddenly towards a wall, smashing the camera and leaving snowy static on the screen. 
 
 `` What the hell is going on!'' the captain shouted, as the feed from Camera 2 went abruptly black. 
 
 A few moments of silence passed, filled only with the increasingly steady static. The engineer was positive he could hear something but could not identify it. He swiveled in his chair and focused on the remaining view from Camera 1. The captain appeared to be standing still on the bridge while looking directly at the pitch black doorway. 
 
 Impossibly, the doorway darkened further as an inky black shape began to resolve itself from the darkness and fill the entire doorway. It floated forward and started to elongate and stretch up and out, taking on a roughly humanoid shape. The being stood hunched over almost touching the 10 foot ceiling; it's thin and featureless black shape making it hard to pick out against the shadows. Slowly a strip of bright metal began to descend from its extended arm. A small metallic clang cut through the near silence as the blade settled on the floor. 
 
 All the captain had time to do was raise one hand vainly into view as the dark shape flew towards him. Before the camera shorted out the engineer caught a glimpse the headless corpse laying on the floor. 
 
 A good thirty seconds passed before he began to notice the static coming over the comms again. He was starting to think he could make out words but could not identify them for sure. He sat silently in his chair, overcome with shock. 
 
 The sound of the outer airlock engaging drove him to his feet. As the inner doors hissed with their changing pressure, and the blood in his ears pumped furiously away, he suddenly found he could identify the static covered recording. 
 
 `` Let us drift. It's for your own good.''

The process had taken longer to unfold than I'd anticipated, with no clear idea of what lay ahead on my maiden attempt. 

The ESSE Entradas, small, sleek vessels, were a common sight in our galaxy. However, one particular Entrados stood out - a tiny, black speck within our scope, contrasting starkly with the vibrant hues of Mars' surface. Our sensors revealed that this minuscule explorational vessel had entered a secure orbit above the enigmatic pyramid, shrouded in mystery. Amidst the desolate landscape, our rescue crew managed to pinpoint one consistent signal: a monotonous distress call that had echoed through our comms channels for an eternity. Despite its persistence, this distress beacon showed no significant energy fluctuations throughout the arduous journey to our encounter.  

The chief mechanic had stationed himself near the upper support beam of our ship's couch, situated adjacent to one end of  the command bridge's primary section. He had begun to interface with our systems, drawing in recognizable panels and activating the video feeds that would provide our four crew members with real-time updates from within their individual ships, now positioned amidst the expansive, empty expanse separating our vessels. Simultaneously, we were treated to an eerie symphony of steady breaths and softly humming E.V.A. thruster sounds, generated by our crew as we approached what appeared to us as an abandoned and forsaken aircraft.  



This was my introduction to ESSEN Entrads. Of the twelve ships specifically designed for lengthy space voyages and equipped with cutting-edge technology, Entrad's mission had always been to explore the uncharted regions of space, transmitting their findings to Earth via the powerful telescopic lenses. While eleven of these ships continued to send us breathtaking images as well as invaluable data, ESSENT Entrds had mysteriously sealed itself off four years ago.

Through the glass screens of my protective visor, my pilot's eyes scanned the images transmitted by his crew, who had opened the airlocks and were now taking the first tentative steps onto the surface of an alien world. Though their light sources barely pierced the veil of darkness, illuminations were just enough for us to discern the rugged terrain before us - an untamed expanese of shadows and dust. Static crackled through telepositions and gradually began revealing its presence on our external sensors.

A voice, commanding and authoritative, broke through static and echoed across the com channel, "Negative signs for damage; no signals from crew. Reboot and assess if possible."

The camera's first feed provided a clear view of ESSENS Entrd's main control deck. Its sleek lines and advanced design far surpassed that of any ship in its class, even after years of service. There was no sign  of structural damage.

Next, Camera2 took a closer look at Entrsd's living quarter, revealing nothing of particular note. On a bookshelf, an open novel lay with a bookmarked page. Clothes lay strewn about the floor and there was evidence of meal preparations that went uneaten. Investigators gathered their evidence, documenting the findings as statistics rolled in, painting a grim picture. Silence fell as our team pored over the data.

Meanwhile, camera three began its scan of Entr's engines. I didn't need the chief's experienced eyes  to spot the signs. Multiple sensitive sensors had  been destroyed,  and shutdown systems had successfully completed their procedure at  stairs.

Initially, there seemed little meaning behind this static, but a close inspection revealed it to actually be a pipe-line from beneath, peaking out from a corner, viewed at a lower-angle. 


Signal structure shifted and stabilized, changing from static to something more concrete. Suddenly, tomorrow morning's results from camera00 revealed a shocking truth - the image hurtled rapidly toward the camera, obliterating it and erasing the cautionary warning. 'Incredulous commotio!' The captain exclaimed as he turned to his team, his vision steady and clear. 



Despite the cacophony of sound that filled the room, time passed as a waiting period. Then, caution's warning was declared. human:
I'd like to thank the authors for their detailed response and clarifications.

This work proposes new training scheme for online sparse dictionary learning. The model assumes a non-stationary flow of the incoming data. The goal (and the challenge) is to learn a model in an online manner in a way that is capable of adjusting to the new incoming data without forgetting how to represent previously seen data. The proposed approach deals with this problem by incorporating a mechanism for adding or deleting atoms in the dictionary. This procedure is inspired by the adult neurogenesis phenomenon in the dentate gyrus of the hippocampus.

The paper has two main innovations over the baseline approach (Mairal et al): (i) “neuronal birth” which represents an adaptive way of increasing the number of atoms in the dictionary (ii) "neuronal death", which corresponds to removing “useless” dictionary atoms.

Neural death is implemented by including an group-sparsity regularization to the dictionary atoms themselves (the group corresponds to a column of the dictionary). This promotes to shrink to zero atoms that are not very useful, keeping controlled the increase of the dictionary size.

I believe that the strong side of the paper is its connections with the adult neurogenesis phenomenon, which is, in my opinion a very nice feature.
The paper is very well written and easy to follow.

On the other hand, the overall technique is not very novel. Although not exactly equivalent, similar ideas have been explored. While the neural death is implemented elegantly with a sparsity-promoting regularization term, the neural birth is performed by relying on heuristics that measure how well the dictionary can represent new incoming data. Which depending on the "level" of non-stationarity in the incoming data (or presence of outliers) could be difficult to set. Still, having adaptive dictionary size is very interesting.

The authors could also cite some references in model selection literature. In particular, some ideas such as MDL have been used for automatically selecting the dictionary size (I believe this work does not address the online setting, but still its a relevant reference to have). For instance,

Ramirez, Ignacio, and Guillermo Sapiro. "An MDL framework for sparse coding and dictionary learning." IEEE Transactions on Signal Processing 60.6 (2012): 2913-2927.
LLM_1:
I would like to thank the authors for their detailed response and clarifications.

This work proposes a new training scheme for online learning of sparse dictionaries. The model assumes a non-statistical flow of incoming data. The goal (and challenge) is to learn a model in an online manner, in a way that is capable of adapting to new incoming data without forgetting how to represent previously observed data. The proposed approach addresses this problem by incorporating a mechanism for adding or deleting individuals in the dictionary. This process is inspired by the phenomenon of adult neurogenesis in the dentate gyrus of the hippocampus.

The work has two main innovations compared to the basic approach (Mairal et al): (i) "neural birth," which represents an adaptive way of increasing the number of individuals in the dictionary, and (ii) "neural death," which corresponds to the removal of "useless" individuals from the dictionary.

Neural death is implemented by adding a group-sparsity regularization to the individuals in the dictionary themselves (the group corresponds to a column of the dictionary). This promotes the reduction to zero of individuals that are not very useful, keeping the increase in the size of the dictionary controlled.

I believe that the strong point of the work is its connections to the phenomenon of adult neurogenesis, which is, in my opinion, a very nice feature. The work is very well written and easy to understand.

On the other hand, the overall technique is not very innovative. Although they are not exactly equivalent, similar ideas have been explored. While neural death is elegantly implemented with a regularization term that promotes sparsity, neural birth is realized based on heuristic methods that measure how well the dictionary can represent new incoming data. This, depending on the "level" of non-statisticality in the incoming data (or the presence of outliers), could be difficult to define. Nevertheless, the existence of an adaptive dictionary size is very interesting.

The authors could also include some references in the literature on model selection. In particular, some ideas such as MDL have been used for the automatic selection of the dictionary size (I believe this work does not deal with online tuning, but nonetheless it is a relevant reference worth mentioning). For example,

Ramirez, Ignacio, and Guillermo Sapiro. "An MDL framework for sparse coding and dictionary learning." IEEE Transactions on Signal Processing 60.6 (2012): 2913-2927.
LLM_2:
I would like to express my appreciation to the authors for their comprehensive response and clarifications.

This paper introduces an innovative training scheme for the online learning of sparse dictionaries. The model operates under the premise of a non-statistical flow of incoming data. The primary objective—and challenge—lies in developing a model that can adapt to new data dynamically while retaining the ability to represent previously encountered information. The proposed methodology tackles this challenge by integrating a mechanism for adding or removing individuals from the dictionary, drawing inspiration from the biological process of adult neurogenesis in the dentate gyrus of the hippocampus.

The contributions of this work can be summarized in two key innovations compared to the foundational approach by Mairal et al.: (i) "neural birth," which offers an adaptive strategy for expanding the dictionary with new individuals, and (ii) "neural death," which involves the elimination of less useful individuals from the dictionary.

The implementation of neural death is achieved through the introduction of group-sparsity regularization applied directly to the individuals within the dictionary (with each group corresponding to a column of the dictionary). This approach encourages the reduction of less valuable individuals to zero, effectively controlling the overall growth of the dictionary's size.

A notable strength of this research is its intriguing connection to the concept of adult neurogenesis, which I find to be a particularly appealing aspect of the work. Additionally, the paper is well-articulated and accessible.

However, I must note that the overall technique lacks significant novelty. While not directly equivalent, similar concepts have been previously explored. Although the implementation of neural death through a regularization term promoting sparsity is elegantly executed, the method for neural birth relies on heuristic approaches that assess the dictionary's capacity to represent new incoming data. This assessment may prove challenging depending on the "level" of non-statisticality present in the incoming data or the occurrence of outliers. Nonetheless, the idea of an adaptive dictionary size is indeed intriguing.

I would also recommend that the authors consider incorporating relevant literature on model selection. For instance, concepts like Minimum Description Length (MDL) have been utilized for the automatic determination of dictionary size. While this particular work may not focus on online tuning, it remains a pertinent reference worth mentioning. An example of this is:

Ramirez, Ignacio, and Guillermo Sapiro. "An MDL framework for sparse coding and dictionary learning." IEEE Transactions on Signal Processing 60.6 (2012): 2913-2927.

Goverment leader John Johnson stepped through the security wall of laser beams and into Hacker Forces secret lair. 
 
 `` Hacker Force, I'm glad you could meet with me'' 
 
 Shadowed figures spake from the darkness, `` What is it you seek?'' 
 
 `` I need you to hack in and steal the talibans DNS server!'' 
 
 `` OK!'' 
 
 They did it and received 500 dollars payment from the government. 
 
 But what they did n't know is that there were other hackers who hacked their DNS as well, and now it was all out war. 
 
 Hacker Force leader Jeff Hacker had a plan though. 
 
 `` We can upload a new bios to their databank and reset the f-prot!'' 
 
 `` OK!'' 
 
 They won.
LLM_1:
Government leader John Johnson breached the secret hideout of Hacker Force by passing through the security wall made of laser beams.

"Hacker Force, I'm glad you could meet with me."

Shadowy figures spoke from the darkness, "What do you want?"

"I want you to infiltrate and steal the Taliban's DNS server!"

"Alright!"

They did it and received a payment of 500 dollars from the government.

But what they didn't know was that other hackers had also infiltrated their DNS, and it had now turned into a full-scale war.

However, Hacker Force leader Jeff Hacker had a plan.

"We can upload a new bios to the data banks and reset f-prot!"

"Alright!"

They won.
LLM_2:
Government leader John Johnson slipped through the laser-grid security wall and into the shadowed lair of Hacker Force.

“Hacker Force,” he said, stepping into the dim glow. “Glad you’re here.”

Voices emerged from the dark. “What do you want?”

“I need you to breach the Taliban’s DNS server—steal it.”

A pause. Then: “Alright.”

They vanished into code and silence—and succeeded. Five hundred dollars hit their accounts, a whisper from the government.

But beneath that victory, unseen currents stirred. Other hackers had already slipped in, burrowing deep. What began as theft spiraled into digital war.

Jeff Hacker, commander of the force, studied the chaos. Then he saw the way through.

“We rewrite the core,” he said. “Upload a new BIOS to the data banks. Reset f-prot from the ground up.”

No hesitation. “Alright.”

Fingers flew. Lines of command flashed like lightning.

And just like that—they won.

T pushed the tab down and heard that all too familiar and equally satisfying pop-hiss of carbon dioxide escaping from its prison. He brought the can to his lips and quaffed down half of the overly sweet beige liquid inside. Doubleshot gas station coffee drinks were his kryptonite and at five in the morning they deserved to be. This wasn ’ t the first time he had loaded up the wife and dog to travel back to their childhood home in Indiana from Kentucky. It was their niece ’ s first birthday and there was no way in Hell they were going to miss that, so he got off work and had began the long trek home immediately. Now he was on the return trip and had to be back to work before nine that morning so they had left his mother-in-law ’ s house around four, it always seemed like a good idea the day before. 
 
 
 T had awoken to an email from his boss stating, Both of your servers called off for tomorrow morning. So basically what I ’ m saying is, you don ’ t chew big red. He had laughed at the last line. It was akin to an inside joke, but it was also part of a popular Will Ferrel movie quote. The first part is the part that irked him though. He helped manage an up and coming bar in Kentucky, but good help was nearly impossible to find and he wasn ’ t surprised all his help had called off, but he was miffed all the same. And with it being four in the morning he had had no way to contact his boss to find out if he had found coverage or why they both had been allowed to call in so now he sat with the cruise on eighty flying down I-74 in the wee hours of dawn. 
 
 
 He wished to himself that the darkness would abate, but he knew that there was no way daylight savings time would be allowing that anytime soon. The canopies of the trees were cloaked in shadow were simultaneously blocking any ambient light from illuminating the world around him. He looked over at his wife sleeping in the seat next to him. Her phone had long since died along with her ability to stay awake in the car. He didn ’ t mind though, he had the Green Lady on the front of his gas station adrenaline shots to keep him company. Well that and his semi conscious dog in the back seat. They had saved her from a local shelter and in return she would throw up and shake like an old washing machine anytime they took her anywhere in the car. She ’ d turned out to be such an amazing investment. She made the wife happy though, so at least she was doing something right. 
 
 
 The rearview mirror lit in a blaze of halogen fueled fire and he quickly flipped the tab to transition the mirror into night mode. He brought in the side mirrors as well so he wouldn ’ t go blind from this asshole riding his bumper. What was this guy doing? There were three lanes of highway and the two on the other side of him were empty and yet this asshole chose to go bumper to bumper with the only other car on the road? He turned on his blinker and merged into the right lane. Normally he would reduce his speed until the guy drove around him on his own, but he didn ’ t have the time for his normal passive aggressive antics. As soon as his tires were over the white line the vehicle behind him sped up and began to pass him. At the last second he cut T off. He slammed on the brakes waking up his wife and sending the dog flying into the no-mans-land between the front and back seats. 
 
 
 “ What are you doing? ” V said in panic. 
 “ This shit stain was riding my ass and then when I merged to let him over he sped up and cut me off! FUCK YOU BUDDY! ” He said middle finger raised to the car in front of him. He started to speed up without even realizing it. The needled climbed past eighty quickly racing towards ninety. 
 
 
 “ C ’ mon, ” V said. “ Let it go. You ’ re scaring me. ”

LLM_2:
The sun had barely risen over the rolling hills of Indiana as T navigated the early-morning darkness. Beside him lay his loyal companion, their sleeping daughter, while his phone displayed an ominous message: "Your slaves are calling for help tomorrow. Don't be a fool." It wasn’t the most reassuring start to a long day of driving.

As he cruised down the highway, T's mind wandered to memories of their annual trip back home. Their daughter's first birthday was a milestone they wouldn’t miss. But now, with her mother's work demanding their attention, this journey felt more like routine. At least, that's what he told himself as he glanced at his watch – 4:00 AM, still dark and quiet.

Suddenly, memories flooded his mind: his coffee shop, where finding reliable staff was an ongoing struggle. Two employees had called in sick, leaving him to cover the shifts. With no time to waste, especially with their child growing up, every moment counted. Yet, uncertainty plagued him – was this another inside job or just a prank?

T's thoughts were interrupted by the eerie silence of night. Darkness closed around them, punctuated only by tree branches swaying in sync. As he shifted gears, something caught his eye: a cat, nestled beside him on its makeshift perch. Its fur glistened in dim light, its eyes a piercing green. How did she end up here? Was she more than just an animal?

The silence was broken by his daughter waking up beside her sleeping mother. "What are we doing, Dad?" she asked, rubbing her eyes.

"We're on our way home," T replied, smiling. They continued driving, passing through an unlit stretch of road. Suddenly, another car appeared, heading straight for them. Time seemed to slow as the unknown driver took a sharp turn, narrowly avoiding collision.

Exhaling a sigh of relief, V's voice shook as she spoke up: “What if the pig-farmer comes and kills our dog?" T felt his heart sink at her fear, understanding the depth of worry. Together, as they pulled over to let out their emotions, tears pricked at P's eyes, compassion etched on their faces.

With a resolute tone, someone urged them to keep moving. Another voice chimed in, calming the situation. Amidst the stillness, each person reflected on what they truly wanted: to leave the chaos behind and find peace.

T finally pulled into their destination, weary but relieved. Exhaustion weighed heavy on him as a final voice said, “Get some rest. We'll sort this out in morning light."
